LEAD: A man whose two infant daughters died under similar circumstances within three years told police that his wife was upset after giving birth and apologized both times for not having boys.

LEAD: Calling for an ''all-out, all fronts fight'' against crime in New York City, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday proposed a major expansion of the state and city criminal justice systems, including additional police, probation officers and prison cells.
LEAD: To all appearances, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist came as a supplicant to testify before the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee last week.

LEAD: Over the years, choreographers have often created dances about people struggling on perilous journeys. It's understandable that they should do so, for struggle and peril lend themselves to choreographic treatment. At their best, such dances are metaphors for life's mystery and uncertainty. At their worst, they are cliche-ridden.

LEAD: In East Harlem, in an area of broad streets and red-brick high-rises just north and east of the green canopy of Central Park, street violence is as much a part of growing up as listening to rap music, teen-agers say: it has its own rhythms, and it is everywhere.

LEAD: Susie Berg Waldman, a writer and editor, died of bone cancer and pneumonia Sunday at New York University Hospital in Manhattan. She was 66 years old and lived in Riverdale.
LEAD: The bombs returned to the Bronx last night, but they weren't unleashed by the team that bears no resemblance to its ancestors.
LEAD: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about the National Transportation Safety Board misidentified its chairman. The acting chairman is James L. Kolstad.
LEAD: Each Wednesday morning Long Island's five Congressional Representatives meet behind closed doors to map strategy in the campaign to save the Grumman Corporation's F-14 Tomcat fighter.

LEAD: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., May 8 - Heralded by its trademark double sonic boom, the space shuttle Atlantis dropped through scattered clouds above the Mojave Desert and glided to a safe landing today in gusting winds.

LEAD: How many times in the summer have you wished for a wafer-thin coat? They're nice to toss on when it rains or it is a bit cool, or when you want to create a dramatic billowy effect. Yet these coats are always hard to find, particularly when warmer weather arrives. There are a few around town now, though they are apt to be available in limited quantities only.

LEAD: Cynical politics! Betrayal of the taxpayer! Soft on the Russians! On every side, President Bush's decision to subsidize wheat sales to the Soviet Union has ignited heated criticism. But even on brief reflection, the criticism looks hasty, even unfair. The costs of Mr. Bush's decision are small. The potential benefits are substantial.

LEAD: The new suburban Wilton is teeming with prosperous executives riding high in their weekend Broncos. The old, rural Wilton is Eugenia Slaughter. For half a century, Mrs. Slaughter has lived here on 20 acres of lush, rolling fields that are divided by stone walls and anchored by a 1757 farmhouse with a tilted red barn.

LEAD: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on March 29 misstated the fat content of a three-strip serving of bacon. As a fitness program manager has recently written to point out, the fat accounts for 81 calories and 77 percent of the caloric content.
LEAD: Hundreds of thousands of people march in the streets. The police are pushed back, and a Government shakes in fear of its own citizens.

LEAD: There is restraint and moderation in their method, and discipline is their password, which is why the Montreal Canadiens aren't chortling just because they are a game away from becoming the Wales Conference representative in the Stanley Cup final.

LEAD: Minutes after the Chicago Bulls' heart-stopping playoff victory Sunday, someone asked Doug Collins how he felt. The Bulls' coach was honest; he said he was drained. But he also said he felt a sense of anticipation looking ahead to Chicago's next challenge, the Knicks.

LEAD: In the rain and mud at Towson, Md., last Saturday night, the Johns Hopkins team's grasp at an undefeated season fell one goal short. LEAD: Bob Crable's injury-plagued career as a Jets linebacker, following his selection as the club's No. 1 draft pick of 1982, has officially ended. A knee injury suffered late in the 1987 season that required surgery and sidelined him all of last year was too much to overcome. The Jets will formally announce the 29-year-old's retirement today at a luncheon unveiling their 1988 highlight film.

Magadan, alerted to the fact and then considerably embarrassed by it, had to turn and pick the bat up again. He then promptly struck out.

LEAD: The Southland Corporation, the owner of 7-Eleven convenience stores, said it might sell its half-interest in the Citgo Petroleum Corporation and all or part of its distribution and food centers in order to reduce the debt it incurred in a leveraged buyout last year. Southland's bank debt totals $1.56 billion.

LEAD: Strikes by thousands of workers at Polish copper mines continued today after talks failed to produce an accord on pay. The strikes pose a serious challenge to the Government and are an acute embarrassment to the national leadership of the Solidarity trade union.
LEAD: Tally Brown, an actress and a cabaret performer, died after a stroke on Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 64 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Foundlings are often the stuff of Bible stories (Moses in the bulrushes) and fairy tales (princes placed on humble doorsteps). But they are also the reason the Sisters of Charity opened a hospital in New York City 120 years ago. In the hospital's first 10 weeks, 123 abandoned babies were given to the nuns.
LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* Environmental Power (OTC) Year to Dec 31 1988 1987 Revenue 514,341 389,783 Net loss 4,666,777 1,166,970

LEAD: Greg Mathews, a St. Louis Cardinal left-hander, will undergo surgery on his pitching elbow later this week and will miss the remainder of the season. The surgery on Mathews, 26, will involve the transfer of ligaments from his right wrist to his left elbow. After having soreness during spring training appearances, Mathews was sent to Louisville for a 20-day injury-rehabilitation assignment.

LEAD: New York City yesterday awarded five minority-owned construction companies contracts to build affordable housing in a new program intended to help such companies break into the city's mainstream real-estate development industry.

LEAD: In a game that opens up as many complex and bewildering possibilities as chess does, there is a natural inducement to head for the simple, sure thing, the pattern that gives you all the winning chances, or at least denies the opponent any. The trouble is that there is nothing simple about such a project.

LEAD: COMPANIES I.B.M. will introduce a series of software programs that will make it possible for desktop computer users to obtain information from a larger mainframe or minicomputer and integrate it into a program on a local machine. The programs, to be introduced next week, are regarded as I.B.M.
LEAD: * B. Altman & Co., the retailer, named Barbara Haskett vice president of public relations.

LEAD: There were suitcases to pack and last-minute details to attend to and even an appointment to keep at Forest Hills before Ivan Lendl boarded a flight to Europe last night where he will spend the next nine weeks in pursuit of the French Open and Wimbledon titles.
LEAD: The A. H. Robins Company, the pharmaceutical maker in its fourth year of Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization, today reported a 12.7 percent increase in earnings for the first quarter of 1989.

LEAD: Federal District Judge John G. Penn of Washington refused to give Stena A.B. of Sweden an injunction to prevent Sea Containers Ltd. of Bermuda from buying back its stock. The judge said Stena, a ferry company with 8.2 percent of Sea Containers' stock, had failed to establish that Sea Containers' disclosure papers were false and misleading.
LEAD: The shaky truce between warring Lebanese factions seemed to have crumbled today as heavy fighting in and around Beirut continued for the third day.

LEAD: A majority of the American people view Oliver North as ''well-meaning but misguided,'' according to a Gallup Poll taken after Mr. North's conviction last week on criminal charges stemming from his role in the Iran-contra affair.

LEAD: Although the New York Amateur Athletic Union All-Star team that went against the Soviet junior national basketball team at St. John's University last night was without the help of Kenny Anderson, who is still nursing a sore ankle, it did not need the 6-foot-2-inch all-American from Archbishop Molloy.

LEAD: For five years, Louis L. Brindisi has been trying to make corporate executives think like corporate raiders. Mr. Brindisi, a senior partner with a newly formed firm called Strategic Compensation Associates, a joint venture between Korn/Ferry International and the Management Compensation Group, argues that a ''raider mentality'' - a strong concern about the company's stock price -can help executives make their businesses more productive and profitable.

LEAD: THE ''AI Catalog'' from Thinking Software is a wonderful potpourri of programs for all personal computer users, from the rawest beginner to the experienced DOS jockey, including those who are just out for a good time.

LEAD: Britain today called for the rapid drafting of a new international convention to deal with the problem of global warming, saying rising temperatures could lead to disruption of normal life, political tension and war.

LEAD: With more than 40 percent of the vote in Bolivia's presidential elections yet to be counted, a former dictator and a wealthy businessman both declared victory today.

LEAD: The Spanish tenor Jose Carreras has postponed his recital at Carnegie Hall, scheduled for tomorrow evening, because of an ear infection that prevents him from flying. The performance has been rescheduled for May 25.
LEAD: The Pittsburgh Penguins' assistant general manager, Eddie Johnston, said yesterday he was leaving the club to look for another job in hockey.

LEAD: On the 51-member House Banking Committee, everyone is buzzing about it privately, few are willing to discuss it openly and the consensus is that it may be the best thing that has happened to the panel in years.

LEAD: Goldman, Sachs & Company announced yesterday that it was entering the equity investment management business and named Leon G. Cooperman, the firm's highly regarded market strategist, to run an expanded asset management division.

LEAD: Astronomers have detected the effects of a giant planet in orbit around a star. But having gained one planet, scientists have lost a planetoid in the solar system, which has now been classed a comet.

LEAD: HIT the ground running after a long flight and the effect of jet lag may be reduced, researchers say.

LEAD: Shane Rawley scattered eight hits in seven and two-thirds innings, and Kirby Puckett ended an 0-for-15 slump with a run-scoring double tonight to lead the Minnesota Twins to a 4-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

LEAD: In an effort to raise its endowment, Boston University plans to take out life insurance policies on some of its students and alumni, hoping to collect hundreds of millions of dollars when they die.
LEAD: The Varity Corporation agreed today to buy the Fruehauf Corporation for an estimated $650 million in cash, stock and notes.

LEAD: Kenneth J. Lynch, a skilled blacksmith who created many pieces of metalwork adorning New York City buildings, directed repairs on the Statue of Liberty in the late 1920's and twice restored the weather vane on Boston's Old North Church, died Thursday at his home in Wilton, Conn., after a long illness.

And facing his own ghosts is what Mr.

LEAD: Belmar raised beach fees in 1986 in part to keep blacks from visiting the seashore community, a state attorney said today in opening one in a series of trials aimed at lowering the cost of using New Jersey beaches.

LEAD: A former commander of the Argentine Air Force, Orlando Ramon Agosti, was released from prison today after completing his sentence for torture of political prisoners during the 1976-83 military regime.

LEAD: Yawning Q. Why do my mouth and eyes sometimes water when I yawn? A. The American Medical Association says that medical authorities believe the watering of the eyes may result from pressure on the main tear glands, at the outer margins of the eye sockets, because of the facial contortions involved in yawning.

LEAD: CYCLING A Top Sprinter Takes 3d Stage: Eric Vanderaerden of Belgium used team strategy, then sprinted away from a dozen riders yesterday to claim the Lehigh Valley to Harrisburg Road Race, the third stage of the Tour de Trump. Vanderaerden, considered one of the world's finest sprinters, rode conservatively into a steady headwind in a pack of about 50 riders during much of the 116.3-mile race through the farmlands of central Pennsylvania.

LEAD: The last two decades have seen a dramatic improvement in the ability to prevent and treat life-threatening heart disease. Changes in living habits, like eating less fat, stopping smoking and getting more exercise, are stemming the epidemic of coronary deaths. And the lives of those already afflicted with heart disease are being prolonged by coronary care units, pacemakers, bypass surgery and drugs that stimulate the heart, thin the blood and lower cholesterol and blood pressure.

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Chevrolet Lumina referred incorrectly to a fabric-protection product and misidentified its manufacturer. It is Scotchgard, from the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, not Du Pont.

LEAD: Customers at savings and loan associations withdrew $8.5 billion from their accounts in March, the Government said today in a report that showed only slight improvement from the sharp outflow of the first two months of this year.

LEAD: The Bush Administration is delaying development of key parts of Ronald Reagan's antimissile plan for two years while it studies a proposal that could radically alter it, the project's new director said today.

LEAD: Sears, Roebuck & Company is still searching for a new headquarters for its 6,000-person merchandising group, but the group prefers to stay in the Chicago area, said Edward A. Brennan, Sears's chairman. At a news conference after Sears's annual meeting, Mr. Brennan said Sears continued to review relocation proposals from cities around the country.

LEAD: The Bush Administration proposed comprehensive legislation today establishing a Federal fund to pay for cleaning up oil spills, an idea that had languished in Congress for years until the recent Alaskan spill.

LEAD: Two grandsons of Henry Ford, the founder of the Ford Motor Company, were named yesterday to the executive and finance committees of the company's board, an important step toward their goal of keeping a family member at or near the top of the company.

LEAD: On its silliest level, ''Earth Girls Are Easy'' is about three life-sized, fur-covered creatures - one red, one blue, one yellow - whose spaceship crashes into Geena Davis's swimming pool. On a slightly less goofy level, it is a nostalgic chance for baby boomers to escape to the toy-and-television culture of their childhoods.

LEAD: In three and a half years, Union Square Cafe has garnered a well-deserved national reputation as a paragon among a new breed of restaurants that might be called international bistros. Danny Meyer, the engaging young American owner, studied in Italy and France, but clearly his soul resides in Tuscany.
LEAD: The Amway Corporation said yesterday that if its $2 billion bid to buy Avon Products Inc. was successful, it would sell Avon's profitable retail division.
LEAD: Dan Wagoner is a choreographer who has always gone his own way, seemingly working within certain trends hovering in the air but actually applying a twist of fervent originality.

LEAD: Richard V. Secord, the former Air Force major general who sold weapons to Iran and diverted profits to the Nicaraguan rebels, has been indicted on nine criminal charges of lying to and obstructing the Congressional committees that investigated the Iran-contra affair, it was announced today.

LEAD: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev strolls on Chinese streets during the summit meeting planned next week to end three decades of hostility between China and the Soviet Union, he is expected to face a snub so blunt as to remind him that there is still a chill in the air.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: One of the better-kept secrets of the season in New York City is the astonishing change that has come over the West Gallery in the Frick Collection. This was always one of the great rooms of the world. The room was very handsome, though no longer in its first freshness. The mix of painting, sculpture and furniture was just about perfect.
LEAD: Constitutional Physics

LEAD: Kenneth A. Roberts, a former Democratic Representative from Alabama who was wounded in a 1954 shooting in the House of Representatives, died Tuesday at his daughter's home in Potomac, Md., after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Anniston, Ala.

LEAD: IN ''Only Kidding,'' Jim Geoghan's acidly funny dissection of the stand-up comedy jungle, Andrew Hill Newman and Paul Provenza portray a rising young comedy duo whose partnership explodes when one wants to sign a contract with a sleazy club owner and the other doesn't.
LEAD: Senate and House negotiators agreed today on a $1.17 trillion Federal budget for the 1990 fiscal year, a spending plan that leaves many prickly decisions for later.

LEAD: Changing a government while the old one and the people who run it are still around is never easy. And nothing shows more surely how troublesome that process can be than the efforts of the New York City Charter Revision Commission.
LEAD: Arnold P. Collery, an authority on international economics and former dean of Columbia College, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

LEAD: Most people doubt the existence of flying saucers, but not Kyusik Kim, an engineer in Santa Barbara, Calif. He has designed one himself, and said it would be many times as fast as winged aircraft if it were ever built. ''Conventional aircraft have long wing spans, which create a lot of drag,'' Mr.
LEAD: Rick Reuschel won his 200th game and his 25th against the Expos tonight as the San Francisco Giants beat Montreal, 2-1.

LEAD: R. Philip Custer, emeritus senior member of the Fox Chase Cancer Center, Philadelphia, whose career in cancer research spanned nearly six decades, died of congestive heart failure May 3 at his home in Narberth, Pa. He was 85 years old.
LEAD: Soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian today and wounded at least 10 others in clashes in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, Arab reports said.
LEAD: Four members of a group intended to steer children away from drugs and crime were convicted of first-degree manslaughter today in the beating death of an 8-year-old girl.

LEAD: In a long-awaited speech on Soviet-American policy, President Bush said today that the United States was ready to welcome the Soviet Union ''back into the world order.'' But he cautioned that Moscow still had to earn the right to a new and warmer relationship with Western nations.

LEAD: A great sitarist, like any other classical virtuoso, must have a command of extremes, from infinitesimal subtleties of pitch and timbre to crowd-pleasing displays of speed. Unlike Western classical musicians, a sitarist reveals his prowess in music that is likely to be almost entirely improvised.
LEAD: The Detroit Pistons needed a spark tonight and John Salley came off the bench to provide it.

LEAD: Richard Dotson continued his sudden rise from mop-up reliever to Yankee savior tonight when he pitched seven innings and earned his first victory of the season in a 5-2 decision over the California Angels at Anaheim Stadium.
LEAD: Two Massachusetts teen-agers who had earlier told a state trooper they were on foot because their car had broken down were struck and killed by a passenger train Thursday night.

LEAD: Acting on a request by the Bush Administration, the Senate voted today to delay an ethics law that has prompted at least 36 high-level officials to resign from the Pentagon and the space agency.

LEAD: ''A new relationship cannot simply be declared by Moscow, or bestowed by others. It must be earned because promises are never enough. The Soviet Union has promised a more cooperative relationship before, only to reverse course and return to militarism.'' - President Bush. [ 1:6. ]

LEAD: The first remote control in any household is a blessing and the second is a joy, but as these blessings mount, they clutter up your coffee table - and the one you want always seems to be under a newspaper or the cat.

LEAD: Steve Ross's program at L'Omnibus de Maxim's, Madison Avenue at 61st Street, where he will be singing at the piano Wednesdays through Saturdays until June 3, pays its respects to the well-established sources one might expect in such a setting - Cole Porter, the Gershwins, Noel Coward.

LEAD: Marian Tyler Chase, co-author of several books with her husband, the economist Stuart Chase, died of pneumonia May 4 at a nursing home in Danbury, Conn. She was 92 years old and lived in Redding, Conn.

LEAD: The Australian Olympic Federation has lifted a lifetime ban on the modern pentathlete Alex Watson, who was disqualified from the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, last year after failing a drug test.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Esteban de Jesus, the World Boxing Council lightweight champion from 1976 through 1978, died of AIDS yesterday at his home in San Juan, P.R. He was 37 years old.

LEAD: Hundreds of Rutgers University students protesting tuition increases occupied the office of the dean of students today in a demonstration that lasted several hours and led to the arrest of about 50 people.

LEAD: An article on May 5 about President Bush's plans to nominate Gwendolyn S. King as head of the Social Security Administration misstated the number of Federal employees she would oversee. It is 65,000.

LEAD: The forest of Arden is transporting, magically turning the urbanized into the countrified and uniting lovers of contrasting guises. ''As You Like It'' is a blithe pastoral comedy that draws its strength primarily from the character of Rosalind, that most attractive and witty of Shakespearean heroines.

LEAD: Tomorrow being the 75th anniversary of Mother's Day, the subject is flowers. While the holiday has yet to become the biggest flower-giving occasion - that honor goes to Christmas - it ranks No. 2, nipping Valentine's Day in the bud. Mother's Day accounts for 13 percent of all flowers sold during the year.
LEAD: U.N. Unit Delays on P.L.O.
LEAD: Randy Kraft, a computer programmer accused of leading a double life as a brutalizer and killer of 37 young men in three states, was convicted of 16 murders today.

LEAD: As unpredictable as the recent weather in Ohio, Fuzzy Zoeller left everyone gaping in disbelief today as he not only maintained his lead in the 14th annual Memorial Tournament, but also increased it from one stroke to five. He did so with an amazing nine-birdie second round of six-under-par 66 in a cold, miserable rain.

LEAD: Sixteen people were charged yesterday with running a money-laundering operation that funneled $100 million a year from cocaine sales in New York to Colombia and Panama, Federal authorities said.
LEAD: Two men and a woman were found shot to death in a Bronx apartment yesterday afternoon, but the woman's 4-month-old daughter was found unharmed in her crib, the police said.
LEAD: A Government study issued today found that 69 general hospitals with 4,233 beds closed in 1987, for reasons that included shortages of doctors and patients.

LEAD: An investment group led by George S. Mann, the Canadian investor, said it was in talks with third parties interested in participating in a possible tender offer for Dunkin' Donuts Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Mann did not identify the parties with whom he was talking.

LEAD: International 3-7 President Bush's Soviet policy was outlined in a long-awaited speech. He cautioned that Moscow still had to earn warmer ties with the West and resurrected a proposal for East-West aerial surveillance. Page 1 Moscow's latest nuclear arms cut was welcomed by the Western allies, but diplomats said the move only aggravates the divisions within NATO over negotiations on curbing short-range missiles.

LEAD: Federal Food and Drug Administration inspectors made an unusual visit to the Northvale, N.J., plant of Barr Laboratories Inc. 15 minutes after Barr had told a Congressional committee that the F.D.A. was improperly delaying its drug-marketing applications, the company said yesterday.

LEAD: Mingus Dynasty will play the music of Charles Mingus tonight and tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at Perry Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.
LEAD: Angered by a scathing state review of his agency, New York City's welfare chief in effect challenged the state yesterday to take over the city's beleaguered social-service system.

LEAD: An article on May 4 about Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's veto of funds for a New York State wildlife pathology laboratory referred incorrectly to Ward Stone, the laboratory supervisor. He is not a doctor.

LEAD: A new electronic device holds promise for the creation of computers that will operate using internal laser beams rather than the conventional currents of electricity. The device enables a hundred tiny lasers to be packed onto a computer chip.

LEAD: Bob Wade, whose program has been under investigation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for nearly three months, has resigned as basketball coach at the University of Maryland, the school's president, William E. Kirwan, announced yesterday.

LEAD: Despite complaints about bullying and threats of retaliation, the United States has reaped positive results from the pressure it put on its trading partners, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today.

LEAD: Before an altar ablaze with white candles, thousands of New Yorkers - from schoolchildren to leaders of the city and state -filled the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday to commemorate Dr. Richard R. Green as a man of hope and inspiration.
LEAD: Strategic Weapons

LEAD: As democracy was being mugged in Panama, it was showing surprising resilience this week in Bolivia, a country once synonymous with instability. An orderly presidential vote produced no majority winner, so the final selection will again be made by the congress when it convenes in August. Strikingly, the front-runners are Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, the architect of a tough economic stabilization plan, and former President Hugo Banzer, who endorses it.

LEAD: In the weeks before the Knicks finally acquired Kiki Vandeweghe, every New York basketball lab technician wondered how the 30-year-old jump-shooter with the bad back would affect the ''chemistry'' of this young team. But as the Knicks awaited today's third game of their Eastern Conference semifinal with the Bulls in Chicago, their test tubes were bubbling over with a new potion.

LEAD: Rick Leach, the Texas Rangers outfielder who disappeared in New York for 24 hours earlier this week and was issued a summons for marijuana possession, has been ordered to undergo drug counseling and testing, the baseball commissioner's office said yesterday.
LEAD: The World Health Organization today set aside a Palestinian application for admission as a member state. The application had been strongly opposed by Israel and the United States.
LEAD: Clanking past Lodz's gracefully decaying Hotel Polonia, the gleaming trolley's flanks flashed red and white Solidarity slogans left and right.

LEAD: C. S. Harding Mott, who teamed with his father to develop and sustain what is now the nation's 12th largest charitable foundation, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 82 years old and had residences in Delray Beach, Fla., and Flint.
LEAD: A Federal judge today accepted a plan to pay up to $100 million to settle hundreds of lawsuits stemming from the December 1986 fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel that killed 97 people.

LEAD: New York City has agreed to pay $75,000 to settle a $145 million wrongful-death suit filed by the mother of 17-year-old Edmund E. Perry, the prep school graduate who was shot to death by an undercover police officer in Harlem nearly four years ago.

LEAD: Midori, the remarkable Japanese violinist, is 17 years old now, and despite her diminutive stature has long since graduated to a full-size violin -a Guarnerius del Jesu, in fact, which not all 17-year-olds get to play. She and her mother and her management have been properly cautious about capitalizing on her fame as a prodigy.
LEAD: Emanuel R. Posnack, a patent lawyer, inventor and author, died of congestive heart failure last Saturday at his home in Great Neck. L.I. He was 92 years old.

LEAD: The House ethics committee has requested the bank records of a $100,000 loan that House Speaker Jim Wright received in 1983 to finance his investment in a nursing home business, a bank official said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Congress went down to defeat in Washington Thursday, but it was an honorable defeat. Playing against some giants of the corporate world with much greater bridge experience, a group of Senators and Representatives lost by the narrow margin of 15 imps, 39 to 54.

LEAD: Beirut residents ventured out of their bomb shelters today as another cease-fire went into effect. But having seen six truces collapse since a new cycle of violence erupted in Lebanon two months ago, residents on both sides of the divided city capitalized on the respite from fighting to flee the city.

LEAD: The Delaware River Basin Commission ended its drought warning yesterday, making additional water available to New York City, as city officials considered lifting some emergency measures imposed before the drenching rains of recent weeks.

LEAD: The dollar swung wildly yesterday in hectic trading, falling sharply amid aggressive dollar-selling by central banks before rebounding to new highs for the year against the yen and the West German mark.

LEAD: Sales of United States savings bonds fell 11.1 percent, to $634 million, in April, the Government said Thursday. The Treasury Department said sales in April were down by $79 million from March, when sales had risen 3.2 percent. The drop, however, was only the second in the first seven months of the Government's fiscal year, which began Oct.
LEAD: Playground safety has taken on a new urgency this year.
LEAD: Howard F. Corcoran, a retired judge of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia, died of complications of cancer Thursday at his home in Washington. He was 83 years old.
LEAD: The Koch administration has told the City University of New York that it will propose a budget cut of only $1 million for the university's seven community colleges in the 1989-90 fiscal year.
LEAD: A former lobbyist for Teledyne Electronics was sentenced today to six months in prison for his role in a scheme to pay bribes for inside information about a military contract.

LEAD: TENNIS Lendl and Becker Gain: Ivan Lendl and Boris Becker, the top two seeded players, reached the semifinals of the German Open tournament yesterday in Hamburg, West Germany. Lendl beat Jonas Svensson of Sweden, 6-2, 6-2, and Becker advanced when his opponent, Paolo Cane of Italy, defaulted because of a strained hamstring.
LEAD: A Government panel voted today to abandon a dam project on the Danube, calling it ''a symbol of Hungary's mismanaged economic development,'' the official press agency reported.
LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor met last night with relatives of two of the suspects in the rape and beating of a jogger in Central Park.
LEAD: A chemical engineer at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation has invented a plasma ''curtain'' to break up the hazardous byproducts in the smoke of municipal waste incinerators.

LEAD: Western allies today welcomed Moscow's latest nuclear arms cut, but diplomats said the Soviet move had only aggravated the divisions in the NATO alliance over talks on reducing short-range nuclear weapons.

LEAD: An entry in the People listing of the Advertising column in Business Day yesterday referred incorrectly in some editions to the magazine that has named George C. Fields Jr. as publisher. It is Decorating Remodeling.

LEAD: The California Supreme Court's recent decision on Proposition 103 contains a lesson for the nation: On the subject of automobile insurance, there's no free ride. Instead of seeking relief from high rates in plebiscites, consumers would do better to demand measured, rational legislative remedies, beginning with genuine no-fault insurance.

LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc. said today that it had reached an agreement to produce computer memory chips at a new $250 million plant in Taiwan that it would build with Acer Inc., a broad-based electronics company that is also Taiwan's largest maker of computers and telecommunications equipment.
LEAD: Whitley, a rising star of country music, was found dead in bed at his suburban home Tuesday. He was 33 years old.
LEAD: In a reflection of newly strengthened provisions of the Fair Housing Act, a Florida mobile home community has agreed to pay a black New Jersey woman $40,000 for discrimination.
LEAD: Is the West, in its eagerness to end the cold war, turning a blind eye to Soviet domestic policies that contradict Mikhail Gorbachev's engaging rhetoric of democratic renovation?
LEAD: David Glaser, a former principal of the Elisabeth Irwin High School in Manhattan, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Hyde Park, N.Y. He was 64 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Christopher Wright, a physicist who studied science policies in relation to other aspects of contemporary life, died of lymphoma Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 62 years old.

LEAD: The man who is widely expected to be South Africa's next President today promised a restructuring of the Constitution to give the black majority a greater political role, but ruled out majority rule.
LEAD: Even to Nguyen Xuan Oanh himself, hardly a modest man, it all seems just a bit improbable.
LEAD: The slow pace of filling jobs in the Administration has brought complaints that nobody is in charge to solve a backlog of problems. Page 9.

LEAD: Four years ago Lloyd Daniels was hailed as the best high school basketball player to emerge from the streets of New York City in two decades. Sportswriters compared him to Connie Hawkins and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and saw him as a future N.B.A. superstar.
LEAD: A gene previously linked to breast cancer has also been found in ovarian tumors, researchers reported in a study published today.
LEAD: President Bush announced Thursday that he had selected Janet Dempsey Steiger, a longtime personal friend, to be chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.

LEAD: A former senior aide to George Bush ran into fierce opposition today as he tried to convince Democratic senators that neither he nor Mr. Bush knew about the Reagan Administration's clandestine program to arm the Nicaraguan contras until late 1986.

LEAD: One field goal, more than any of their other 46, symbolized the Knicks' 114-97 victory over the Chicago Bulls that tied their Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series at one game each Thursday night at Madison Square Garden.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the Exxon Corporation's decision to add an environmentalist to its board of directors misidentified Exxon's president. He is Lee R. Raymond. The article also misstated the composition of a proposed committee of Exxon directors to study environmental problems.

LEAD: Now celebrating its 10th anniversary, the Chicago International Art Exposition is, by exhibitor and visitor consensus, one of the best and biggest art fairs in the world. Thanks to good management, a spectacular site on Navy Pier - a 1916 landmark that thrusts three-quarters of a mile into Lake Michigan - and the solid support of Chicago's art community, the fair draws dealers from all over the world.
LEAD: Laura Davies, Cindy Rarick and Marci Bozarth shared the lead today after the first round of the Chrysler-Plymouth Classic, the 13th Ladies' Professional Golf Association event this year.

LEAD: Pygmies from the rain forests of Zaire, their bodies dappled in paint, cross the stage in a loping crouch, singing in complex, staggered counterpoint. From Niger, two pipers with puffed cheeks (on the shawm-like alghaita) and two drummers, all in long robes, move in slow processional, playing starkly penetrating melodies.

LEAD: The Bush Administration has proposed rewriting a major job training program that Vice President Dan Quayle helped to draft when he was a Senator. The proposed revisions would direct most spending under the program to teen-agers and the poor.

LEAD: For openers, Gary Carter came to work with a swollen right knee and a .114 batting average, and was placed on the disabled list. After that, the evening rapidly deteriorated for the Mets, just when they came soaring home to face the West with a clear shot at first place in the East.

LEAD: Can elderly people have too much private health insurance? And do they pay too much for it? The answers are often yes, said witnesses at two Congressional hearings on policies that supplement the Government's Medicare coverage.
LEAD: Few matters incite the passions of New Yorkers like questions about the uses of land. How towering an office tower? Where to build a jail?
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Leonard Kudisch, an advertising research executive, died Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Brookline, Mass.

LEAD: Increasingly eager to improve its food supply, the Soviet Union is seeking to buy at least 200,000 tons of soybean oil from the United States at subsidized prices that could cost American taxpayers about $30 million, people in the Administration, Congressional offices and the agriculture industry confirmed
LEAD: Business inventories rose moderately in March and sales held steady, indicating a weaker economy, but economists said the trend was not worrisome yet.

LEAD: The television crews taping the New York City Ballet's performance of ''A Fool for You'' on Thursday night for ''Live From Lincoln Center'' arrived at the New York State Theater after George Balanchine's ''Episodes.'' They left before Balanchine's ''Cortege Hongrois,'' taking some of the audience with them.

LEAD: Eight states bordering the Great Lakes plan to open a permanent office in Canada to take advantage of what they consider an improved climate for cross-border cooperation in tourism, economic development and the environment.

LEAD: Researchers at A.T.&T.'s Bell Laboratories this week received the first in what is expected to be a series of patents for a new generation of semiconductor devices known as ''hot electron transistors.''

LEAD: In an embarrassing setback for Japan's political leaders, Masayoshi Ito today officially rejected the appeals of the governing Liberal Democratic Party to serve as Prime Minister, charging instead that party officials had blocked his proposals to end corruption.

LEAD: As Surrogate of New York County, Renee R. Roth all too often sees ''families rent asunder'' when wills are challenged in court. ''The best way to avoid a probate contest is to sit down with members of your family and discuss what you intend to do'' before a will is drawn up, she said this week in a speech entitled ''Preserving the Family Through Financial Planning.
LEAD: The Cuban Day parade starts at noon at 44th Street and the Avenue of Americas, moving north to Central Park South, then west to Columbus Circle.
LEAD: Nathan Messner, a former president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Beekman-Downtown Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

LEAD: Nat Adderley, a trumpeter, is leading a sextet that includes Sonny Fortune and Vincent Herring on saxophones, tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

LEAD: In the first demonstration by a Chinese minority group since a wave of student protests began last month, about 2,500 Muslim students marched to the city's central square today to protest the publication of a book they say blasphemes Islam.
LEAD: After three years of legal battles, a Federal appeals court ruled today that the Boston Police Department could conduct random drug testing of its officers.

LEAD: Moscow's plan to withdraw 500 nuclear weapons from Europe and President Bush's proposal for aerial surveillance flights throughout NATO and Soviet-bloc airspace marked an extraordinary week of public diplomacy intended to sway opinion in Western Europe.

LEAD: Panama's Roman Catholic Church today released a blistering attack on the regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, questioning his moral authority to govern and inviting the military to disobey repressive orders.
LEAD: The big man at the top of the gangplank wore lots of tattoos and a leer. ''Hiya, sister,'' he said. ''Welcome to the love boat.''
LEAD: The Pittsburgh Pirates lost the reliever Jim Gott for the season yesterday because of a damaged ligament in the pitcher's right elbow.

LEAD: In a move likely to draw opposition from environmentalists, a top Coast Guard officer has told the Exxon Corporation to consider using powerful chemicals to break down the oil spill because other methods have proved ineffective.

LEAD: In a week of increasing conflict in Panama, Americans grew much more supportive of the use of United States troops to restore order if necessary, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. But a clear majority said the treaties giving up the Panama Canal should not be breached.
LEAD: Joseph Boatner, a later member of the Ink Spots singing quartet, died on Monday at Lakes Region General Hospital in Laconia, N.H. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: Japonica Partners said yesterday that it would begin shortly a tender offer for CNW, the owner of the Chicago and Northwestern Transportation Company. The offer would have a total value of more than $800. Japonica, which holds an 8.8 percent stake in CNW, has been seeking a friendly acquisition of CNW but has been rebuffed by the board, a company spokesman said.
LEAD: The Patent and Trademark Office, which has been publishing record numbers of patents in recent months, is now swamped by its own paperwork.
LEAD: * Acmat Corp., East Hartford, Conn., purchased 3.45 million shares of United Coasts Corp. at $4 a share for a total of about $13.8 million.
LEAD: The Soviet Union's largest bank began issuing Visa cards to replace the passbook savings account, Visa International reported today.

LEAD: A speeding freight train hauling 69 carloads of potash derailed this morning in San Bernardino, demolishing a row of houses, killing a trainman and two children and shaking the area like an earthquake, officials and residents said. At least one person is missing.

LEAD: The nation's largest airline computer reservation system, the American Airlines Sabre system, shut down for almost 12 hours yesterday, disrupting the operations of about 14,000 travel agencies nationwide.

LEAD: President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said today that the United States had begun consulting foreign governments to see whether any would accept Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama if he could be persuaded to give up power.

LEAD: Economy
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Aided by a rallying bond market, bankers for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday completed the largest-ever underwriting of corporate debt, an estimated $4 billion of securities of the RJR Holdings Capital Corporation.

LEAD: London may have Andrew Lloyd Webber but - on a rather different scale of ambition and achievement - San Francisco has Paul Dresher. Both composers emerged from the shadow of better-known collaborators (Mr. Lloyd Webber from Tim Rice, Mr. Dresher from the San Francisco vanguard theater artist George Coates).
LEAD: The Treasury securities market posted its strongest one-day gain yesterday since last September, sparked by a much smaller than expected rise in the Producer Price Index for April.

LEAD: A news analysis article on Thursday about President Bush's effort to win foreign support for the ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama misstated Senator Bob Graham's attitude toward the Panama Canal treaties. Mr. Graham, Democrat of Florida, says it is premature to talk of canceling the treaties.
LEAD: Questions appear on page 11.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: This is the time to repair winter's wear and tear on locks, other door and window hardware and window sashes. Simple lubrication is almost always the remedy. Lightweight household oil is the standby. But newer products that contain silicone or Teflon do not stain as oil sometimes does, and won't harm paint or woodwork.
LEAD: The Milwaukee basketball team is called the Bucks in the dictionary sense of a male animal; especially, a deer or antelope.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Robert O. Geiger, a copywriter and editor at Lord & Taylor for 15 years, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: American Ballet Theater offered its first mixed bill of the season on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The enchantments of ''Swan Lake,'' to which the company devoted the opening performances of its engagement, gave way to three festive ballets, including works by two of our century's greatest choreographers, Leonide Massine and George

LEAD: Kenneth Farnham Duchac, director emeritus of the Brooklyn Public Library, died of liver cancer Tuesday at the Bon Secours Extended Care Facility Hospice in Ellicott City, Md. He was 66 years old and lived in Ellicott City and Sarasota, Fla.
LEAD: The WPP Group appears close to an agreement to buy the Ogilvy Group in a deal that would create the second-largest advertising and marketing company in the world.

LEAD: With little more than 48 hours remaining before a threatened strike, motormen who drive the PATH trains between New York and New Jersey voted last night in favor of a new contract that gives them a $10,000 total pay increase over a five-year period, retroactive to 1985.

LEAD: An article on Wednesday about the impact of drug addicts on hospitals in New York City misstated the period in which recorded cases of AIDS among intravenous drug abusers first outnumbered those among homosexual men. It was the first quarter of 1989, not 1988.

LEAD: Raymond Jackson, a pianist and a professor at Howard University, wrote his doctoral dissertation at Juilliard on piano music by black American composers. He lectures frequently on the topic around the country and he is currently editing an anthology of black contributions to keyboard literature.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: I am not surprised that half the world's scientists have dropped everything and rushed out to disprove, denounce and jeer at the fellows who claim they produced fusion in a jar.

LEAD: A judge declared today that the State Senate seat of Israel Ruiz Jr. is legally vacant, but several state officials said the lengthy skirmish over whether the Bronx Democrat is still a Senator is not over.

LEAD: Douglas F. Young, retired justice of the State Supreme Court, died of complications from Parkinson's disease Thursday at St. Francis Hospital, Flower Hill, L.I. He was 77 years old and lived in Sands Point, L.I.
LEAD: Sixteen weeks after President Bush took office, 80 percent of the senior positions in Government departments and agencies have not been filled.
LEAD: Baseball

LEAD: Following is a transcript of President Bush's remarks on Soviet-American relations today at Texas A & M University, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network. Because of a slip in Mr. Bush's delivery, one sentence, indicated by italics, is taken from his prepared text.

LEAD: A dispute has emerged between the New York City ambulance service and Lenox Hill Hospital over a delayed response to the 911 emergency call during the asthma attack that killed Schools Chancellor Richard R. Green early Wednesday.

LEAD: The Government agency that insures pensions for millions of retired workers cannot force the LTV Corporation to reinstate three steelworker pension plans that the company said it was unable to finance, a Federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled today.
LEAD: Cynthia M. Welles, the wife of Benjamin Welles, a former foreign correspondent for The New York Times, died on May 3 after a stroke at her home in Washington. She was 72 years old.
LEAD: Sending a surprisingly encouraging signal on inflation, prices at the producer level rose a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Labor Department reported today.
LEAD: The Greek Supreme Court today upheld an American request for the extradition of a Palestinian in connection with a 1982 bomb explosion aboard a Pan Am airliner.
LEAD: Former Vice President Dario Echandia Olaya, a senior statesman and Liberal Party leader who served four times as caretaker President, died on Sunday. He was 91 years old.

LEAD: A concert of traditional music and dance from the Andes is to take place at 8 o'clock tonight at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street (864-5400). The music will be performed by Tahuantinsuyo on pipes, flutes, drums and stringed instruments; the group will be joined by 18 dancers. Tickets are $15 and $12; information, 206-1050.

LEAD: President Bush is committed to beginning negotiations on a ''framework'' for a treaty on global warming but is not ready to endorse specific elements, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency said today.
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

LEAD: For years, Dorothy Miller lived in her sister-in-law's apartment. James Wood had a bed in a shelter for homeless men. Amelia Ryan shared a room in her granddaughter's house. None of them could afford anything else.
LEAD: Brandon Tartikoff, the president of the entertainment division of NBC, said yesterday that the network had renewed its entire Tuesday night lineup for the 1989-90 television season.
LEAD: A fierce lobbying campaign against a bill banning unsolicited facsimile advertising may have backfired when Gov. William A. O'Neill's fax machine was jammed for hours with unwanted messages.
LEAD: CAR POOLING is Carol Dee Angell's business, and she makes sure she practices what she preaches.

LEAD: Davis Phinney of Boulder, Colo., survived his premature celebration today and won a 51-mile stage of the Tour de Trump bicycle race by 4 inches. Eric Vanderaerden of Belgium finished second, and when the 10-day race ends Sunday on the Atlantic City Boardwalk, Vanderaerden will be favored to win the first prize of $50,000.

LEAD: Fan violence during and after an English soccer game yesterday resulted in 25 arrests and the hospitalization of 16 people for minor injuries, shattering a month of calm after the Sheffield stadium tragedy.

LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that they had agreed to use part of a disputed $100 million to expand New York City's Tactical Narcotics Team program to three additional areas.

LEAD: THE LIVING CITY By Roberta Brandes Gratz. 414 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut, Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester Sunday regional sections of The New York Times. Ratings at the end of each item - satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication.

LEAD: Unaccustomed as he is to public speaking these days, Ronald Reagan has found that money talks, or at least that his talks bring big money. Lavish plans are being made in Japan to welcome him for 10 days of speeches and ceremonies in October. Despite a shadow cast by a scandal involving illicit payments to Japanese politicians by corporations, a bidding war is said to have erupted to be Mr.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: One of Bill Irwin's constant companions in the immensely funny entertainment known as ''Largely New York'' is a cane, a perfectly ordinary walking cane with which he does certain wondrous things. Actually, he does even more wondrous things with one of those remote controls that make television sets so obedient, but we'll get to that.
LEAD: CONNECTIONS TO THE WORLD The Basic Concepts of Philosophy. By Arthur C. Danto. 281 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.95.

LEAD: FINDING a Mother's Day card for my mom has never been easy. When I was growing up, the women depicted on the front of the cards didn't resemble my mom. In their aprons and print cotton dresses, they were the typical Donna Reed type mom of the early 1960's.

LEAD: The democratization of the Soviet political process has taken a turn familiar to Western voters as a candidate for the national congress used a freewheeling television debate to issue sensational 11th-hour charges of a cover-up of corruption in which he dropped the name of a leading member of the Politburo.
LEAD: It has been said that the truth is the first casualty in a war. The same thing can be said of the protracted struggle over the Shoreham nuclear power plant and its grotesque denouement.
LEAD: An article last Sunday about the First National Collegiate Poetry Fellowship misidentified the winner. She is Saskia Hamilton.

LEAD: ELEANOR BETTS has been urging fellow parishioners at Christ Church Cathedral in Hartford to say a special prayer that she wrote each and every day. The prayer begins: ''O God, who gives us a great work to do, give us also joy in the doing. Create in us thankful hearts for the opportunity and responsibility of helping to maintain and restore your holy church.

LEAD: ''A few months ago, i was rehearsing a new ballet in Studio 3 and Twyla Tharp was in Studio 4 and Misha was in Studio 5,'' Clark Tippet, the 34-year-old dancer-turned-choreographer with American Ballet Theater, said recently, ''and I suddenly began thinking, 'What am I doing with this group?' When I choreographed my first few pieces, I had nothing to lose, but I realized the company was counting on me this time, and it spooked me.

LEAD: EVEN as Mikhail S. Gorbachev prepared for his visit to China, the Soviet leader managed to throw a little gasoline on the fiery arms control debate within the Western alliance about nuclear short-range missiles.

LEAD: In 1973, John P. Mack, then 19 years old, worked at a home furnishings store in a Virginia suburb of Washington. As he later confessed, Mr. Mack attacked a 20-year-old woman, Pamela Small, pounding her skull with a hammer and slashing her. He served 27 months in jail before being released to a clerk's job in the office of Representative Jim Wright of Texas.

LEAD: You devoted five pages of your magazine to displaying five white shirts, none of which costs less than $132 (Fashion: ''The White Shirt,'' April 23). I suppose there are some who might pay $560 for a white shirt. The shirt itself is very good-looking. And the price tag may serve to convince them they've bought something stylish and elegant.

LEAD: Several days a week, a familiar form goes through the motions of training at the Metropolitan Toronto Track and Field Centre, a large, modern brick building on the campus of York University. It was here, for so many days leading to the Seoul Olympics, that Ben Johnson honed the skills that took him through the 100-meter final in 9.79 seconds, the fastest time ever run over that distance.

LEAD: This has been a season of revivals of unusual works by George Balanchine. The Joffrey Ballet reconstructed ''Cotillon'' of 1932. Tulsa Ballet Theater offered the New York City premiere of the 1942 ''Mozart Violin Concerto.'' And the New York City Ballet has just given us ''Danses Concertantes,'' a ballet of 1944 - or, is it really from 1972?
LEAD: Earl (Red) Blaik, who coached the Army football team to national championships in 1944 and 1945, was eulogized Saturday in a memorial service at West Point.

LEAD: THE issue of recycling versus incineration, to manage New Jersey's solid-waste crisis, is the focus of great controversy. To date, these solutions have been viewed as black or white - either we recycle or incinerate, and passionate arguments have been presented for each position.

LEAD: I know i am probably alone in this, but there are a few things in the ''Ring'' that I still do not understand, even after a season in which the Metropolitan Opera has considered the subject in rare detail. I am not talking about peripheral questions, like why Siegfried is vulnerable only to a spear in the back.

LEAD: Happy Mother's Day, godmother, grandmother, stepmother, mother-in-law. Thinking of you, best friend's mother, other mother, mother-to-be and like-a-mother-to-me. Because you care, care-giver, baby sitter and nanny, the greeting-card makers have come up with Mother's Day messages just for you.

LEAD: LUCKY audiences attending the American Stage Company's happy new revue, ''Ed Linderman's Broadway Jukebox,'' are instantly informed that the songs they'll be hearing won't be from ''South Pacific,'' ''Oklahoma!'' or ''Fiddler on the Roof'' but, more likely, from the likes of ''Hot September.'' ''Hot September''?

LEAD: An article last Sunday about the interests of Vice President Dan Quayle's wife, Marilyn, misstated the ages of their children in some editions. Tucker is 14, Benjamin is 12 and Corinne is 9.

Koontz. (Berkley, $4.95.) A mysterious stranger saves a woman from a series of dangers and disasters.

At least that's what some have claimed at one time or another. But you probably didn't know that the English invented Champagne. Well, neither did anyone else, but over the years that's exactly what some articles in

LEAD: Tradition can be a tricky thing. In the broadest sense, just about all music is traditional, unless it uses unique instruments and brand-new structures. And in the narrowest sense, virtually no music is purely traditional since each new interpretation alters the tradition in some way - although that process is itself a traditional one, as oral traditions constantly sift promising innovations from indulgences and tangents.

LEAD: America's mothers are finding more than ever that the empty nest left by grown children is quickly refilled by frail parents or other aging relatives in need of care, according to a private study.

LEAD: I was standing near the start of the first stage over a week ago in Albany when Donald Trump came over to introduce me to Mario Cuomo. He said, ''Governor, I'd like to introduce you to one of the best cyclists in this country, Davis Phinney.''

LEAD: For many companies, the good news is that they have finally managed to improve the quality of their products. The bad news is that their competitors have done the same. As a result, the locus of competition is shifting from quality to something broader: satisfying the customer in every way before, during and after a sale.

LEAD: Last week the dollar rallied against the world's other major trading currencies, reaching a 30-month high against the West German mark, an 18-month high against the British pound and an eight-month high against the Japanese yen. Although the central banks of the major industrial powers - the G-7 - have intervened in the currency markets to push down the dollar, the effect has been negligible.

LEAD: CHATTERTON, by Peter Ackroyd. (Ballantine, $8.95.) Keats wrote a sonnet to Thomas Chatterton, the young and unappreciated poet who killed himself in 1770 at the age of 17. Peter Ackroyd has made him a character in a story that takes place over three centuries and the result is ''a wonderfully vivid book,'' Denis Donoghue said here last year.

LEAD: Rex E. Lee, who served as Solicitor General in the Reagan Administration, was named Friday as the 10th president of Brigham Young University, the nation's largest private university. Mr. Lee, 54 years old, is to assume the presidency July 1. He succeeds Jeffrey R. Holland, who was appointed on April 1 to a leadership position in the Mormon Church, which owns the university.

LEAD: Gail Ann Collins and Joseph Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Williams of Jamaica, Queens, plan to marry in August, the prospective bride's parents, the Rev. and Mrs. Stewart Collins of Evansville, Ind., have announced.
LEAD: An intermittent rain today wiped out the first day of what is expected to be record-setting qualifications for the May 28 Indianapolis 500.
LEAD: A SLUGGISH housing market has brought most types of construction to a halt, but one conspicious exception is that intended for the affluent elderly.

LEAD: Never mind the Louvre pyramid. Forget the monumental arch at La Defense, and the new opera house at Place de la Bastille, and have a look at a really monumental piece of new architecture in France: the sprawling headquarters of Bouygues (pronounced Bweeg), the multinational construction company, in this new town about 12 miles from Paris.
LEAD: One of the important subliminal issues of a political campaign that many describe as ''surreal'' was apparently cleared up this week as Argentines prepared to go to the polls Sunday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I knew John Silber during my four years as superintendent of the Boston public schools. When the Boston schools needed help, John Silber was always there. When students, particularly minority-group students, needed scholarships or other assistance, John Silber and Boston University were at the forefront helping to provide them.

LEAD: SHORT on cachet and well within liberty range of the world's biggest naval base, Virginia Beach is one of those resorts that's easy for the uninitiated to dismiss. Indeed, in nearly a decade of living a half day's drive away, I never heard anybody even mention the place in the same breath as ''vacation,'' much less actually go.

LEAD: AS the Bush Administration's proposed savings and loan bailout works its way through Congress, more and more attention is being paid to a peculiar challenge: how to carry out the plan without worsening the depression in Southwestern real estate prices that helped cause the crisis in the first place.

LEAD: The letters from two physicians, Wendy S. Aronson and Carl Austin Weiss (April 16), critical of Morton Hunt's Body and Mind article ''Patients' Rights'' (March 5), merely serve to reinforce the extraordinarily cogent points Mr. Hunt was trying to make. To wit, too many doctors nowadays have become haughty, arrogant, too busy to listen, and clutching at the pedestals they themselves have erected on patients' backs.

LEAD: The cold spring wind off Lake Michigan carries the sounds of the new season: the rasp of saws, the pang of hammers and the rumble of bulldozers cutting roads into the steep-sided sand dunes that rise hundreds of feet above the shore.

LEAD: Not since Mr. Ed, the talking horse, wore hats - not all the time, but he wore them - has horse haberdashery had more of an audience. Horse wear showed up in nearly a dozen fall collections, reflecting either fashion's collective unconscious or a sudden surge in the equestrian passion.

LEAD: Claude Chabrol's latest film, ''Une Affaire de Femmes,'' is emotionally brutal, morally disturbing and probably one of the masterpieces of this decade. Yet it slipped in and out of New York recently, its United States premiere limited to two screenings at the Museum of Modern Art in a series devoted to the film's producer, Marin Karmitz.
LEAD: A better way to administer the management of marine fishes will have to be developed if the depletion of various species is not to continue, according to the Sport Fishing Institute.

LEAD: Power, control, raw sensual appeal - concepts car makers have used for years to tout their products, have been commandeered by the shoe industry to promote advances in athletic footgear. LEAD: IN the 19th century, it could be said that there were two alternative predictions about mankind's future. Marx proclaimed the inevitability of world socialism while Toqueville asserted that democracy, which he saw with some trepidation as rule by the consent of the governed, would surely replace rule by the few.

LEAD: In the nearly five months since a terrorist bomb concealed in a cassette tape player tore apart a Pan American Airways 747 over Lockerbie, Scotland, security at Europe's airports and at Kennedy International Airport has grown steadily tighter.
LEAD: A little pink stomach with legs and a smile talks about ulcers.
LEAD: For NBC, the timing of tomorrow night's television movie ''Roe v. Wade'' could not be better - or worse.

LEAD: Suzanne Russell Lynde and William Francis Maguire 3d were married yesterday at the Ralph Waldo Emerson Inn in Rockport, Mass., by the Rev. Donald A. Wells, a United Church of Christ minister.
LEAD: No! Al Leiter for Jesse Barfield will go down as a Nolan Ryan for Jim Fregosi trade. George Steinbrenner and Syd Thrift should learn from the Mets that you build with young pitching.

LEAD: MORE than any other thoroughfare in New York City, Park Avenue has been a street of surprising change. From the first grade-level railroad in 1834, to the sinking of the tracks and construction of middle-class housing after 1875 to the electrification of the railroad and the building of luxurious mansions and then apartments after 1900, the broad boulevard has consistently provided fascinating real estate news for more than a century and a half.
LEAD: THE CROSSWINDS OF FREEDOM The American Experiment. Volume Three. By James MacGregor Burns. 864 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.
LEAD: Rick Pitino walked off the court this afternoon with a worried expression. He knew the Knicks were in trouble. And he had less than 24 hours to do something about it.

LEAD: By the time Col. Cyril Ratanayake was sent to this guerrilla free-fire zone to set up some semblance of public services, it was too late to talk about winning hearts and minds.

LEAD: Lehigh University, known in some quarters as much for its legendary beer parties as its academic rigor, is among the Pennsylvania institutions that have begun to feel the effect of year-old state legislation to end drinking by people younger than 21.

LEAD: Pittsburgh, long thought of as the smoky city of mills and factories on the banks of the Ohio, Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers, can no longer be regarded as ''hell with the lid off,'' as the journalist Lincoln Steffens once described it.

LEAD: IF you are staying at a minimum-service economy motel, miserly phone service should not be a surprise. At the Econo Lodge on International Drive in Orlando, Fla., for instance, guests cannot use the telephone in a room for any outside call, whether collect, credit-card or whatever, until a $10 deposit is received by the front desk.
LEAD: THE real Mother's Days, to my mind, consist of the most magical moments of being a mother. The prime occasion may well be when the baby kicks for the first time during pregnancy.
LEAD: I RECENTLY saw a young man in the detoxification unit at the hospital. He had overdosed on synthetic heroin and was brought in unconscious and near death from respiratory failure.
LEAD: Faced with rising postal costs, catalogue houses and other direct mailers are on the lookout for alternatives to Postal Service delivery.

LEAD: CLOSER. By Dennis Cooper. (Grove, $15.95.) The gay teen-age boys who populate this short, brutal novel are not entirely indistinguishable from one another, but their energetic couplings betray a fatal sameness that is only occasionally relieved by the homicidal fetishes of their older lovers. Some readers have found similarities between the novelist and art critic Dennis Cooper's work and that of Jean Genet or William Burroughs, but it must be said that he lacks the ordering instincts of the one and the wild comedy of the other.

LEAD: THE New York City Council is considering a bill that would mandate inspections for asbestos in all buildings throughout the city.

LEAD: ''WHAT are all those new plays about?'' an observer of New Jersey's theater season is often asked. A visit to the Renegade Theater Company's fourth annual One-Act Play Festival, which lasts through next Sunday, prompts a weighty four-part reply: the roots of violence, the essence of manhood, the destructibility of civilizations and the collapse of the family.

LEAD: Tania Lawson-Johnston Tassie and Samuel Adams McCleery were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., by the Rev. Jean R. Smith. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Peter Lawson-Johnston and Mr. and Mrs. William McCleery, all of Princeton.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: LONELY AND DEPRESSED, BROODING on the perfidy of a nation that once worshiped him, Peru's young President, Alan Garcia Perez, rarely emerges these days from his ornate, 19th-century palace in the heart of Lima. Twice last year, he tried to resign. Earlier this year, a military coup looked imminent.

LEAD: American sporty themes, like parkas and oversized sweaters, in color palettes ranging from pale creams and cool neutrals to hot hues and molten golds. And there were enough variation of figure-clinging pants and cat suits to outfit an army of ''To Catch a Thief'' burglars.

LEAD: South African Army units stopped their search for rebels in northern Namibia and returned to their bases today under an international agreement that requires insurgents of the South-West Africa People's Organization to withdraw at least 90 miles inside Angola.

LEAD: The marriage of Pamela Lee Crimmins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Bates Crimmins of Noroton, Conn., to Carl Lawrence Gable, a son of Mrs. Carl Everett Gable of Twelve Mile, Ind., and the late Mr. Gable, took place yesterday at St. Vincent de Paul Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Michael Crimmins, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Banker's Lady proved herself the new queen of American racing by running Winning Colors into defeat and then pulling clear to a 2 1/4-length victory over Rose's Cantina in the $174,300 Shuvee Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

LEAD: With millions of twists of the wrist, New Yorkers have saved about 5 billion gallons of water since a drought emergency was declared almost two months ago, helping set the stage for the possible lifting of some water-use restrictions tomorrow.

LEAD: A couple of baseball movies have come to town recently on the coattails of last year's hit ''Bull Durham'' in the timeless tradition of bad to so-so movies chasing good ones until you never want to see another of that particular kind as long as you live. LEAD: WHEN I heard the terrible news that Lucille Ball had died, a picture sprang immediately into my mind: Lucille kneeling at my feet in my dressing room at the Biltmore Theater in San Francisco, hemming my dress.

LEAD: The work ethic - producing goods and services through long hours of hard work - is no longer serving America well. The reason is that the work enviroment found in most American companies discourages people from working from the heart - from caring about the job they do and the people with whom they work.

LEAD: Manuel Melgarejo's voice still trembles when he remembers the excitement of winning $155,000 at a new casino on Spain's Costa Brava and then setting off on a wild gambling binge that kept him away from home for the next nine months.

LEAD: Jay Doblin, a leading industrial designer who also taught for three decades at the Illinois Institute of Technology and directed its Institute of Design for 14 years, died of cancer Thursday at Lutheran General Hospital in Chicago. He was 68 years old.

LEAD: Q. My house has an unfinished attic that I can walk into. I use the attic frequently, but in summer the temperature climbs so high it is difficult to stay long. The attic floor is insulated with a layer of vermiculite, covered with a thick layer of fiberglass without a paper backing. This seems adequate to prevent heat filtering into the rooms below.

LEAD: An article in the Long Island Weekly on April 23 misstated the amount of money the Montauk Historical Society spent last year on an erosion project at the Montauk Point Lighthouse. The organization spent $7,000.

LEAD: Gary Carter, hitting .114, is forcing the Mets to ponder a difficult decision.

LEAD: THE care and cultural feeding of our young artists is essential to the future of music in America, so it is encouraging to note that many Connecticut organizations are tending to these vital tasks.

LEAD: Political leaders receive awards frequently, but a double ceremony tentatively scheduled to take place in New York City on May 30 will be distinctly different. Two awards will be given to one of the leaders of the People's Republic of China for services to bridge.

LEAD: ON a bright April morning, a wrong turn landed me on Belleville Avenue in New Bedford, Mass. A huge yellow backhoe was mangling a stretch of sidewalk on a cross street. In the blocked roadway stood a construction worker, watching the machine and chewing at a bread and meat combination in his hand.

LEAD: IN a city where shelters for the homeless are full and more than 6,000 families are waiting to get into public housing, the Jersey City Housing Authority is proposing the demolition of 312 apartments, with alternative housing to be provided at a cost of $32 million.

LEAD: The conservative movement, which has never regarded George Bush as one of its own, is uneasy over his first four months in office. It is troubled by his apparent eagerness to compromise with a Democratic Congress and worried that he lacks Ronald Reagan's sense of how to use the power of the Presidency.
LEAD: The damp gray skies of an approaching South American winter have settled over this riverside capital. But on the chilly cobblestone streets below, young women have started wearing miniskirts.

LEAD: President Bush finally offered a glimpse of his thinking about Soviet-American relations, and it seems a sensible one. Speaking in Texas on Friday, he wisely called for moving beyond containing Soviet expansionism to ''the integration of the Soviet Union into the community of nations.''

LEAD: Gripe did originally mean grip, as Roy Blount says in his article, but that's not the point here. An old meaning of gripe is intestinal pain, and because people with a bellyache often go around bellyaching, the word eventually acquired the slang meaning ''complaint.'' LOUIS JAY HERMAN New York, N.Y.

LEAD: WITH an uneasy ceasefire in the battle over what will be built on the site of the New York Coliseum, neighborhood groups allied with environmental organizations are mounting sophisticated new campaigns to influence planning and real estate development across New York City.
