LEAD: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

LEAD: Across the Washington State University campus, dozens of fraternity men are sipping cold beers in the sun, but they may not be doing so for long. Student leaders, trying to change the university's party-school image, are imposing sanctions next fall that will prohibit beer drinking in fraternities that have low grade-point averages.
LEAD: Should the Mets have traded Nolan Ryan? DAVID SELINGER New York

LEAD: An investment group headed by Joseph Ritchie, a Chicago options trader, yesterday submitted a proposal to buy Eastern Airlines that would temporarily put Frank C. Carlucci, the former Defense Secretary, in charge of the troubled carrier.

LEAD: An article on March 5 incorrectly described the founding of the National Plastics Center and Museum in Leominster, Mass. The museum, which opens later this year, was founded by an unaffiliated group of individuals in the plastics industry.

LEAD: OF ALL THE TRIBES THAT INHABITED North America in the centuries before European visitors, few people had so much leisure time on their hands as the nations of the Northwest coast. Their main source of food, the tasty Pacific salmon, arrived at their doorstep every year without fail.
LEAD: AS the nation's most populous state, and one of its more affluent, California is a market so large and lucrative that industries will suffer almost anything to succeed here.

LEAD: The flag at City Hall here flew at half-staff today as Minneapolis bade farewell to Dr. Richard R. Green, a resident since his childhood, who rose from a housing project to the school superintendent's chair before he moved to New York City to head the nation's largest school system.

LEAD: AT the corner of Harbor Road and Harbor Hill Road is a lonely, two-acre saltwater marsh surrounded by low, dark hills. The head of a harbor narrows to a swampy point across the road, and a couple of 100-year-old farmhouses are not-too-distant neighbors.

LEAD: FROM THE STREET, IT APPEARS THAT A LARGE PEDI-ment caps this 11-story building. But the classical silhouette actually tops french doors leading from the architect David S. Rockwell's living room to his rooftop terrace.

LEAD: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York, Caroline Evelyn Slusser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Peter Slusser of New York and Windsor, Calif., was married yesterday to Floyd McElroy Converse, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chandler Bullock Converse of West Palm Beach, Fla. Msgr. Robert L. Charlebois performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Syd Thrift just made the biggest mistake of his baseball career. I am not denying the team's need for offense, but is a .200 hitter the miracle cure? Thrift shot a hole through the Yankees' togetherness. They lost youth, enthusiasm and unparalleled potential. KARA YORIO Kinnelon, N.J.
LEAD: A map on April 30 with an article about Salzburg mislabeled the country adjoining Austria, West Germany and Italy. It was Switzerland.

LEAD: EARLY next year a rubble-strewn, forgotten section of New Haven called Downtown South, just off Interstate 95 and a half mile south of the historic New Haven Green, will begin its transformation into a new $360 million neighborhood with 2.4 million square feet of commercial, retail, hotel and residential space surrounding a 3-acre park.
LEAD: DOUGLAS MACARTHUR The Far Eastern General. By Michael Schaller. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.50.

LEAD: Q. My house has an unfinished attic that I can walk into. I use the attic frequently, but in summer the temperature climbs so high it is difficult to stay long. The attic floor is insulated with a layer of vermiculite, covered with a thick layer of fiberglass without a paper backing. This seems adequate to prevent heat filtering into the rooms below.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: A WOMAN OF SINGULAR OCCUPATION By Penelope Gilliatt. 180 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $17.95.

LEAD: La Monte Young has a deserved reputation as a musical mystic, arrayed in Indian garb and presenting periodic concerts in hieratic settings of his grandiosely protracted compositions. But he is also of this world, a hard-working promoter of his own works and, perhaps even more laudably, of others'.

LEAD: Ralph Moore, a young tenor saxophonist who knows how to nudge a beat until it rolls sleekly, came to Fat Tuesday's on Wednesday night leading a quartet that included Kenny Barron on piano, Peter Washington on bass and Victor Lewis on drums. Mr. Moore is a regular sideman around New York and his appearance as a leader indicates that he is deservedly moving up in rank.

LEAD: WITH summer - and bathing suits - around the corner, it is time for sensible eating. Low-calorie meals do not have to be boring, however, or even skimpy. It is simply a question of laying off the saturated fats. The recipes below are substantial enough for company; they have little fat but get plenty of flavor from marinades and light sauces.
LEAD: AROUND the turn of the century, Adirondack guides and ''great camp'' caretakers whiled away winters fashioning chairs and tables out of logs and branches.

LEAD: SINCE 1964, when what is now the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center was built on 1,600 acres of prairie land donated to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration by Rice University, the aerospace industry has been an integral part of Houston's identity as well as its economy.

LEAD: RICHARD R. GREEN may have been unfamiliar with many peculiarities of New York City when he arrived to take over the public schools in March 1988, but he was certainly aware of one feature of the city: the reverence afforded the concept of decentralization. At first he was careful not to criticize the system, in which elementary and junior high schools are run by 32 locally elected boards.

LEAD: WHEN Watts and Elizabeth Wacker volunteered to become a Fresh Air Fund family, caring for an underprivledged boy for two weeks during the summer, they knew they were aiding a child in need. But they found that they were also helping themselves.

LEAD: A recent article, ''Determining Family Computer Needs'' by Paige Sheard Jaeger [ Westchester Opinion Page, April 16 ] , made several points about computers that may not accurately reflect the place of the computer in education today.

LEAD: Ever since he took over as president and general manager of the Kansas City Chiefs last December, Carl Peterson has been cleaning house. After starting out by replacing the coach, Frank Gansz, with Marty Schottenheimer, and making several other personnel changes, Peterson recently turned his attention to the grounds and stables.
LEAD: As a member of the ''very badly bred generation of students'' John Silber found at Boston University when he became president in 1971, I read Helen Epstein's article with great interest.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Lester Lipton of New York have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Sherri Alexandra Lipton and John Rovensky Grace, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Grace of Palm Beach, Fla., and Newport, R.I.

LEAD: Of all the perils of modern life, none casts the net of destruction further than drug and alcohol abuse. Phil Bosakowski examines one tragedy of such abuse in his short, taut play ''Crossin' the Line,'' which is being presented at the Lamb's Little Theater.

LEAD: I'm with you, Roy (''It Gripes Me to Say This,'' by Roy Blount Jr., April 16). I've been on a nonstop gripe-fest since your article appeared, and there's no telling when I'll stop. My husband has turned a deaf ear, the cats have skittered away, all from my unstoppable grousing. And it feels swell.

LEAD: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, addressed top business executives today on corporate debt and met privately with John S. Reed, chairman of Citicorp, probably to discuss Mexico's debt.

LEAD: OPERA is the thing this spring for children in the county. A symphony orchestra, a music school and even a nature preserve have focused their recent efforts on making this all-inclusive art form accessible to the younger set.

LEAD: The composer Ezra Laderman had a 65th-birthday party at Merkin Concert Hall last week, nearly two months early. Since his birthday -June 29 - falls too far outside the formal concert season for a performance on the actual date, three string quartets - the Audubon, Colorado and Blair - marked it on Tuesday evening with a concert of Mr.

LEAD: ''Legends in Concert,'' the glitzy Las Vegas revue that opened at the Academy Theater on Wednesday evening, presents nine performers doing mechanical impersonations of stars who have little in common beyond the fact that they are all dead.

LEAD: At the Marble Collegiate Church in New York, Elva Elizabeth Allen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mancill Allen of Houston, was married yesterday to John Frederick Allen, a son of Margaret Allen of Springfield, N.J., and the late Frederick J. Allen. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro, a Methodist minister, officiated.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: The Soviet Union has informed the United States that it is prepared to totally dismantle a long-disputed radar in Siberia if the United States agrees to a strict interpretation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, according to Bush Administration officials.

LEAD: A June wedding is planned for Hillary Lauren Jacobs and Jeffrey Stone Kaplan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward S. Kaplan of Memphis. Ms. Jacobs is a daughter of Gail Jacobs and Dr. Eugene L. Jacobs, both of New York.

LEAD: Spike Owen tied the score with a two-run homer in the seventh inning and then singled home the winning run with two out in the ninth as the Montreal Expos beat San Francisco, 5-4, today, ending the Giants' five-game winning streak.

LEAD: The panel rewriting the New York City Charter proposed yesterday that members of a new City Planning Commission be appointed to serve full time for a single five-year term and agreed that the body should have the central role in controlling the use of land.

LEAD: SINCE he was 6 years old, Ronald M. Mayfield Jr. of the Bronx, now 13, has visited the Morgan family in Mount Arlington as a Fresh Air Fund child every summer. Each visit is kicked off with a huge sign across the Morgans' red ranch-style house that reads, ''Welcome Ron.''

LEAD: The usual political suspects have been rounded up for the mayor's race here. To hear the candidates tell it, voters can choose among a fiscal watchdog, a high-tech visionary, a party and union insider and a former 1960's civil rights worker.

LEAD: Katonah, N.Y. $322,000 Allison Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 31-year-old farm ranch; country kitchen, fireplace, studio, screened porch, 1.5 acres; taxes $4,503. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $600,000 Trinity Pass 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial/Cape Cod; 2 fireplaces, country kitchen, family room, deck, hot tub, 3.9 acres; taxes $6,765.

LEAD: Beth Susan Trueman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Trueman of Yonkers, was married yesterday at Restaurant Provence in New York to Paul Frederick Cody, a son of Rosemarie Cody of Quincy, Mass., and the late Frederick M. Cody. Richard Lee Price, an acting State Supreme Court justice, officiated.

LEAD: An article by The Associated Press on April 23 about a proposal to administer drugs to a criminal defendant misstated benefits of the drug Cogentin in countering possible side effects of anti-psychotic drugs. Cogentin can alleviate drooling and involuntary muscle movements, but can cause mouth dryness and blurring of vision and can aggravate a condition called angle-closure glaucoma.
LEAD: A caption on page 15 last Sunday with an article about Satyajit Ray misidentified the actor shown with the film maker. He is Subhendu Chatterjee.
LEAD: In a major shift in policy, Mayor Edward I. Koch will announce today new initiatives for dealing with the AIDS crisis.

LEAD: OFF to an early start, Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky's bid for the County Executive post held by Andrew P. O'Rourke has filled Democrats with an optimism that seems to outweigh the considerable difficulties the Democatic challenger faces in ousting his experienced Republican rival.

LEAD: MY FATHER SAID, ''Don't let your mouth get in front of your mind, that's all.'' It was sage advice, if sometimes difficult for a stutterer to follow. Getting my mouth in front of my mind - words in front of the underlying thoughts - has been a problem for longer than I want to think about, like some threadbare sweater

LEAD: WHEN Ginny Bales was a college student visiting her hometown in Kingsport, Tenn., she went to church with the women in her family - her mother, two grandmothers, and assorted aunts and cousins - who were all joining voices in a hymn.

LEAD: Most experienced tournament players distrust radical early violent mating attacks - they've seen too many of them flop - so it is a terrible embarrassment when one of these coffeehouse adventures achieves a smashing success.

LEAD: To the Editor: In regard to the article by Jeannie Pulston Fleming on trekking in Nepal with children (Travel, March 26), we have trekked there several times, the last time in November north of Gurkha with our 18-month-old daughter. The only other Westerners we ran into was the group of children from the International Lincoln School.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced steps to prohibit the use of Alar on apples and other foods but said final action is not likely for at least 18 months. A recent private study said the chemical, used by some growers to prolong the shelf life of apples, can cause cancer and is particularly harmful to children.

LEAD: Why do those who would rape our nation's public lands for direct personal profit label as elitist advocates for the preservation of the wilderness? It seems the elitist label belongs more aptly to those who stand to profit at the expense of the rest of us. JOHN L. TURNER Huntington, L.I.

LEAD: WE have many mothers to remember today, not only the women who gave us birth, but also the countless others who nurtured us. I think first and lovingly of my own mother and then of the special women who added meaning to my life.

LEAD: Considering that he has sired two winners of the Kentucky Derby, Halo did not look proud. What he looked was mean.

LEAD: The Phoenix Suns felt right at home on the road again today, and as a result, they are going back to Arizona with a 3-1 lead in the Western Conference semifinals, and cold-shooting Golden State is a game away from heading home for the summer.
LEAD: Putting aside his usually cautious demeanor, President Bush today urged the people and military of Panama to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

LEAD: Fuzzy Zoeller continued his amazing performance in the cold and rainy 14th annual Memorial Tournament today when he chipped over a bunker and into the 18th hole for a birdie 3 to maintain his lead by a stroke over Bob Tway going into Sunday's final round.

LEAD: If Alfred MacLennan, in his letter ''The Speed of Sound: A Matter of Fact'' [ Letters to the Westchester Editor, March 26 ] , had simply presented his value for the speed of sound at sea level [ regarding Robert P. Levine's essay ''When the Ballpark Cost Just a Nickel'' ] in a straightforward manuever, that would have been fine.

LEAD: The Rev. James E. Pierce, a nationally known leader of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. who was the executive presbyter of Long Island, died of cancer Friday at his home in Commack. He was 49 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Ground will be broken May 23 for the third retail development in downtown Newark to be started this year, a 54,000-square-foot strip shopping center at West Market Street and 12th Avenue, adjacent to the University of Medicine and Dentistry's University Hospital. The $5.5 million center, with 33 stores and restaurants, is to be Newark's largest minority-owned and -developed retail project.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To the Editor: I would like to note an inaccuracy in ''What's Doing in Louisville'' (Travel, April 9). The J.B. Speed Art Museum, while enjoying a close relationship with the University of Louisville, is not ''the University of Louisville's ... Museum,'' but a private institution, Kentucky's oldest and largest art museum, which has served this area of the county independently as an art museum for more than 60 years.
LEAD: IF Roy Doty has his way, Billy Buck Hightrail could become the first superhero in the fight against cancer.

LEAD: The idea of charging customers for catalogues may seem ridiculous. But the concept could be just the ticket to offset retailers' higher postal expenses and winnow browsers from their mailing lists. People who pay for catalogues, after all, are more likely to place orders.
LEAD: Temple re-established its rule over its hometown Schuylkill River course today, winning the Tom Conville Cup for men's varsity eights in the 51st annual Dad Vail Regatta.

LEAD: Jacquelyn M. Helin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph A. Helin of Redwood City, Calif., was married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University to Robert Alan Glick, a son of Florence Weiskopf of Tamarac, Fla., and William Glick of Miami. LEAD: To the Editor: I thoroughly enjoyed the article about Sarasota and its keys, but there was one misconception that needs clarification, especially for readers who may be traveling to Siesta Key.
LEAD: The Cuban Day parade starts at noon at 44th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, moving north to Central Park South, then west to Columbus Circle.
LEAD: The Residential Resales column on April 23 omitted the listing broker in the sale of the town house at 55 Charles Street in Greenwich Village. It was Laurie Brant.

LEAD: ON three summer days in 1681, the Puritan settlers of Hingham, midway between Plymouth and Boston, raised the frame of their new meetinghouse. For inspiration, they drew on what they remembered of church architecture in England, then dominated by the Elizabethan Gothic style. But because they lacked the stone or bricks of the home country, they used the available local material, large virgin timbers.

LEAD: The fans were too busy at Chicago Stadium yesterday afternoon cheering for Mile-High Jordan, whooping for Long-Range Hodges and hooting the erstwhile Bull, Plucky Oakley, to bother much with booing the jazzy Mark Jackson.

LEAD: Animal prints. Bright colors. Bikinis. Pareus. Sheer fabrics. Beach dresses. Polka dots. Molded bras. Neoprene. Want to be in fashion at the seaside this summer? Wear suntan lotion, a big straw hat and at least one of the above.

LEAD: Q. My house has an unfinished attic that I can walk into. I use the attic frequently, but in summer the temperature climbs so high it is difficult to stay long. The attic floor is insulated with a layer of vermiculite, covered with a thick layer of fiberglass without a paper backing. This seems adequate to prevent heat filtering into the rooms below.
LEAD: More than two weeks after political organizing for national elections was to have begun, the Government and its opponents remain locked in a dispute over the rules that will govern the vote.
LEAD: Catalogue Retailers face a test of wits.

LEAD: Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, steadfastly opposed to reinstating the death penalty, proposes to punish first-degree murder with a sentence of life in prison and no chance of parole. Those who oppose that idea point to a convict named Willie Bosket, who seems bent on causing as much trouble in prison as he did on the outside.

LEAD: In California's agricultural belt, a meat-packing plant that had been closed for years reopened recently with new financial backing - Japanese. In the same city, Fresno, a Japanese textile company, is building what will be the first cotton mill west of the Mississippi River.
LEAD: A BIT of England will grace the grounds of the historic Glebe House in Woodbury when an English garden designed by Gertrude Jekyll is finished, more than a half-century after it was planned.
LEAD: Loudspeakers with variable patterns of sound radiation are rare. Any newcomer to their ranks is bound to arouse interest - especially if the design is musically competent and notably cheap.
LEAD: Since he became commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association five months ago, Bill Blue has been working feverishly to upgrade the image and increase the exposure of women's golf.

LEAD: THE PLANS ARE THUS: ON JULY 4, 1992, surrounded by an international armada of Tall Ships, a replica of Christopher Columbus's tiny fleet - comprising the Nina, the Pinta and the Santa Maria - will arrive in New York Harbor, commencing the party of the half-millennium. In celebration of the quincentennial of Columbus's first trans-Atlantic voyage from Iberia to the New World, the ships will stop in the Bahamas at San Salvador, now Watlings Island, the probable site of Columbus's first landing.

LEAD: Your article on the work of Nassau-Suffolk Law Services [ ''Legal-Aid Project Strives to Help Poor,'' April 2 ] managed to capture the enthusiasm and dedication of Victor Ambrose, who manages a burgeoning case load in the face of escalating costs and proportionately decreasing staff.

LEAD: Leslie Stuart Dickey was married yesterday at the home of her mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Fitz Randolph Jr., in Ridgefield, Conn., to Sanjay Hiralal Patel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Hiru N. Patel of Bombay, India. Judge Romeo G. Petroni of the Court of Probate for the District of Ridgefield officiated.

LEAD: In his response to Morton Hunt's article, Dr. Weiss insults a large portion of the public whose intelligent command of medical jargon is as natural to them as his own is to him. No one, especially the patient, is better served by the use of ''everyday names'' to describe symptoms. How can ''my belly hurts'' possibly supply nuances that a detailed description of the location, intensity and duration of pain would not?

LEAD: GEORGE AULT (1891-1948) was a Precisionist to the degree that he reduced architectural forms to a geometry inspired by Cubism. But where Charles Sheeler and other Precisionists purged their scenery of all human associations, Ault charged his with emotion.

LEAD: A June wedding is planned for Barbara Gail Lewis, a daughter of Leon Lewis of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Elaine Lewis, and Seth Adam Kaplan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kaplan of Teaneck, N.J. Ms. Lewis is a first vice president of the New York public-relations concern of Ruder-Finn. Mr. Kaplan is a partner in the New York law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz.

LEAD: ''LAND of the unruly'' - Yaghistan - was what the first modern ruler of Afghanistan, Amir Abdur Rahman Khan, called his country at the turn of the century. By another translation it means ''land of rebels.''
LEAD: THE ENIGMA OF JAPANESE POWER People and Politics in a Stateless Nation. By Karel van Wolferen. 496 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

LEAD: By any standard, it was a huge camp-out: 700 undergraduates on the main quad at the University of Chicago last weekend braving 30-degree weather not to raise money for charity, buy concert tickets or demonstrate for or against some cause, but to enroll in next year's classes.
LEAD: Many Italian dishes lose nothing by being frozen. Here is a basic recipe for lasagna, with or without meat, that makes a Sunday meal and has enough left over for dinner days later.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. DeCarlo of Rosemont, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michele Joan DeCarlo, to Thomas Lowry Blum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Blum of New York. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: It was called the Summer White House. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill are said to have planned the first atomic bomb here. Eleanor Roosevelt ran a cottage industry that produced furniture, pewter and cloth. A generation of Roosevelt children grew up here.

LEAD: I HAVE come into the kitchen for the third time today and I can not remember why. I am not over 60 years old, not suffering from Alzheimer's, but somehow a few of the cells in the overstuffed computer of my brain do not have room to remember why I came into the kitchen.

LEAD: If we don't produce the minerals and energy we require from domestic sources, our only alternative is to get them from abroad, primarily from underdeveloped countries where few safeguards are applied to resource development. The wilderness advocate is having an ''esthetic experience'' in our forests, but he might ponder the morality of having this burden borne by people who live on a subsistence level.

LEAD: HEADACHES ARE A-mong the five most frequent complaints brought to a family doctor - but no two people describe them in quite the same way. Nor are two doctors likely to interpret those complaints in the same way. So it's not hard to see why misdiagnoses are common and why they lead to failed treatments.

LEAD: Seventeen rustic shacks on Cape Cod's outer dunes, whose fate has been the subject of a dispute between Massachusetts officials and the Boston regional office of the National Park Service, have been given national historic status by the Federal agency's headquarters here.

LEAD: In many ways, Amantine Lucile Aurore Dupin was a precursor of today's supermom: she supported her two children by writing about 80 novels (under the pseudonym of George Sand) and she was a staunch advocate of freedom in living for women. Her atypical dress and manner - not to mention tempestuous romantic proclivities - became the 19th-century symbol of the modern woman.

LEAD: A headline last Sunday about the engagement of John H. Grady Jr. misidentified the bride-to-be. She is Ellen Canan. Patricia G. Canan is her mother.

LEAD: Here in Silicon Valley, smallness has traditionally been equated with power, so it was not by accident that the Poqet Computer Corporation chose its name. These days, Poqet's future sits, appropriately enough, in the breast pocket of a jacket worn by the company's founder, Stav Prodromou.

LEAD: When the helicopters land, the men with the bundles of possessions and the women in the head-to-toe shrouds rush forward, elbowing and shoving in a desperate effort to board before the machines soar back into the air.

LEAD: LAST week, as ethnic Tamil guerrillas met with leaders of Sri Lanka for the first time, the hope in everyone's mind was that a political formula could be found for ending six years of civil war. The formula under discussion was the classic device used by democratic nations to make room for regional differences: federalism.

LEAD: THE CHIP WAR: The Battle for the World of Tomorrow. By Fred Warshofsky. (Scribners, $22.50.) Fred Warshofsky has taken his tape recorder and toured the American semiconductor industry, recording the anguish of its leaders as they watch their markets relentlessly eroded by Japanese competition. He has also traveled to Japan and visited factories, universities and Government officials to paint a picture of a near-invincible rival.

LEAD: Time was when most companies felt that research and development was something they had to do for themselves and technology developed by others was adopted only as a last resort. However, as international competitive pressures have grown and research has become more expensive, that ''not-invented-here'' syndrome has faded.

LEAD: CHISELS with handmade wooden handles, a wreath of human hair, a porcelain sink and a cedar canoe are among the items displayed in the gallery of the Guilford Handcrafts Center. The items were all handcrafted by Guilford residents and are part of ''Tri-and-a-Half Crafts,'' a show that celebrates the town's 350th anniversary.

LEAD: There's no arguing about the usefulness of filters. With slide films they are virtually a necessity, since you can't fiddle much with the image after it has been shot. But even those of us who use color-negative films, which can readily be color-corrected in the printing stage, find good reasons to put filters in front of our lenses.

LEAD: Southern Methodist University, whose winning football program was derailed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association on accusations of illegal payments to team members, will begin the 1989 season with a team educated to say no to illegal offers.

LEAD: ECHO OF LIONS. By Barbara Chase-Riboud. (Morrow, $19.95.) In this, her third novel, Barbara Chase-Riboud takes on one of the most fascinating episodes in the history of the slave trade, the successful rebellion of a group of Africans on board the Spanish slave ship Amistad. Led by the man who would be known in America as Joseph Cinque, the intended slaves killed the captain and crew of the ship and, with no maritime knowledge, attempted to sail back to West Africa.

LEAD: Michele Ann Coyne and John V. Regan, graduates of St. Bonaventure University, were married yesterday at St. Augustine Roman Catholic Church in Ossining, N.Y. The Rev. Robert McCormick officiated.

LEAD: Members of the New York Philharmonic will play a program of chamber music at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, today at 3 P.M. The program includes Gordon Jacob's Suite for Eight Violas, Prokofiev's Quintet (Op. 39), Dohnanyi's Serenade (Op. 10) and shorter works by Handel and Shostakovich.

LEAD: Itinerant Therapy What if psychotherapy were to come out of the closet and walk around in the world with the patient, like two peripatetic philosophers? This is how Max, the hero of Sara Vogan's novel ''Loss of Flight'' (Bantam), sees his patients.

LEAD: The black stains left by the Exxon Valdez have left a mark not only on Prince William Sound but also on Alaska's political landscape, blotting out much of the influence that the oil industry has enjoyed in state government for the last decade.
LEAD: In response to the attack on a jogger in Central Park, Mayor Edward I. Koch has proposed an eight-point program to toughen state laws governing the way juveniles are tried and punished.

LEAD: The Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed today to readmit Egypt, whose membership was suspended because of its peace with Israel a decade ago. The move was a further step in Cairo's return to the Arab fold after 10 years of ostracism.

LEAD: A British man was reported missing in Lebanon today, hours after a group asserted it had taken a hostage to win the freedom of comrades jailed in the slaying of a Palestinian cartoonist in London.

LEAD: If Mrs. Hunt was describing her symptoms accurately, what difference does it make whose jargon she was using? If she understood the terms and used them comfortably in speaking to someone who also understood them, the only impediment to the transfer of information would be the arrogance of a physician who is threatened by an informed, intelligent patient.

LEAD: Dave Magadan, the denizen of the dugout, sat on the Mets' bench in Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon. He heard the sellout crowd of 46,484 yelling. He saw the San Diego Padres walk Darryl Strawberry on purpose to load the bases with two down in the 11th inning and the score tied at 3-3. And he sensed that Davey Johnson was calling his name.
LEAD: ''WHEN we see the summer's first fireflies, we know it's time for Dario to come,'' said Monica Willard, looking forward to the arrival of the family's Fresh Air Fund friend from Brooklyn.

LEAD: THE near desperate demand by the wealthy for works of art is reminding some Wall Street investors of the speculative frenzy that has characterized stock market booms. ''It does have a late 60's feel to it,'' said Dave H. Williams, an art collector and chairman of Alliance Capital Management. ''There is a certain hubris and confidence on the part of collectors and dealers that it only goes one way - up.

LEAD: Q. My house has an unfinished attic that I can walk into. I use the attic frequently, but in summer the temperature climbs so high it is difficult to stay long. The attic floor is insulated with a layer of vermiculite, covered with a thick layer of fiberglass without a paper backing. This seems adequate to prevent heat filtering into the rooms below.

LEAD: Al Leiter has proven he talks a good game and nothing more. The Yankees needed Jesse Barfield's run-producing bat to protect the franchise, Don Mattingly. The gloom-and-doom prophets in the news media, who are openly rooting for Barfield to fail, can no more guarantee that Leiter is the next Sandy Koufax or guarantee that Barfield won't annually hit 30 plus homers and 100 plus r.b.i.
LEAD: Susan Willet Bird was having a business dinner with a man recently. The waiter came over with the check and, although she hadn't asked for it, he placed it in front of her.

LEAD: A new shuffling of the space shuttle schedule will cause a delay of three to five months in the launching of the Hubble Space Telescope, space officials and scientists said last week.

LEAD: WHAT with West Germany suddenly stamping its foot at NATO and resisting the battlefield nuclear weapons that other allies consider critical, the old fear has surfaced again: is it not the Germans' real goal to be one nation-state again, an economic and cultural powerhouse straddling East and West in the heart of Europe?
LEAD: FIRE ON THE RIM A Firefighter's Season at the Grand Canyon. By Stephen J. Pyne. 323 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $19.95.

LEAD: A WOLVERINE IS EATING MY LEG. By Tim Cahill. (Vintage, Paper, $8.95.) In this collection of adventure stories, Tim Cahill, a columnist for Outside magazine, says offhandedly that ''every once in a while, I like to flirt with some physical challenge in which the price of failure is death.'' He recounts, in much the same manner, such challenges as squeezing through barely passable openings a half-mile beneath the earth, diving off the Philippines for poisonous sea snakes and hiking Death Valley in the summer.

LEAD: It's been nearly 75 years since the British passenger liner Lusitania was torpedoed by a German submarine. The ship's sinking slowly sucked the United States into World War I and inspired one of the most controversial medals ever made. That medal and others by the German sculptor Karl Goetz will be sold at auction today at the Omni Park Central Hotel at Seventh Avenue and 56th Street at 1 P.M.

But researchers and environmentalists remain cautious about how to address the long-term underlying causes of coastal pollution.

LEAD: Stiffer competition and the higher cost of landing new customers has made catalogue retailers more appreciative of their old customers -and more eager to keep them. ''Cataloguers are now working very hard to establish a relationship,'' said Jo-Von Tucker, president of the JVT Direct Marketing Corporation, a direct-mail marketing firm.

LEAD: Musical sculpture - slit gongs, horns, harps and drums in the shape of oxen, buffalo, horses, long-beaked birds or armless men - are silhouetted against the walls of the great hall at the Smithsonian's National Museum of African Art. These figural instruments include several that are monumental in scale and many more that convey movement or the music they were devised to bring alive.

Last fall, Seagate Technology, the largest independent hard-disk company, announced that it had a glut of inventory, cut prices and took a loss, setting off an industry-wide binge of price cutting, losses and layoffs.

LEAD: MAY is the equivalent of the Christmas buying season for those who sell ornamental plants, shrubs and trees. But on a recent afternoon, thousands upon thousands of plants, trees and flats of seedlings covering six acres at Tony's Nurseries in Larchmont were still waiting for the hundreds of buyers who never came.

LEAD: Inflation worries eased considerably in response to some new statistics. Wholesale prices for April showed an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent, much less than expected. Gasoline prices, up 7.2 percent, had their steepest monthly rise in nearly two and a half years, but were offset by declines in food and auto prices.

LEAD: The New Jersey Weekly recently reported that Fairleigh Dickinson University plans a one-year phaseout of its College of Dental Medicine. Since no follow-up story has been written, here is accurate current information on the status of our dental students.

''Didn't you tell any of them you'd already seen it?'' ''Not one.'' ''Why not?'' ''Because it was literary, sensitive and romantic.

LEAD: FOR projects like house painting and installing new siding, scaffolding obtained from a rental center is easy and safe to use, and more efficient than ladders. Units are constructed from pairs of end frames linked by braces and covered by planks or platforms on which to stand. Joining units vertically creates a tower; joining them side by side creates a run.

They perform similar jobs, associate with similar friends, frequent the same night spots, survive on the same shoestring budgets and a good many of them are at least toying with the idea of devoting their lives to public service.

LEAD: WITH considerable fanfare, Fannie Mae (the Federal National Mortgage Association) announced last month that it was expanding its co-op loan program. As a result, borrowers were supposed to obtain mortgage loans for co-op apartments more easily and cheaply. The move was also designed to help lenders make fixed-rate loans on co-ops, which had been difficult to obtain in the past.

LEAD: AS gasoline retailers converted to self-service, drivers had to get used to the idea that they might not be able to count on their local service station to make repairs, change tires or even clean their windshields. Soon they may not even be able to drive in and ask the attendant for directions.

LEAD: To Stephen Doyle, a 32-year-old co-conspirator behind the design of the magazines Spy, In Fashion and The New Republic, graphic design is a bit like driver's education. ''You communicate through layout,'' he said. ''Type tells the reader when to speed up and when to put the brakes on.''

LEAD: At the Union League Club in New York, Aimee Susan Brown, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Beau Brown of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Gary John Anderson, a son of Irene Anderson of Hermitage, Pa., and the late S. Tedford Anderson. Judge Michael L. Pesce of Civil Court in Brooklyn officiated.

LEAD: Nearly a decade after imposing strict quotas for the hiring of minorities and women by the New York State police, a Federal judge has lifted his court order and commended the department for its recruitment efforts.

LEAD: For the first nine months of his two years in detention, Zwelakhe Sisulu was in solitary confinement. All he was given to read was the Bible - in Afrikaans, a language he cannot read.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Paul Richard Foote of Seneca Falls, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Sarah Foote and Bruce Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cohen of Manalapan, N.J.

LEAD: To the Editor: Seeking advice from a specialist in tropical and travel medicine should be foremost when a family is planning to bring youth along on a trek to a developing country. The incidence of typhoid, shigella, amebiasis, tuberculosis, diphtheria, meningococcal infections, dengue fever, hepatitis, rabies, hookworm and other intestinal parasites is high in Nepal and many other countries where trekking occurs.

LEAD: THE GODCHILD. By Stephen Alter. (Andre Deutsch/David & Charles, $19.95.) Tricia, abandoned by her teen-age mother at a mission hospital in India, has been raised by adoptive parents in suburban Connecticut. Now, at the age of 20, she has returned to her native land, hoping to find Mamta, the mysterious tribal woman who she believes is her mother.

LEAD: THE runoff from spring rains has been carrying an unhealthy element in many areas - particles of salt used to de-ice the highways in the winter - and one of the latest apparent casualties of the pollution is a nursery here.
LEAD: The short and not very happy reign of Edward VIII as King of England produced a set of stamps that are strikingly severe in design, almost plain. But the story behind the design is interesting.
LEAD: JoAnn Coleman and Neil Novikoff were married last evening at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York by Judge Richard Owen of Federal District Court in Manhattan.
LEAD: FOR DR. SHERVERT FRAZIER, there was nothing special about that April day last year.

He denounced the work of an artist as deconstructionist drivel; she railed against the ''esthetic hegemony'' of a gallery owner.

LEAD: THE sales office for 780 West End Avenue at 98th Street opened last month and the conversion of the building's 63 apartments into condominiums is under way. ''We bought it because it was so distinctive'' says Glen Siegel, a spokesman for Walter & Samuels, selling agents for the owner.

LEAD: The unscientific playoff format of the National Hockey League, often a vehicle used by Cinderella squads to cling to contention until the championship round, was not fooled by pretenders this spring.

LEAD: What better day than Mother's Day to think about the thousands of babies born this year that won't be going home to festooned bassinets and fancy strollers? Instead they will be tethered to tubes in intensive care units, and some eventually turned over to foster care.

LEAD: As a Boston University student (1971-75) and a writer in the publicity office there (1980-83), I have seen John Silber up close.

Salem is the fastest-growing town in Connecticut, in the heartland of the beautiful Connecticut River Valley on the edge of the pristine Devil's Hopyard.

LEAD: Men in traditional Afghan costume greeted 400 guests at the Ambassadors' Ball for Afghanistan Tuesday night at the Plaza. More than $75,000 was raised for the Afghanistan Relief Committee, which provides humanitarian aid.

LEAD: June wedding plans for Wendelin Knowlton Borman and Philip Quaranta have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Earle K. Borman Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Quaranta is the son of Mrs. Leslie Egenhauser of Rye Brook, N.Y.

LEAD: ''Move for Parental Choice in School Gains'' (April 16) seems to favor Gov. Thomas H. Kean's simplistic approach to improve the quality of education in New Jersey. Permit the parent of a child to have a choice of the school the child will attend, and educationally the child will succeed.
LEAD: Long after disconsolate American fans had filed out of Murdock Stadium on the El Camino College campus today, the drums and cowbells were still beating out their rhythms in the stands.
LEAD: The owner of three Manhattan art galleries was found shot to death in what the police believe was an attempted robbery near one of his galleries in Greenwich Village.

LEAD: What a difference a couple of decades can make. In 1969, the University of Wisconsin's Miflin Street Block Party became the focal point for a three-day student protest that left 80 people injured, 20 of them police officers. These days it is just a happy one-day festival.

LEAD: While the boys were disporting themselves on the streets of the city, in the days when it was still safe to play on the streets, hitting, slapping or punching among the sewers, the girls were engaged in kinder, gentler (though not wimpier) games. We played potsy, developing our sense of balance. We jumped rope, sharpening our timing.

LEAD: For Mothers of Multiples MANY Long Island mothers of twins are resting today, but not because it's Mother's Day. They are recovering from last weekend, when 332 mothers of twins descended on the Long Island Marriott for the annual New York State Mothers of Twins Clubs convention.

LEAD: It started in a big way in 1970, when ''TAKI 183'' was scrawled on walls around the city. Other youths began spray-painting ''tags'' - their nicknames and street numbers - everywhere, especially on subway cars, and by the early 1980's more than 95 percent of the cars bore layers of multicolored hieroglyphics and sometimes also the murals called ''pieces.

LEAD: Hawaii is a popular destination and therefore a popular subject for guidebooks. Following are four of the most recent. 22 Days in Hawaii By Arnold Schuchter. 129 pages. John Muir Publications. $6.95.

LEAD: Hatred, jealousy and despair come to life, almost as characters in their own right, in the Repertorio Espanol's Spanish-language production of ''La Casa de Bernarda Alba.'' But this new staging of the Federico Garcia Lorca play, under the direction of Rene Buch, moves so fast at times as to become a headlong rush to tragedy.

LEAD: Penny Haft, a daughter of Mrs. Bob Murphy and a stepdaughter of Mr. Murphy of New York and Jensen Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Bill Thomason, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Thomason of Bessemer, Ala., at Stephen's Episcopal Church in Birmingham, Ala., by the Rev. Douglas Carpenter.
LEAD: Looking toward the 90's; mergers and acquisitions and the office market; a Disney creation in Houston. Is it time to rebuild Park Avenue?

LEAD: LIKE a family trading in a scratchy 1950's hi-fi for a compact-disc player with all the extras, office tenants in New York City today are going modern. Many space users, including some of the nation's largest legal and financial firms, are abandoning their old offices in favor of new buildings that can accommodate their computer systems and provide more efficient, comfortable conditions.

LEAD: ON A STARK, SNAKEWEED-IN-fested plain in northwestern New Mexico sits an enormous mound of hardened lava that was squeezed out of the earth in the Pleistocene Epoch. It's called Mitten Rock, and some Navajo Indians believe it to be inhabited by witches. Tony Hillerman steers his four-wheel Isuzu Trooper up for a close look at the monolith.

LEAD: WE were on an unsteady course toward the lounge. A friend and I had stopped for a drink at the Grove Park Inn in Asheville, N.C., and as we walked down a long, wide corridor, I was drawn left and then right, again and again. I wove this way toward a big hulk of an oak sideboard or that way toward a severe-looking couch with wooden slats at its sides and back.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Regarding ''Effectiveness of Drug Law Questioned'' (April 9): The new ''drug-free zone'' law for 1,000 feet around schools may not be perfectly written, nor is it a cure-all, but in my experience it seems to work - and not only by arrests and sentencing, but by discouraging drug dealing near a school.

LEAD: Every so often, there surfaces in the international art world a truly terrible idea. An idea of precisely that order was approved unanimously not long ago by the trustees of the Victoria & Albert Museum in London. The essence of it was that henceforth the curatorial staff of the museum were to concern themselves entirely with scholarly pursuits, leaving the day-to-day work of the museum - the ''housekeeping,'' as it is now called - to a chain of command newly set up for the purpose and attuned to modern managerial methods.

LEAD: Two-Homer Innings Q. How many Yankee batters have hit two home runs in one inning and who was the last one to do it? A. Since 1900, the feat has been achieved 18 times in the major leagues, and of the eight American Leaguers to accomplish it, three were Yankees. But no Yankee has managed to do it since 1977, when Cliff Johnson became the third one in the history of the franchise to trot round the bases twice in the same inning.

LEAD: Peter Scott, a champion of gay rights who canceled a campaign for the California Assembly after learning that he had AIDS, died of complications from the disease at his home Saturday. He was 50 years old. A lawyer who gave up his practice to advocate gay rights, Mr. Scott worked to defeat measures requiring the dismissal of homosexual teachers and requiring that people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome be registered with the state.

LEAD: George A. Cornish, a former managing editor and executive editor of The New York Herald Tribune, died of a heart ailment yesterday at Saint Anthony's Hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla., where he lived. He was 87 years old.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY Employers are aggressively bargaining with doctors and hospitals on health-care costs, and steering workers to the ones with the best price. Although the costs to these employers are lower, patients may lose some freedom of choice, and other companies and individuals may end up paying more.

LEAD: The takeover battle for the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership grew more complicated on Friday, with the Omnicom Group apparently expressing its willingness to pay up to 360 pence a share, or about $5.99, for a substantial minority stake in the British agency, said advertising executives close to Omnicom's plans.

LEAD: Jim Wright's Democratic colleagues now readily concede that he is in desperate trouble and that his fate may be settled in a month or so, when the ethics committee rules on the Speaker's efforts to dismiss major charges against him.

LEAD: After applying its free-market doctrines to virtually every other facet of national life, the Conservative Government of Margaret Thatcher has finally worked its way to the most hallowed of British institutions: the pub.

LEAD: The Rothschild banking dynasty, which has its start here in the 18th century, plans to reopen an office in this city after an 88-year absence, the city treasurer said today. The Frankfurt office was closed in 1901 as the city's role as a financial center temporarily waned. The city treasurer, Ernst Gerhardt, said Rothschild planned to open an office with about 20 people this summer.

LEAD: In one of the more subdued moments of ''Eleemosynary,'' the new Lee Blessing play, Eileen Heckart effortlessly takes hold of her audience simply by resting in a bentwood chair. LEAD: If Jim Wright's constituents remain more loyal than distressed that their man has been accused of serious ethical wrongdoing, they will be following in a well-established tradition in American politics. Voters know - and appreciate - a politician who has the power to deliver jobs. And politicians know that taking care of constituents is a far more effective route to political power than satisfying platitudes about morality.

LEAD: The right guide to the news from China isn't Marx or Mao, but Ripley's ''Believe It or Not.'' Just as Moscow and Beijing ceremonially ended 30 years of estrangement, 300,000 protesters occupied Beijing's huge central square to demonstrate for democracy and a free press. And their hero? Mikhail Gorbachev, who was all but smuggled by his hosts into the Great Hall of the People so he wouldn't see - or be seen by - the youthful masses saluting him as ''the democratic envoy.

LEAD: Berenice Bramson is an experienced soprano who now spends much of her time teaching. Judging from Sunday afternoon's program at Weill Recital Hall, one assumes her pupils are fortunate. Miss Bramson retains a firm technique (though it is a little frail at the top of her voice), she has an excellent sense of how a melodic line should be sung and her taste in material is first rate.

LEAD: In the wake of yesterday's downpour, the very word ''drought'' sounds almost silly. May showers have raised the reservoirs to more than 90 percent of capacity and washed away New York's fears of another drought, the third in the last decade to require emergency water conservation rules. The state drought management task force now recommends lifting the emergency.

LEAD: Poi Dog Pondering radiates lighthearted benevolence like no other 1980's band I've heard. The group is from Austin, Tex., and performed Monday night at the Knitting Factory. Poi Dog Pondering has its spiritual home in the San Francisco of the late 1960's, when psychedelic bands cheerfully crossed category lines to come up with hippie skiffle tunes that might dip into country, folk, pop, jazz and world music, sometimes all at once.

LEAD: Though S. J. Perelman was pigeonholed as a humorist, he was, first of all, a literary artist - an acrobat with language - and his wit and erudition are imperishable. Feeling low? Enervated by ennui? Read Perelman and rejoice.

LEAD: Opera Ebony, now 16 years old, has been branching out in ambitious directions. Last year, the company undertook a co-production of ''Porgy and Bess'' with the Finnish National Opera, taking it on tour in Finland and the Soviet Union. On Saturday night, in an unofficial cultural exchange, the company brought Eri Klas, the Estonian conductor who led ''Porgy,'' to make his American debut with the Verdi Requiem in Aaron Davis Hall at City College.
LEAD: Irving Edison, former president of Edison Brothers Stores and a longtime member of the National Jewish Welfare Board, died Tuesday at his home in St. Louis. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: The Knicks' Eastern Conference playoff semifinal series against the Chicago Bulls has been dominated by Michael Jordan, who has scored 174 points against them, and by Patrick Ewing, who had been a disappointment for them until he dominated Tuesday night's game and prevented New York from being eliminated.

LEAD: The ''Flamenco Fusion'' show at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Saturday night opened with one of those rare, clearly beautiful moments that seem to stop time. LEAD: Last year's treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces required the Soviet Union to dismantle the 239 SS-23 missiles it had in Europe. Soviet officials had argued that the SS-23's range was just below the 300-mile threshold set in the treaty, but to meet American concerns they agreed to include it.

LEAD: The Xerox Corporation has decided to stop making copiers for the A. B. Dick Company because the Chicago-based company's sales were cutting into Xerox's markets, a Xerox spokesman said today. Xerox has been making low- to mid-volume copiers for Dick, an office products company, since 1986 under a three-year agreement that is scheduled to expire next month, a Xerox spokesman, Arthur Zuckerman, said.

LEAD: For years, travelers to Florence have believed it was the Italian water that made them go funny all over -faint, hallucinate, perspire heavily, suffer palpitations and stomach cramps. Today, because of the researches of a psychiatrist named Graziella Magherini, the world knows better. It wasn't the acqua; it was the art.
LEAD: With exports posting a surprisingly strong rise, the nation's trade deficit narrowed sharply in March, the Government reported today.
LEAD: A coup attempt in Ethiopia appears to have failed, but military units outside the capital continue to hold out, Western diplomats there said today.

LEAD: IN less than a decade, the peck of typewriter keys and the ring of the carriage have been replaced by the glow of the computer terminal and the buzz of the printer. Today the manual typewriter, with its steel body and sensual, rounded keys, is a relic of another era. Indeed, even the electric typewriter seems an anachronism.

LEAD: A Federal judge on Tuesday struck down as unconstitutional provisions of a child pornography law that placed stringent record-keeping requirements on producers and distributors of sexually explicit materials.

LEAD: A report in the Advertising column in some editions of Business Day yesterday about a stock split by the Interpublic Group of Companies described the action incorrectly. Interpublic announced a 3-for-2 split, by way of a 50 percent dividend, and did not announce a special 50 percent dividend.

LEAD: Japanese officials today appeared to be inching toward an increase in the country's record-low discount rate, amid growing nervousness about the rise of the dollar and signs that inflation could be returning after an absence of many years.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev left China today after a four-day summit meeting that ended 30 years of estrangement between the Soviet Union and China, taking with him promises of expanded party and government contacts and a general reduction of military tensions in Asia.
LEAD: California's Legislature today became the first in the nation to pass a broad ban on semiautomatic assault weapons.

LEAD: Not many hours after they lost Keith Hernandez for the next two months, the Mets got the act together with a clatter last night and overpowered the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-3, with one of their best pitching, hitting and wall-scaling performances of the season.

LEAD: James M. Campbell, a lawyer for the New York City Commission on Human Rights, died of complications from AIDS Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 37 years old. Mr. Campbell joined the commission in 1986 in the law-enforcement bureau and helped to redraft the Human Rights Law and rules of practice.

LEAD: Long before there was a musical called ''Cats,'' Eartha Kitt was projecting a sensuously feline image in cabarets and such musicals as ''New Faces of 1952.'' LEAD: J.R. Reid of North Carolina and Nick Anderson of Illinois led the list of 14 early entry candidates for the National Basketball Association draft June 27. The list, which was released by the league yesterday, included Vlade Divac, a center for the Yugoslav national team that won the silver medal at the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, and Andrew Gaze, the Australian who started for Seton Hall's N.C.A.A.

LEAD: A year ago, before friends could have predicted that a political scandal would lead him to suicide, Ihei Aoki wrote a telling message in his high-school alumni newsletter about the ugly side of Japanese politics.
LEAD: John H. Sununu was fuming.

LEAD: BRASEBALL Villanova Big East Champion: Gene Schall, the designated hitter, cleared the bases with a double in the eighth innning last night, sparking Villanova to a 10-7 victory over Providence and the Big East tournament title. Villanova earned its first trip to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament since 1961.

LEAD: The capital of the United States holds one of the smallest urban communities of Soviet emigres in the nation, a loosely knit group of professionals, scholars and writers whose common bond, if there is one, is to escape being typecast as emigres.

LEAD: Diamandis Communications Inc. withdrew yesterday from negotiations to acquire McCall's magazine because of unresolved issues involving subscription liabilities and differences over its value, publishing industry analysts and executives said.
LEAD: Seventeen Bronx teen-agers were arrested yesterday after a fight with two men working at the Van Cortlandt Golf Course in Van Cortlandt Park, the police said.

LEAD: Lonrho P.L.C. today lost the final round of a court battle that all but ends the long struggle of its chairman, Roland W. (Tiny) Rowland, to wrest control of Harrods, the famed London department store, from the Fayed brothers of Egypt.
LEAD: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's debut opera season is ending this weekend with the most impressive of the three highly impressive productions it has presented.

LEAD: Harold Mager, a United States Treasury official in World War II and a State Department planner in the postwar period, died of kidney disease Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: House Speaker Jim Wright struggled for his political footing today, predicting victory in the legal challenge to the ethics charges he faces, while allies battled a deepening gloom in the House.
LEAD: Responding to the Exxon Valdez spill, the Interior Department has announced a year's postponement in the Government's sale of an oil lease in the Gulf of Alaska.

LEAD: ''Austin City Limits'' has quietly outlived other pop-concert television shows by keeping things simple. The program books performers on grounds other than raw popularity, seeking out the deserving individualists who tend to land in the middle and lower reaches of the pop charts. And the show, which is produced by Terry Lickona and directed by Gary

LEAD: The Exxon Corporation has agreed to put an environmentalist on its board of directors, thanks in part to pressure from New York City's Comptroller, Harrison Goldin, and a small band of like-minded big stockholders.

LEAD: It has reached the point, one Panamanian said this week, where she can no longer keep food down; she feasts on antacids instead. Another, chronically healthy, has suddenly developed an allergy that makes her sneeze and sniffle uncontrollably. A third has begun having obsessive dreams.
LEAD: Figgie International Inc., a com-pany led by its strong founder, Harry E. Figgie Jr., said yesterday that it had named Vincent A. Chiarucci president. The post has been vacant since 1982.

LEAD: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., May 18 - It is a new era for the American advertising industry and the American Association of Advertising Agencies must respond to it, said Glen W. Fortinberry, the new chairman of the advertising trade group.

LEAD: Nearly two months after the biggest oil spill in American history, Alaskan officials say that not a single mile of beach has been completely cleaned and that the death toll of birds, fish and mammals continues to mount.
LEAD: Dale Linx Orrin, a dancer, teacher and choreographer, died on May 5 at St. Joseph's Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 36 years old.
LEAD: Five months after fleeing the New York City area to avoid a prison sentence for the largest Medicaid fraud to date, Sheldon Weinberg was arrested yesterday in Scottsdale, Ariz.

LEAD: The board of the Southmark Corporation, the Dallas-based real estate and financial services company, postponed a special shareholders meeting scheduled for Friday in Atlanta at which the company's proxy holders were to vote on directors. Three incumbents are opposed by nominees from a group of dissident shareholders.

LEAD: In a shift in policy, the immigration service will permit foreigners with AIDS to enter the United States on temporary visas to attend conferences or for medical treatment, a Justice Department official said today.

LEAD: George (Specs) Toporcer, the first major league baseball player other than a pitcher to wear eyeglasses on the playing field, died Wednesday after a fall in his home in Huntington Station, L.I. He was 90 years old.

LEAD: What's striking about the China-Soviet thaw is the equanimity that greets it in Washington. Not so very long ago, in frostier days, any reunion between the two giants of the Communist world would have been viewed with dread. Some people even believed the China-Soviet split was a sham, just as a vocal minority now argues that this week's apparent reconciliation between Moscow and Beijing threatens freedom.

LEAD: Senator Nancy L. Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, announced today that she would seek a third term, dampening the hopes of Democrats for their first Senate seat from Kansas in 50 years. Mrs. Kassebaum, who had pledged in earlier campaigns not to serve more than 12 years, said she decided to run so the state would not lose the benefits of her seniority.

LEAD: The graduating class of an evangelical Christian law school is facing limited job prospects because of the American Bar Association's reluctance to give its seal of approval to the school's legal education. Now the students have taken the A.B.A. to court, arguing that its power to accredit law schools has been used to stifle competition, not to control quality.

LEAD: The New York Chamber Symphony's concert at the 92d Street Y got off to a late start on Sunday afternoon because one of the soloists in the opening work - Stephen Albert's ''Treestone'' - was caught in Mother's Day traffic at curtain time. Since the composer was in the audience, he was drafted to fill the time with a lecture about his piece.

LEAD: WHEN it comes to public festivities, New York is like a perpetual-motion machine - a place with a never-ending procession of street fairs, parades and other outdoor entertainment. But this weekend, the machine threatens to become seriously overheated.
LEAD: Despite the fact that their once famous Sack Exchange was gone, the Jets were second in the American Conference in sacking quarterbacks last season.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY Gasoline prices posted their largest one-month increase on record in April, pushing the consumer inflation index up 0.7 percent. Without the volatile energy component, the April increase was 0.2 percent, leaving the financial markets cheering. [ Page A1. ] Prices in the New York metropolitan area rose 0.5 percent.

LEAD: The N.F.L. said yesterday that it would take no action against Lawrence Taylor in the wake of his acquittal on drunken-driving charges. Taylor, the Giants' celebrated outside linebacker, was found not guilty May 10 in Saddle Brook (N.J.) Municipal Court. Taylor has been cited twice by the league for violating its substance-abuse policies.

LEAD: One of Karl Otto Pohl's standard comments on foreign exchange trading is that even the most powerful central banks can do little in the face of an overwhelming market trend.

LEAD: A Cook County grand jury has refused to indict a man who disconnected his brain-damaged, comatose son from a life support system last month and held hospital workers at gunpoint until the boy died, the authorities said today.

LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday ordered the first of a series of repairs to the nation's aging airliners that will eventually involve 2,200 airplanes and cost the airline industry hundreds of millions of dollars.
LEAD: When Cora T. Walker told her mother that she planned to become a lawyer, the mother minced no words. ''You're going to be another poor, hungry Negro lawyer,'' she said.

LEAD: The TV Notes column yesterday understated the size of the audience for the ABC mini-series ''The Winds of War'' in February 1983. The program was watched by 53 percent of the viewing audience, not 43 percent.

LEAD: SHARES of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, also known as the savings institution that ''junk'' built, rose sharply yesterday as its president complained it was undervalued and said he was thinking of taking it private.

LEAD: Sunningdale Holdings Ltd., a group linked with the British investors Jacob Rothschild and Sir James Goldsmith, said today that it had agreed to buy the 29.9 percent stake in Ranks Hovis McDougall P.L.C. that is owned by Goodman Fielder Wattie Ltd.

LEAD: THE traffic just below North Bridge coursed turgidly through the broad, overflowing West Street, and Weekend Walker felt that the occasion of this outing called for a comment as grandiloquent as the skyline that overshadowed him and his companion, City Stroller.

LEAD: President Francois Mitterrand spoke out today against the elimination of short-range nuclear weapons in central Europe but insisted that NATO did not have to decide about replacing its own battlefield missiles until 1992.

LEAD: The stock of Avon Products Inc. plunged $7.125 yesterday, to $33, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange, after the Amway Corporation said on Wednesday that it was withdrawing its $2 billion offer.

LEAD: In his lifetime, Qin Benli has been buffeted by a Nationalist purge, the Communist revolution, the anti-rightist campaign, the Cultural Revolution, the campaign against spiritual pollution and the campaign against bourgeois liberalism.

LEAD: A century or so ago, when idealistic Zionists in Europe talked of returning to Palestine, it must have seemed as though they were nurturing an utterly impossible dream. One never knows, however, how things will turn out, which is one of the reasons hope springs eternal. A Swedish-made documentary, filmed in part in the shadow of Mount Ararat, the geographical and spiritual center of the Armenian homeland destroyed by the Turks during World War I, seems aimed at keeping the flame of hope alive.

LEAD: An article on Wednesday about the economics of fighting acid rain misidentified one environmental organization and gave an incorrect location of another. The group that represents a traditional approach to regulating air pollution is the Natural Resources Defense Council, not Defense Fund.

LEAD: One of the things that this critic least wants to do, ever again and even for quite a large sum in ready money, is to read another novel or sit through another movie about the contemporary art world.

LEAD: ''A Night in Havana: Dizzy Gillespie in Cuba'' documents the great jazz trumpeter's triumphal visit to Cuba, where he was invited in 1985 to headline the Fifth International Jazz Festival of Havana. For Mr. Gillespie, who is now 71 years old, the journey was a kind of spiritual homecoming. In the late 1940's, he had been one of the first American jazz musicians to incorporate Afro-Cuban polyrhythms into a big-band setting.

LEAD: Ryo Noda, a young Japanese composer and instrumentalist, has written several works in which he has tried to find common ground between his country's traditional music and its Western-influenced contemporary school. It is not an easy task: each language has its own sense of tonality and timbre, reflected in its instrumentation, and its own kind of rhythmic and harmonic movement.

LEAD: In hockey's playoffs, when goaltending is either a team's trump card or its Achilles heel, the two goaltenders who have survived to duel in the Stanley Cup championship are engaged in a self-deprecating cold war.

LEAD: The public has been chilled by reports of cyanide in Chilean grapes and alarmed by Alar residues in apples. Now come Washington's latest gyrations on cyclamate, the artificial sweetener banned in 1970. Consumers may well wonder what's safe, what isn't and whether regulators know what they're doing.

LEAD: When the Chicago Bulls' practice ended today, Bill Cartwright headed straight for the whirlpool. He settled his 7-foot-1-inch body into the soothing water, and let out a satisfied sigh of relief.

LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company said it was putting its energy assets into a new subsidiary that is intended to expand the company's share in the $10 billion independent power market. The unit, called Destec Energy Inc., will be based in Houston and will be headed by Charles F. Goff Jr., Dow's current director of mergers and acquisitions.
LEAD: Long-term Treasury securities rose moderately yesterday as investors shrugged off a larger-than-expected seven-tenths of 1 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index for April.
LEAD: The University of Pennsylvania Law School yesterday became the first major law school in the United States to require its students to provide voluntary legal services.
LEAD: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., said it had received a contract to supply an air-traffic collision avoidance system, valued at $100 million, to USAir Group Inc., Winston-Salem, N.C.
LEAD: A Manhattan racketeering trial that involves the murder of a police officer has turned into an unusually harsh clash between defense lawyers and a Federal judge.

LEAD: ''There are two things that top the list of Washington dislikes: the obligatory stand-up cocktail party and the 8 A.M. breakfast,'' John G. Tower noted with a smile this morning as he played host at what was billed as a ''power breakfast'' at Joe & Mo's restaurant on Connecticut Avenue (starting at a presumably more civilized 8:30 A.M.).

LEAD: Despite sharp divisions in the Bush Cabinet on the usefulness of trade sanctions, Japan is likely to be cited for failing to open its market in supercomputers, officials said today. They spoke after the first Cabinet meeting devoted to singling out unfair practices under last year's trade law.

LEAD: Small-scale but widespread, the cuts announced yesterday by Mayor Edward I. Koch as part of his proposed budget would be felt keenly around New York City, as library branches close some days, new playgrounds go unbuilt, museums curtail operations and parks get dirtier.

LEAD: Dave Butz of the Redskins, who had been the oldest starting player in the National Football League, yesterday announced his retirement in Washington. The decision of the 38-year-old defensive tackle to retire had been rumored for several months even though he had another year remaining on his two-year contract that would bring him $550,000 next season.

LEAD: Turning around a senescent institution like the Edwardian Room in the Plaza Hotel is like trying to throw a loaded supertanker into reverse: the momentum of longstanding mediocrity is powerful. Memories of the last time I dined there, about two years ago (before Donald Trump bought the hotel), include a halibut fillet that had been roasted to within seconds of incineration and a wizened baked potato that should have been served with a carbon-dating kit.
LEAD: The Federal Express Corporation yesterday priced a $150 million issue of 10-year notes through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company, a unit of General Electric Financial Services Inc.

LEAD: For more than a decade, David Hammons has been erecting sculptures and carrying out performances on the streets of Harlem, where he lives, and elsewhere in Manhattan. He works a good deal with found objects, like discarded liquor bottles, and with ephemera, like hair from the floor of a barber shop.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In ''Road House,'' Patrick Swayze has the most laughable role since Tom Cruise juggled a few liquor bottles and danced to ''The Hippy Hippy Shakes'' in ''Cocktail.'' ''Road House'' is also set in a bar, where Mr. Swayze is a bouncer named Dalton. He's so famous he needs only one name like Cher or Sting, so tough that when knifed he calmly stitches his own arm, so cool that he stays perfectly serene while knives, fists, feet and chairs come flying toward his face.

LEAD: Nearly as rare as the colt that grows up to be a racing champion is the birth of twin foals. Yet a tiny and brave filly and her weaker twin brother grow stronger every day here in an intensive care unit for newborn horses.
LEAD: The space agency moved today to quickly fill vacancies in the management of the space station program, naming a former astronaut to head the program.

LEAD: Lydia Pasternak Slater, a poet who translated some of the works of her brother, Boris Pasternak, the Russian Nobel laureate in literature, died in Oxford, England, on May 4 after a long illness. She was 87 years old.

LEAD: A stocky dark-haired man died in a Dallas prison in 1967, leaving only a suit, a watch, a ring and a .38-caliber pistol. Twenty-two years later, his lawyer and heirs are still arguing over the estate.

LEAD: THE changing business climate, with the economy slowing, the inflation rate flattening and interest rates edging down, has called forth a burst of speculative buying of stocks, bonds and dollars. But the superstrong dollar is worrying business executives with goods to sell abroad and Government officials who fear that a rising dollar will, sooner or later, worsen the United
LEAD: MTV Networks announced plans yesterday to form a cable television comedy channel, the second all-comedy channel announced this week.

LEAD: The two-and-a-half-hour film ''Testimony,'' the ''Great Performances'' presentation on Channel 13 tonight at 9, could be subtitled ''Montage Mania.'' This film biography of the Russian composer Dmitri Shostakovich (1906-1975) was produced, directed, designed and, with David Rudkin, co-written for Britain's Channel 4 by Tony Palmer.
LEAD: The Manhattan Democratic Executive Committee last night overwhelmingly endorsed the mayoral candidacy of Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan.

LEAD: When Sonny Rollins, 59 years old, and Branford Marsalis, 28, two tenor saxophonists, step onstage tonight at Carnegie Hall, listeners might well sense a challenge. Jazz history is full of tales, authenticated and apocryphal, about the nights in which reputations were made, new styles were forged and pretenders were deflated in the jazz equivalent of one-on-one basketball or a duel of honor - the jam session or ''cutting contest.

LEAD: West Germany's Defense Minister began discussions today with top American officials to try to forge a compromise in their dispute over short-range nuclear missiles as some German officials voiced optimism that differences could be resolved.
LEAD: Parents plan to sue the Yonkers school district over a strip search that was conducted in a junior high school class after one student claimed someone had stolen $28, a lawyer said today.

LEAD: Israel lifted the curfew over about one-third of the Gaza Strip today, though Gaza remained a closed military zone, meaning that about 60,000 workers were still prohibited from leaving for their jobs inside Israel.

LEAD: Bill Shoemaker, the retiring jockey who has ridden 8,799 winners and won more than $120 million in stakes money, announced today that he would begin his worldwide farewell tour June 4 in Zurich, Switzerland.

LEAD: The World Health Organization today predicted that the number of AIDS cases worldwide would increase to five million by the year 2000, from 450,000 today.

LEAD: Danny Sullivan, the winner of the 1985 Indianapolis 500 who crashed in a practice run for this year's race last Thursday, returned to a race car yesterday at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. Wearing a special protective brace for the right forearm he broke when his Penske PC18-Chevrolet crashed into the wall on the third turn, Sullivan hopped into a similar race car a few minutes after the beginning of a practice session at the Speedway.

LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today named a former astronaut, Dr. William B. Lenoir, to head the space station program. Dr. Lenoir, who flew a shuttle mission in 1982, is now a vice president of Booz-Allen & Hamilton, a consulting company. The space agency also announced that Richard Kohrs, the deputy manager of the space shuttle program at Johnson Space Center in Houston, will move to NASA's headquarters in Washington to be operational director for the space station, which is to be called Freedom.

LEAD: Democratic leaders in the General Assembly, saying Connecticut's finances have worsened since Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed the largest tax increase in state history three months ago, today offered a package of 25 new or increased taxes to balance next year's budget.

LEAD: William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, told Congress today that Pakistan was ''engaged in developing a nuclear capability'' while its rival India had begun research that could be used to make thermonuclear weapons.
LEAD: * Bangor Hydro-Electric Co., Bangor, Me., a utility, named Robert S. Briggs president and chief operating officer.
LEAD: Martin L. Beck, an architect who taught at the Princeton School of Architecture from 1929 to 1942, died Tuesday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 88 years old.
