LEAD: Michael Dyne, a playwright who also wrote many dramas and comedies for television, died Wednesday at his home in Linlithgo, N.Y. He was 70 years old and had colon and liver cancer.
LEAD: Gasoline prices posted their largest one-month increase on record in April, pushing the consumer inflation index up seven-tenths of 1 percent, the Government said today.
LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today approved a license for low-power testing at the Seabrook nuclear plant in New Hampshire.

LEAD: The Board of Education's deliberations on who should lead the New York City school system are focused on reservations voiced by the board's two minority-group members about a plan to offer an interim contract as schools chancellor to the acting chancellor.

LEAD: Toni Matt, a pioneer in competitive and recreational skiing in the United States, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Wednesday in Pawling, N.Y. He was 69 years old. Mr. Matt, who was born in St. Anton, Austria, came to the United States in 1938 with a group of Austrian skiers. On April 16, 1939, he skied down Tuckerman's Ravine on Mount Washington in New Hampshire in 6 minutes 29.4 seconds, reaching a speed of 85 miles an hour.

LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that after examining more than 200 insolvent savings associations at the request of President Bush, it had found evidence of criminal fraud and abuse at almost half the institutions.
LEAD: A bitter court battle over millions in legal fees involved in settling the $500 million estate of J. Seward Johnson has been resolved in Surrogate's Court in Manhattan.
LEAD: A wave of dollar-selling by central banks helped slow the dollar's rally yesterday, pushing it lower against most major currencies.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. Azzurro
LEAD: The opening sequences of Steve DeJarnatt's ''Miracle Mile'' are so playfully disarming that the movie feels more like a kooky modern love story than a film about nuclear war.

LEAD: Program trading fell in April, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday. It said program trading accounted for only 7.6 percent of the volume on the Big Board, the lowest level since the exchange began releasing figures last July.
LEAD: As if the Kentucky basketball program doesn't have enough problems with the N.C.A.A., now Madison Square Garden officials are mad at it, too.

LEAD: Steel imports in March fell to their lowest level in six years and their share of the domestic market shrank to 17.2 percent, well within the maximum under the United States import quotas, the American Iron and Steel Institute said Wednesday. Exports rose in March to 606,000 tons, the largest monthly total since July 1974, the institute said.
LEAD: A picture caption on May 8 about the Japanese politician Takako Doi misidentified the head of the Democratic Socialist Party. He is Eiichi Nagasue, not Eiichi Matsunaga.

LEAD: A report on New York State's energy needs warned today that additional generating capacity must be built within three years but cautioned that reliance on traditional energy sources will cause ''alarming'' increases in acid rain and other airborne pollution.

LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch characterized the $26.6 billion budget that he released yesterday as one of ''choices and consequences.'' Nowhere were those difficult decisions more evident than in his proposals for New York City's uniformed services.

LEAD: Minorco S.A., the world's biggest gold mining company, said yesterday that it had filed an appeal in the United States Court of Appeals in New York against an antitrust ruling in an effort to clear the way for a new takeover bid for Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. of Britain, the world's No. 2 gold producer.

LEAD: Garrison Keillor, the popular raconteur whose ''Prairie Home Companion'' stories about the mythical Lake Wobegon amused National Public Radio audiences for 13 years, announced today that he would return to radio this fall. Twelve shows of ''American Radio Company of the Air'' are to be broadcast live from New York, St.

LEAD: Edward S. Finkelstein, the chairman and chief executive of R. H. Macy & Company, denied yesterday that the retailer had arranged to sell an interest to another concern or that any of Macy's store divisions were for sale.
LEAD: Despite a large effort to elect new members to New York City's local school boards, the great majority of incumbents who ran were re-elected.

LEAD: After months of relative quiet in the Federal investigation of trading activities at the nation's two largest commodity exchanges, in Chicago, about two dozen subpoenas have been served in the last few days, people involved in the case said today.

LEAD: The Exxon Shipping Company monitored the alcohol habit of Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood for four years before his tanker went aground in Prince William Sound on March 24, the company president testified today, but it found no evidence of a continuing drinking problem.

LEAD: ''All anyone in New York is talking about,'' someone said yesterday, regarding the sports world, ''are two things: the Knicks against the Bulls, and Montreal against Calgary in the Stanley Cup finals.''

LEAD: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that it had opened an investigation of ties between President Bush's nominee as Ambassador to Luxembourg and a Federal housing program that Democratic lawmakers say was used by the Reagan Administration to benefit some prominent Republicans.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To combine features of urban and rural living, a real estate developer in northeastern Westchester County is offering home buyers the maintenance services characteristic of exclusive suburban condominium developments.

LEAD: The Bush Administration today renewed its strong opposition to Senate-passed restrictions on the $6 billion FSX fighter jet deal, with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d saying they would put the entire warplane agreement with Japan at risk.

LEAD: ''Personal Fouls,'' the book that once promised to expose widespread corruption in Jim Valvano's North Carolina State basketball program, has been scheduled for publication in September. But the book will be published without the sensational claims made by the original publisher before it withdrew from the project in February.

LEAD: Pete Rose can bring witnesses to his hearing with the baseball commissioner next Thursday, Francis T. Vincent Jr., the deputy baseball commissioner, said yesterday. ''It's certainly up to their side if they want to bring witnesses,'' Vincent said. ''It's certainly allowed. It's going to be a fair hearing.

LEAD: The Exxon Corporation's chairman faced the company's owners for the first time today since the oil spill in Alaska eight weeks ago and showed a combination of confidence and exasperation amid hostile questions and calls for his resignation.

LEAD: New York-as-melting pot is to be celebrated in two large ethnic-heritage parades this weekend -one in Manhattan and the other in Brooklyn. Marchers will begin assembling for the seventh Turkish-American Parade at 1 P.M. tomorrow on the Avenue of the Americas at West 56th Street; at 2:30 P.M. 15,000 people are expected to begin following the parade route, which will go south on the Avenue of the Americas to 47th Street and east to the United Nations.

LEAD: Shows, Nature, Museums SPRING STREET FAIR, with games, craft booths where children can make collages, and jewelry, toys, books, sports equipment, entertainment and ethnic food, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. tomorrow, sponsored by the Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School, at 94th Street, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue.

LEAD: The Jazz Tap Ensemble wished itself a happy birthday on Tuesday night when it opened a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) as part of its 10th-anniversary season. LEAD: IT looks like a cross between a Buck Rogers spaceport, a post-modern palazzo and a latter-day Crystal Palace, yet it is one of New York's newest, largest and most innovative performing-arts centers.

LEAD: Following are key sections from the Soviet-Chinese communique issued yesterday at the end of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to China, as provided in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass: Exchange of Opinions

LEAD: Though it is set in Montana, where the glorious scenery is full of horses and mountains and cowboy hats, ''Cold Feet'' is the kind of film where Tom Waits, as a deeply stupid hit man, walks into a western clothing store and asks for some ''cowpoke stuff.'' The film does not send up the West, so much as it looks at westerns from a skewed point of view.

LEAD: President Mengistu Haile Mariam of Ethiopia, who rushed home from East Germany to put down a coup attempt, announced tonight that the leader of the largest rebellious army unit had been executed.

LEAD: Bart Folse will conduct I Cantori New York in a concert of Renaissance music at St. Peter's Church, in the Citicorp Center, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8. The program includes works by Andrea and Giovanni Gabrielli, Claudio Monteverdi, Don Carlo Gesualdo, Orlando di Lasso and Giovanni Palestrina.
LEAD: Is the yearlong shutdown of the reactors at the Savannah River nuclear plant a crisis or an opportunity? Can a lemon be made into lemonade?
LEAD: Consumer prices in the New York metropolitan area continued their rise, climbing one-half of 1 percent last month, the Labor Department's regional bureau reported yesterday.

LEAD: For Ketchum Advertising, doing business with Melitta USA has been a little like a game of ''now you see it, now you don't.'' The German coffee maker's United States subsidiary had twice awarded parts of its business to the Philadelphia office of Ketchum, only to snatch it away again.
LEAD: The Glendale Federal Savings and Loan Association, a unit of Glendale Federal, is offering $150 million of floating-rate notes due 1990 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
LEAD: The United States Supreme Court today opened the way for a 15-year-old Florida girl to have an abortion without her parents' consenting to it or knowing about it.

LEAD: In a move to cement a relationship with an important customer in the booming automobile rental market, the Chrysler Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy Thrifty Rent-A-Car System Inc., the nation's fifth-largest rental company, for $263 million.

LEAD: Two of the world's largest accounting firms -Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young & Company - are expected to announce Friday that they have agreed to merge, people close to the two firms said today.

LEAD: In the largest account switch in the history of advertising, the Burger King Corporation yesterday transferred responsibility for its domestic business from N. W. Ayer to two agencies: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York.
LEAD: One week after they lost Gary Carter with a swollen right knee, the Mets took an even worse jolt yesterday when they lost Keith Hernandez for eight weeks with a fracture of the right kneecap.

LEAD: A New Jersey-Chicago squad was fast out of the blocks when the United States Bridge Championships began here Wednesday night. The tournament will determine the national team that will go to the World Championships in Perth, Australia, in September.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 468 money-market mutual funds rose by $4.9 billion, to $311.95 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The 142 institutional funds jumped by $2.35 billion, to $79.14 billion. The 231 general-purpose funds were up by $644 million, to $101.42 billion.

LEAD: BEIJING, Friday, May 19 - Prime Minister Li Peng warned Thursday that chaos in Beijing was spreading all over the country, but his demand for restraint was ignored by up to a million people who braved a driving rain to demonstrate once more for greater democracy.

LEAD: In an effort to stem losses of more than $300,000 a week on its Sunday issue, The New York Post will replace its multi-section Sunday newspaper with a version of its daily paper beginning next month, Valerie B. Salembier, the president of the New York Post Company, announced yesterday.

LEAD: Twelve years ago, when work started on a huge power dam project near the winding Danube on the border of Czechoslovakia and Hungary, leaders in both countries lauded the project as a symbol of Communist harmony.
LEAD: Henry Willis 3d, who was convicted of shooting a small-town police chief to death one day before the victim was to leave for a new job, died in the electric chair tonight.

LEAD: Cornelia Van Rensselaer King Marsh Templeton, a member of an old New York family, died of liver cancer Tuesday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. She was 78 years old and lived in Bedford, N.Y.

LEAD: Several citadels of higher education dot this state's academic map: Yale, Wesleyan, Trinity. As for the University of Connecticut at Storrs, ''they call us a cow college,'' said a spokesman, Walt McGowan.

LEAD: President Bush met with Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu at the White House today, and American officials said later that Mr. Bush had vowed to use ''pressure, influence and leverage'' on the South African Government.

LEAD: A 14-year-old Brooklyn girl was arrested Wednesday night and charged with second-degree murder after she stabbed another teen-age girl to death during a fight over a dog, the police said yesterday. The victim, Pacquita Braswell, 18, of 375 Blake Avenue in the Brownsville section, was stabbed once in the chest outside her apartment building about 11 P.M.

LEAD: At Pier 60 on the Hudson, at 20th Street, prospective buyers pursued their manifold destiny yesterday, milling around and peering into the 25 automobiles being auctioned by the Department of Motor Vehicles, which had snatched them from the streets because their owners had ignored wads of parking tickets.

LEAD: A field of nine, including the first six finishers from the Kentucky Derby, was entered today for the 114th Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday. Only eight horses, however, are likely to start.

LEAD: Baseball CINCINNATI (NL) - Activated Eric Davis, outfielder, from the 15-day disabled list. Assigned Skeeter Barnes, infielder-outfielder, to Nashville of the American Association. METS (NL) - Placed Keith Hernandez, first baseman, on the 21-day disabled list. Recalled Keith Miller, infielder, from Tidewater of the International League.
LEAD: Finally, some part of the United States Government is opening its mind and heart to the Chinese people surging for freedom and is speaking to them and for them - at least some part.

LEAD: The Afghan guerrillas move around their captured Government outpost in short spurts, dashing across exposed spaces, then crouching in the protection of bullet-pocked adobe walls. But even with the enemy at Jalalabad Airport only half a mile away, two or three rebels are asleep, wrapped in shroud-like cotton shawls in their trenches and makeshift bomb shelters.

LEAD: In the hours before the Yankees played and lost again, Don Mattingly walked into the manager's dressing room, spoke for almost a half-hour with Dallas Green, then returned to his locker and began to dress. The meeting, Mattingly said later, was a chance to clear the air, to communicate.
LEAD: Dexter Manley told a Senate panel today that he has finally overcome childhood rejection and has gained self-respect since seeking help three years ago to learn to read and write.

LEAD: This exhibition, which brings together nearly 40 portraits of children by the photographer Diane Arbus and the painter Alice Neel, is a great and simple thing. Like a good question on an art-history exam - a classic case of compare and contrast - it can trigger a deeper understanding of both the making and the seeing of art that flows effortlessly into a meditation on life itself.
LEAD: The legislature of the Soviet Republic of Lithuania declared today that the republic wanted independence.
LEAD: Commuting back and forth between the United States and South Africa prevents Gary Player from playing regularly on the Senior PGA Tour.

LEAD: From the British wave of angry new film makers, we have seen the bitterness of ''Sammy and Rosie Get Laid'' and the sardonic comedy of ''High Hopes.'' But none of the recent anti-Thatcherite works is as bleak, intense or tough-minded as ''For Queen and Country.'' The story of a working-class black man who returns to his old neighborhood after eight years in the army is the flip side of ''High Hopes,'' for the England of this film is a dim, claustrophobic, utterly hopeless place.

LEAD: A Queens prosecutor charged yesterday that a South Jamaica man was part of a four-man team that murdered Edward Byrne, the rookie police officer shot to death last year while guarding a witness in a drug case.

Goodrich Company for an undisclosed price. The factory manufactures more than one billion pounds of vinyl chloride monomer, the base of polyvinyl chloride, or PVC plastics, widely used in pipes and tubing.

LEAD: Without a doubt, the charges raised against Newt Gingrich, the combative House Republican whip, arise out of partisan fury. Representative Gingrich had partisanship on his mind when he filed charges of ethical impropriety against Speaker Jim Wright last year. But even if such accusations are politically inspired, they may nevertheless have merit, as the Wright case demonstrates.

LEAD: An all-white jury has convicted a former Ku Klux Klansman of murder for providing a rope and a pistol that were used in fellow Klansmen's assault on a black teen-ager who was strangled and hanged from a tree.

LEAD: Raymond V. B. Blackman, one of the world's leading experts on foreign navies and a former editor of the military reference work Jane's Fighting Ships, died on Wednesday, his family said today. He was 78 years old.
LEAD: A substitute teacher was charged yesterday with carrying a handgun for which he held no New York City permit into a Bronx public school, the police said.

LEAD: Declaring that the nation can no longer ''just patch or just tinker'' to repair its educational system, Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos said today that the Bush Administration would work to let parents choose the schools their children attend.

LEAD: The Miniscribe Corporation has advised stockholders that the financial statements issued in the 1986 and 1987 fiscal years and in the first three quarters of 1988 were not reliable. Shortly after the announcement Thursday, the rating firm Standard & Poor's suspended Miniscribe's B-rating on $98 million of subordinated debt, saying it would be impossible to judge the company's financial condition.

LEAD: A former funeral director, Bobby Wilks, 53 years old, pleaded guilty Wednesday to two counts of grand larceny for burying bodies without coffins or vaults their families had purchased. Mr. Wilks could be sentenced up to six years on each count. Investigators found Joseph Roath's body had been wrapped in cardboard and buried only three feet deep instead of without the coffin and vault his family ordered.

LEAD: Poring over recent statistics, many economists have concluded that the economy is managing to walk the line between inflation and recession. It is apparently growing enough to stave off a big rise in unemployment but not enough to push prices up sharply.

It's the dawn of a day that's going to be the longest and hottest of the summer. Mr. Senor Love Daddy, Bedford-Stuyvesant's favorite disk jockey, starts his wake-up show at top volume, ''doing the nasty to your ears, playing the platters that matter.'' He also opens Spike Lee's third and most accomplished film to date, the anatomy of a vicious Brooklyn racial incident. The movie, titled ''Do the Right Thing,'' has successfully shaken up the 42d Cannes International Film Festival and is suddenly a contender for the festival's top prize.

LEAD: This was their first explosion of runs in more than two weeks, and the Yankees seemed to relish every moment. They had fallen on hard times this week -12 runs in a six-game stretch - but tonight they hit a bonanza: a 9-5 rout of the surging Seattle Mariners at the Kingdome.

LEAD: The Electrolux Corporation of Marietta, Ga., announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the assets and business operations of the Regina Company, the Rahway, N.J., vacuum cleaner maker that sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April.

LEAD: The Halliburton Company, the engineering and oilfield services company, said it had acquired Sierra Geophysics Inc., a privately held computer software company that designs programs used to develop maps for minerals and energy exploration, a technology with a rapidly growing market,industry analysts say.

LEAD: As American viewers watched live television coverage from China last night, Chinese officials ordered the networks to cease transmitting pictures and commentary from a portable station set up in Beijing.

LEAD: To the Editor: The article on sugar pies brought back some fond memories - not of Montreal, but of Brussels. I discovered the pastry while on a morning ramble in the St. Josse section, where I lived. On gray and damp Sunday mornings, I often wandered the neighborhood, ending up at one of the many bakeries to purchase something to go with my morning coffee.

LEAD: Almost everybody loves Rockefeller Center, or at least the original part of it constructed in the 1930's between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. This is not just a cluster of buildings in New York City: it is a national symbol of distinguished corporate design, far and away the finest grouping of skyscrapers ever built.

LEAD: OIL, air and water do not readily mix, but problems related to them do. Each one represents a growing ecological concern, a problem in themselves, but in combination a threat to our quality of life and standard of living. As an evolving conservationist, I feel that our current problems can only grow worse if we choose to ignore them.

LEAD: Bicycling seems to have replaced running and swimming as the solo-sport of choice among upwardly mobile adults in America. More people today are using bikes for commuting and vacationing, and racing and riding them for fun and charity.

LEAD: While neighborhood residents, office workers and guests cheered, ground was broken Thursday for a new National Black Theater. LEAD: Q. Two years ago, we had a new stoop of reddish fieldstone built on top of our old concrete one. How can I remove this discoloration, and after that should I apply a sealer?

LEAD: IN THE MINUTES BEFORE the first public test-screening of Brian De Palma's new movie at a theater in Boston, a young man approaches Steven Spielberg, De Palma's friend and fellow director who is sitting in the audience with a baseball cap pulled down over his brow, and asks him if he is Steven Spielberg.

LEAD: ''The natives are extremely fond of painting,'' wrote Thomas Watling, an Australian convict, almost 200 years ago. The aborigines, who have inhabited the Australian continent for an estimated 50,000 years, have been painting on sand, bark and their own bodies for the last 30,000. Suddenly their fondness for painting, now in acrylics on canvas, is landing them squarely in the lap of the international art world, for which they are adapting their grand creation myths, maps of the land and ceremonial symbols to the West's easel- painting tradition.

LEAD: What an experience it must have been to be friends with Henry James, a man whose standards of behavior were almost ineffable, who might well have quailed under the brutal impact of a simple declarative sentence. Just to hear him out would have required a heroic patience. Yet it must have been wonderful, too, his incredible scrupulosity that pursued every thought to the end of its tether.

LEAD: Exercise: In narrative prose of anywhere from 200 to 5,000 words, describe what happened from 5:29 to 5:31 A.M. on July 16, 1945, at the place called Jornada del Muerto, or Journey of Death, in the desert near Alamogordo, N.M. Get it right and keep it fresh.

LEAD: THE YEARLY CLAMBAKE, ONE OF TWO annual McGuinness family reunions, began at dawn on a typically foggy late-July morning in Lloyd Harbor on the North Shore of Long Island. By 6 A.M., with the mist settling on top of the trees, 6 of the 31 people who would ultimately cram into the McGuinness house on this day had set off to comb the beach at Cold Spring Harbor for mussels.

LEAD: THE MANNERS MAVEN Letitia Baldrige likes to tell the tale of a hapless young executive who took one of his prized clients to lunch at a fancy restaurant. When the wine steward handed him the cork, a puzzled furrow came over the young man's executive brow. He then made an executive decision: He bit off a piece of the cork and ate it.

LEAD: THE MOST BEAUTIFUL HOUSE IN THE WORLD By Witold Rybczynski. Illustrated. 211 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.
LEAD: NOT everyone who visits the Napa Valley goes only to sample its most famous wares. The weather that produces the world-renowned wines is as agreeable for people as it is for grapes.
LEAD: A FADED 150-year-old farmhouse, set so far back from Hooten Road here that it is hidden from passing cars, may be on the verge of a new life.

LEAD: THE happiest person in Pennsylvania last month may have been Alverta Handel, a housekeeper from the town of Portage who beat 9.6 million-to-one odds to win an $8.2 million share of the record-breaking $115 million lotto jackpot. But the biggest winner by far in Pennsylvania's lottery is the state treasury, which last year netted $593 million from ticket sales.

LEAD: Jamie Herzlinger says she ''was conceived in the fashion business.'' Her grandfather Samuel Herzlinger was a coat manufacturer known as ''the king of the foxes.'' Her mother, Nan, designed sportswear and her father, Jack, produced it.

LEAD: WHEN Joanne B. learned that she was pregnant, she was determined to have a healthy baby. She quit smoking. She stopped taking over-the-counter cold medicines. She sought medical advice about drinking and was assured that ''one drink won't hurt.''

It's all a matter of perspective, of ratio. To the New York-based observer, American movie making has looked pretty paltry this year, mostly big-budget mass-market comedies of no distinction and even less humor. Three thousand miles away, the scene suddenly takes on a different, far more promising aspect. On the basis of two films shown on the second and third days of this 42d Cannes International Film Festival, one might think that American films are in the midst of some kind of crazy renaissance.
LEAD: Arno A. Penzias, a Nobel laureate and author, told graduates at Drew University's 121st commencement yesterday that career success will depend on their ability to think creatively.

LEAD: Representative Claude D. Pepper, Democrat of Florida, remained in serious but stable condition today with an undisclosed stomach ailment, said Rochelle Jones, an aide. Mr. Pepper, who at 88 years old is the oldest member of Congress, has been hospitalized at Walter Reed Army Medical Center since Monday after receiving treatment at the Johns Hopkins University Hospital in Baltimore.

LEAD: Bambi Lyman celebrated her 35th birthday the other evening in a pink and red Emilio Pucci blouse from the early 1960's and incredibly uncoordinated Lilly Pulitzer pants from the early 70's. Mrs. Lyman's husband, Lincoln, also sported Pulitzer trousers in an outspoken print. So did many of their 40 or so guests, although there was stiff competition from a cluster of madras plaids.

LEAD: Q. Two years ago, we had a new stoop of reddish fieldstone built on top of our old concrete one. The mason advised us to coat it with a silicone sealer; however, I read that this was not needed and so I did not apply any. Now the stoop is gradually turning green. How can I remove this discoloration, and after that should I apply a sealer?

LEAD: Kendal Kerrigan, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Kerrigan of Norwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Andrew Planten Gaillard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Dawson Gaillard of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. David Cannon performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Preston, Conn.
LEAD: LAST month a new store opened here on Newark Avenue, just down the street from the Hudson County Courthouse. ''Lotto Express Inc.'' read the sign; ''Lotto to Go,'' its motto.

LEAD: A 68-YEAR-OLD relative of mine has just been damned with faint praise by some family members for having finally purchased a burial site. From my point of view, he wasn't fooling around. It isn't one of these above-ground pink marble waterproof jobs. It is a real, in the ground gravesite, in a cemetery where some of his ancesters he never met are buried.

LEAD: Trustees sent in to clean up a troubled Bronx school board six months ago have discovered a system in which educational programs were subordinated to politics, sound budgeting practices were ignored and much time and money were devoted to publicizing local board members.

LEAD: Yielding to misguided populism, New York City's charter commission proposes a new planning policy so flawed that it's almost guaranteed to fail. The proposal, in its eagerness to distribute planning power, risks destroying it.

Schwartz, president of Catalyst, a not-for-profit research and advisory organization that works with companies to advance the careers of women. The article, called ''Management Women and the New Facts of Life,'' contained a number of provocative ideas, including the assertion that it costs companies more to employ women than men.

LEAD: Faced with the possibility that they could lose control of Japan's political system for the first time in three decades, leaders of Japan's ruling party have embraced measures that would require politicians to disclose their financial assets and would abolish intraparty factions.

LEAD: IN THE LAND OF SHADE TREES AND PEONY beds, of linen shirts and bare feet, of friends bunched on the deck and families strewn all over the lawn, the cocktail can no longer be assumed to be king. More and more, an icy pitcher full of punch - which used to seem such a throwback, such an archaism, such a dodge - strikes a lot of people as up-to-the-minute and just right.
LEAD: The Bush Administration received support from President Francois Mitterrand of France today in its effort to resolve the dispute in the Western alliance over short-range nuclear missiles.

LEAD: Under intensifying military pressure, the Soviet-backed Government of President Najibullah announced today that it would appoint a three-member commission to negotiate without conditions to end Afghanistan's 10-year war.

LEAD: For years, perhaps for centuries, Luxembourg has usually been an afterthought on a European tour. LEAD: The dropout rate in West Virginia high schools has been reduced almost a third by a new attendance law that lifts the driver's licenses of students who choose dropping out over education.

LEAD: JACKSON HOLE looks too good to be true. The great, glaciered peaks of the Tetons, arguably the continent's most classically beautiful mountains, soar more than a mile into the air from the valley floor. A half-dozen pristine alpine lakes puddle at the base of the range, and the braided channels of the Snake River meander through the valley's lush meadows, sagebrush flats and groves of willow, cottonwood and aspen.

LEAD: GARDENING TIPS It's about now or never as far as getting that garden planted. And just in time comes a program at Muscoot Farm Park in Somers that offers some free advice on planting and caring for herb, vegetable and flower gardens.

LEAD: FOR YEARS, ITALIAN WINE ENTHUSI-asts kept Friuli pretty much to themselves. But now, this lovely, still unspoiled region is being discovered by the rest of the world. Most of Friuli, or Friuli-Venezia Guilia, as the area is officially known, was originally part of the Venetian Republic, and is one of the oldest of all wine regions in Europe.

LEAD: With his fractured right forearm cushioned in a plastic brace, steering was somewhat awkward and the fit was a bit tight, but nine days after he broke his arm in a practice-run crash, Danny Sullivan squeezed into his backup Penske-Chevrolet race car yesterday and qualified for next Sunday's Indianapolis 500.

LEAD: In response to Ms. Berman's letter (''Praise that isn't fulsome,'' April 23), I do appreciate it.

LEAD: There is a magical forest in George Balanchine's production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' The choreographer tells Shakespeare's story of lovers' quarrels and rapprochements with imagination and humor. As in his ''Nutcracker,'' Balanchine takes care of the story in the first act, preparing the way for sheer dance in the second.
LEAD: The Ladies Professional Golf Association has narrowed to three the number of sites it is considering for its new national headquarters.

LEAD: At recess at the Cleveland Elementary School here, children cower near the building so they can run for cover if the shooting starts again. Teachers scan the adjoining streets wondering which stranger is an intruder, and parents gather outside the chain-link fence, worried and watchful.

LEAD: FAT people of the world, unite. A crisis is imminent. Every magazine, newspaper, and television show you see screams the evils of fat and the beauty of ''thin.'' Unless we react to this crisis, we may have nothing to gain and everything to lose. We must remain on guard.

LEAD: To read your article, one would think the modern comic book is distinguished from its predecessors solely by today's explicit sex and violence. You ignore the laudable differences: a variety of nonwhite heroes, strong female characters (one series, ''The X-Men,'' has for years offered a rare role model: a black woman as the leader of the group) and socially relevant issues, from the Arab-Israeli conflict to drug abuse.

LEAD: Elizabeth Dowling Bartle and David Mark Boghossian were married yesterday at the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Boston. The Rev. Theodore H. Evans performed the ceremony. Marion Stuart Bartle was the maid of honor for her twin sister. Paul Boghossian 3d was best man for his brother.

LEAD: History happening before our eyes: That was our awed feeling as we watched the scenes in Tienanmen Square, until the Chinese Government cut the international television links. Here was a giant society stirring against a regime that was suddenly, amazingly, vulnerable.

LEAD: ONCE an ailing industrial center that was the butt of vaudeville jokes, New Britain has been discovered by office developers. They are drawn to the city's recently enhanced telephone system, a potential labor pool of disgruntled commuters, one of the best mass transit systems in the state and an urban renewal area that has been designated an enterprise zone.
LEAD: EGON MAYER, professor of sociology at Brooklyn College, is widely regarded as the nation's leading expert on the growing phenomenon of Jewish-Christian intermarriage.

LEAD: WHEN JACK JELENKO AND HIS wife, Margaret, dine out near their home in Sonoma County, California, their priorities are not always titillating cuisine or an enchanting atmosphere. Rather, they tend to look for a place where tables are uncluttered, service is rapid-fire and much of the food is plain and familiar.

LEAD: RECENTLY, while experimenting with a form of prose bordering on minimalist fiction, I wrote a story about two girls who were pushed to the edge of nervous breakdowns by problems within their families. I am proud of that story; it has moved some readers to tears and caused others to remark that they thought it had been written by someone older than my 17-year-old self.

LEAD: Earlier this year, Rand V. Araskog, the chief executive of the ITT Corporation, held the company's first worldwide management meeting since 1981. Someone at the meeting asked what he thought ITT would look like in the year 2000. All Mr. Araskog could do was laugh.

LEAD: DEEP inside the Olympic rain forest on the far western edge of the continent, there is not a fingerprint of the 20th century, nor the 18th century for that matter. The trees in this part of world were seedlings when Leif Ericson stumbled upon Greenland a thousand years ago; they were mature firs when Columbus landed in the Caribbean islands and towering giants when the Declaration of Independence was signed.
LEAD: The older people are when they become infected with the AIDS virus, the more quickly they become ill, researchers are finding.

LEAD: DAVE BRUBECK is back, restored to health and hard at work. Mr. Brubeck, the 69-year-old jazz pianist, composer and lecturer, underwent quadruple-bypass surgery at Yale-New Haven Hospital in February, was back performing two months later and now is working in the studio at his Wilton home on new pieces both sacred and secular.

LEAD: Maggie Scarf's article made me anxious and a little angry. Outspoken feminists often are portrayed unjustly as angry women. Yet, if our predecessors had not spoken up out of anger and indignation, women in America would not today have the rights these women argued for. PAMELA J. SPAAN Ithaca, N.Y.

LEAD: COLLECTED POEMS By Philip Larkin. Edited by Anthony Thwaite. 330 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

LEAD: IN this city of skyscrapers and giant apartment blocks, a low-rise mingling of row houses and one- or two-family houses covers half the land. As housing costs rose, developers used a zoning loophole to scatter boxy, bulky apartment buildings through many of these neighborhoods.

LEAD: One can only presume, after reading Joe Queenan's report on skyrocketing sales of DC and Marvel comics, in his article ''Drawing on the Dark Side'' (April 30), that the comic-book publishers have become a little complacent recently. How else to explain the omission from their title list of a comic-book adventure series based on the real-life exploits of our very own hardball playing, all-American superhero, Harvey Lee Atwater, national Republican Party chairman?

LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration is recalling institutional-size cans of mushrooms from China because of three outbreaks of food poisoning in February and April, including one at the Peninsula Hospital Center cafeteria in Queens.

Mack of Birmingham, Mich., have announced.
LEAD: FOR those who have helped design and build one, a Robert S. Leathers playground is more than just a playground: it is the stuff of children's dreams and the fruit of a community's labor.

LEAD: The British Government has told the Bush Administration that any offer now to negotiate with the Soviet Union on short-range nuclear missiles in Europe would be a mistake and a personal setback to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, British and American officials said today.

LEAD: The Harmonie Ensemble celebrated its 10th anniversary on Tuesday evening with an Alice Tully Hall concert devoted mostly to music by George Gershwin. The performances were offered in the spirit of authenticity, in the sense that several of the works typically heard in posthumous rescorings were performed here in their original versions.

LEAD: For the most part, I think comics are soap operas for men. My husband is an avid fan, and when he tries to explain the goings-on of the various heroes, I can't help thinking about my soap operas - complicated fantasies full of bizarre plot twists.

LEAD: A Japanese entrepreneur has offered to pay the travel expenses for an international fleet of 50-foot sailboats and their crews to race in his home waters.

LEAD: Q. Two years ago, we had a new stoop of reddish fieldstone built on top of our old concrete one. The mason advised us to coat it with a silicone sealer; however, I read that this was not needed and so I did not apply any. Now the stoop is gradually turning green. How can I remove this discoloration, and after that should I apply a sealer?

LEAD: THOUGH low-cost camping, educational and vacation opportunities have been available to elderly people in various parts of the country for some time, a Boston-based program called Elderhostel has drawn a greatly increasing number of participants and institutions in recent years.

LEAD: It was Friday morning over breakfast. The Knicks were at Chicago Stadium preparing for the sixth game of their Eastern Conference semifinal. A loss to the Chicago Bulls would end the season, a victory would force a seventh game at Madison Square Garden.
LEAD: Unexpectedly strong income tax payments pouring into the Treasury are prompting analysts to predict that the Government's budget deficit this year may be below official projections.

LEAD: The fans did not boo Mark Jackson for missing a shot at a critical point in the first playoff game against Chicago. The fans have no other civilized way to express their disapproval for an incredibly dumb, egotistical attempt to hit a bomb with seven seconds left in a tie game. (He was closer to half court than he was to the three-point line.) His responsibility was to work the ball for a good shot.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE American Hotel dates to 1846, when Sag Harbor and its whaling fleets were in their heyday. Seventeen years ago, it was restored and its restaurant has earned high marks for fine food and a voluminous wine list ever since.
LEAD: Representative James Florio, the leading candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor, lashed out today at an opponent who taunted him for months.

LEAD: An article on April 23 about Portland, Ore., misstated the addresses of two restaurants. The Bangkok Kitchen is at 2534 Southeast Belmont; Thanh Thoa is at 4005 Southeast Hawthorne Boulevard. A map with the article mislabeled the body of water adjacent to Oregon. It was the Pacific.

LEAD: Now in its fifth year, the rivalry between camcorder formats seems endless, pointless and confusing. But videophiles are willy-nilly forced to take sides. They must choose one of the two contesting formats - VHS or 8-millimeter - when buying a camcorder, and naturally they'd like to pick the winner.

LEAD: The days of the greasy, hole-in-the-wall bike storefront are numbered. Independent bicycle shops are moving toward a tonier image, offering not just bikes but fashionable accessories and gadgets.

LEAD: DORIS LOUIE melds impressions of the landscape of the Southwest with motifs from Native American weaving in her tapestry rugs. LEAD: CINDERELLA Retold by Barbara Karlin. Illustrated by James Marshall. Unpaged. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8)
LEAD: A caption last Sunday about Elaine Benson, an art gallery owner, misidentified the sculpture beside her. It was ''Young Venus'' by Molly Mason.

LEAD: PORT CHESTER, February 1889. Fourteen Port Chester matrons, concerned over the plight of the sick and infirm in the community, form the Ladies Hospital Association, ''to serve humanity, to save lives and to relieve suffering.'' During the next several months they hold cake sales, lawn fetes and entertainments until they raise enough money to rent space for a hospital.
LEAD: REMEMBER an overbearingly cute song called ''Freedom'' from the high-minded musical ''Shenandoah''? And how it purported to tell us all those things the word really meant?

LEAD: Braving gale-force winds and drenching rains from Typhoon Brenda, demonstrators turned out by the thousands today in Hong Kong and Macao in support of the Beijing student protests, and against the Chinese Government's hard line.

LEAD: WHILE Democrats in the House of Representatives sink ever deeper into a dismal mood over Speaker Jim Wright's ethical troubles, party political apparatchiks are embroiled in the latest round of what has been a two-decade-long Democratic fight over the rules under which the party selects its Presidential nominees.

LEAD: IN ''Spooks,'' at the Crossroads Theater Company, Howard and Karen are an upwardly mobile black couple. In their BMW, they have driven from New York to the Virginia mansion - ''the dream house'' - that Howard purchased. It's late at night, which is just the time to move into ''a big old house in the middle of nowhere.

LEAD: FOR SOMEONE WHO OWNS A CLASSIC clapboard house with a sloping lawn overlooking the route of one of Vermont's most popular Fourth of July parades, it would seem positively unneighborly not to ask a few friends over to watch. Early in the 1970's, soon after buying her Warren, Vt., home as a refuge from her life in Manhattan as a sportswear designer, Monika Tilley did just that.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday about school desegration in Little Rock, Ark., referred incorrectly to Central High School. Central, where Federal troops were sent 32 years ago to protect nine black pupils, is now 58 percent black and 42 percent white. It is not one of the schools with overwhelmingly black enrollment that would get increased funds for remedial programs as part of a current desegregation proposal.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: VIOLENT crimes are increasing in Connecticut and throughout the country, according to state and national statistics. Many of those crimes never make the news, but others, like the recent attack on the jogger in Central Park, not only make headlines, but cause many people to react as well.

LEAD: A new crop of college graduates will soon be leaving the campus. While some will begin jobs immediately, others may first take a long vacation. Still others are putting off the job search until after graduation.

LEAD: Former Senator Warren Magnuson of Washington, one of the country's most formidable lawmakers and politicians until the Reagan tide wrote an end to his 44 years on Capitol Hill, died yesterday. He was 84 years old and lived in Seattle.
LEAD: The nation's governors, who won Congressional support last year for their overhaul of the welfare system, maintain that the Administration is undermining the new law.

LEAD: Jamie Avins is an architectural choreographer. That was evident from the clear-cut gestures of ''Center and Circumference,'' the program she presented Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. It was even more apparent in the sets she designed for her productions. The environments in which her dancers found themselves affected the ways in which they moved.

LEAD: He spent most of the 1988-89 season on the injured list, but at the age of 30, Ilkka Sinisalo, the Philadelphia Flyers' high-scoring right wing, still has some goals left in him.

LEAD: THE growing problem of teen-age pregnancy on Long Island is prompting heightened efforts by state, county, local and private agencies to provide outreach, information, family planning, prenatal, education and referral services.

LEAD: There really wasn't much Darryl Strawberry could do. He moved slightly in pursuit of Will Clark's enormous shot before conceding the inevitable and stopping, not even bothering to look. He looked a little longer at and ran a little farther after Kevin Mitchell's rocket five pitches later before acknowledging that it, too, was out of the park.
LEAD: Ian Rush, a late substitute, scored two overtime goals today as Liverpool beat local rival Everton, 3-2, in the English F.A. Cup final.

LEAD: The blues-bar circuit doesn't exactly encourage subtlety or originality. For up-and-coming performers who are attached to blues and old-fashioned soul music, however, it's the only circuit there is, and every so often there's a glimpse of real bluesy depth. Joan Osborne, who sang Thursday night at Mondo Cane, doesn't pretend to be anything other than white and northern.

LEAD: For Navy Capt. David M. Walker, the easy part was commanding the space shuttle Atlantis on a four-day flight around the earth earlier this month. The more hazardous part was getting to Washington from Houston last week for a Presidential reception honoring the shuttle crew. About 30 miles west of Washington, aviation officials said, a jet training plane piloted by Captain Walker came within 500 feet of a Pan American World Airways wide-body jet carrying 176 people and bound for Paris, prompting the Pan Am pilot to report a ''near midair collision.

LEAD: Cray Research Inc., the nation's biggest maker of supercomputers, announced last week that it would split into two companies. After the announcement, its chairman, John A. Rollwagen, met with reporters and editors of The New York Times to discuss the future of supercomputing and how this development affects it.

LEAD: An epidemic of yellow fever has broken out in the central jungles of Bolivia, and officials are concerned that the deadly disease may spread to heavily populated areas as well as to neighboring Brazil.

LEAD: If as is widely presumed Deng Xiaoping made the key decision to call in the army to crack down on the demonstrators in Beijing - protesters who have demanded his retirement - he becomes a paradoxical, possibly even tragic figure.

LEAD: The close resemblance between different brands of stereo receivers is easily explained. Koch made gloomy predictions about New York City's fiscal prospects and appeared to be readying himself to run for re-election as ''the Mayor who could say no.'' Last week, as he proposed a $26.6 billion budget for the coming fiscal year, he seemed to have switched his line to, ''Yes, but.

LEAD: The first half of Calliope's program Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall brought the familiar piping, buzzing, tinkling and droning sounds of a Renaissance consort playing works by Praetorius, Isaac, Des Prez and their less-known or unknown fellows. It was pleasant and jolly in the usual way: the sounds of the old instruments have lost little of their piquant flavor; the actual music making is a little on the light side; the Calliope foursome's determinedly down-home vocal contributions create the right atmosphere.

LEAD: A sharp decline in the number of farms in New York State was reported this week by the United States Census Bureau.

LEAD: There is a lot of Jeff Koons and his ultra-ironic art of sleek surfaces and mass-media iconography in Karole Armitage's new ''Contempt,'' performed at the New Ritz on Tuesday night. Mr. Koons designed the decor and costumes with David Salle, and ''Contempt'' is one of the handsomest dances of recent memory.
LEAD: IT is easy for people to tell my mother to sell her apartment and move to Florida. It is hard for me.

LEAD: O.K., so they weren't exactly Amazin'. Their uniforms stretched in odd places and their limbs no longer bent in the old familiar ones. It mattered not at all. The 1969 Mets, reunited, if not rejuvenated, were together and playing again. It lasted only a couple of moments, but it was a marvelously minor miracle all the same.

LEAD: By May 30, the trade representative, Carla Hills, must issue a list of countries that unfairly restrict United States imports. According to section 301 of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988, once a country is put on the list, the trade representative must begin negotiations to correct the unfair practices.
LEAD: The Alder Manor in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was the setting last evening for the wedding of Jessica Feder and Adam Birnbaum. Rabbi Emily Faust Korzenick officiated.

LEAD: Jeans have been through a lot in their day. They've been pegged, bell-bottomed, cut off, bibbed, bleached and dyed in all manner of psychedelic hues. That last was in an age past, the 60's: a millennium ago in fashion terms.

LEAD: Chinese nationals and emigres in major cities across the United States rallied to the support of China's widening democracy movement yesterday with protests against the Beijing Government and calls for the resignation of Prime Minister Li Peng.

LEAD: Fussy makeup and hair are antithetical to summer weekends, when dressing amounts to little more than a bathing suit and cooking means lighting the grill. The traditional approach - packing away the makeup and baking in the sun - is no longer a reasonable solution. Even those who like a bit of sun are wise to its hazards.

LEAD: THIS city of 45,000, where 70 percent of the labor force once worked in textiles, has capitalized on one asset - land - to participate in the economic growth of the metropolitan Charlotte, N.C., region.

LEAD: With millions of dollars riding on big-time collegiate athletics, the N.C.A.A. has strict rules prohibiting colleges from paying players more than the value of their athletic scholarships. The rules are intended to avoid bidding wars that could divert some of those profits from collegiate coffers into the pockets of the players who earn them.

LEAD: I became so absorbed when I read Peter Brandon Bayer's story about his experiences with hemophilia and HIV that I consciously had to relax my sweaty, clenched hands and fight back emotion (''A Life In Limbo,'' April 2). For the first time in three and a half years, I did not feel alone.

LEAD: Some called her ''the conscience of white South Africa.'' Others called her worse. Whatever the view, all sides joined last week in praising Helen Suzman, South Africa's best known white campaigner against apartheid, who decided to retire from Parliament after 36 years. For years, Mrs. Suzman was the only legislator representing opponents of the legal policy of racial discrimination.

LEAD: Alexandra Davis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otis B. Davis of Kent, Conn., was married there yesterday to Anthony Francis DiPentima, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Panteleone R. DiPentima of Sunrise, Fla. The Rev. Roger B. White performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church. Mrs. DiPentima is a partner at the Hartford law firm of Moller, Horton & Fineberg.

LEAD: I don't remember when the idea struck me to write a play about two feuding actresses, legends in their time, who were somewhat over the hill, had made one film together that was a box-office hit but represented personal hell during the making. What if one of them, Sylvia, always played the Joan Crawford parts, the one who started out scrubbing dishes in a diner and was going to make it to Chicago if she had to step over her mother, 12 orphans, several politicians and 23 lovers.

LEAD: WITH progress in reducing the infant mortality rate in the United States seemingly stalled, Congress is considering a host of new measures intended to address what has become a notorious symbol of national failure.
LEAD: It was not a good time to be a goaltender.
LEAD: At the halfway point of the commencement season, members of the Bush Administration have proved to be the stars plucked most eagerly by America's colleges and universities.

LEAD: ''I NEEDED someone with a quicker wit than mine,'' Prince sang in his ''Ballad of Dorothy Parker'' in 1987. That ought to give pause to those who presume that Parker, the Jazz Age writer reknowned for her caustic wit, is unknown to younger generations.

LEAD: Fifteen evangelical Protestant theologians have issued a statement warning that creating a dialogue with Jews cannot substitute for converting them. The theologians urge Christian churches to put a high priority on proselytism.

LEAD: Who would have ever thought that some Long Island congressmen would actually be strongly against jobs for Long Island (''U.S. Decision to Curb F-14 Sends a Jolt to Economy,'' April 30). What I hope the people of Long Island are finally realizing is that when a congressman is anti-defense, he is anti-Long Island.

LEAD: Cynthia Lee Prescott and James Richard Kuster were married yesterday at the West Copake (N.Y.) Reformed Church by its minister, the Rev. James Chase, and the Rev. James Adelman, a United Church of Christ minister. The couple work for the Chase Manhattan Bank, she as an associate in the primary industries finance division and he as an associate in the media and entertainment finance division.

LEAD: To characterize an entire industry as ''determined to dispel any lingering notion that its products are for children'' is incorrect. One need only glance at the comics issued by Archie Comic Publications (''Betty and Veronica,'' ''Jughead''), Father Tree Press (''Elfquest''), Another Rainbow/Gladstone (''Mickey Mouse'' and ''Donald Duck'') and the revival of Classics Illustrated by the Berkley Publishing Group, First Publishing and Classics Media Group.

LEAD: MY FATHER'S HOUSE: A Memoir of Incest and of Healing, by Sylvia Fraser. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Emerging from partial amnesia, a Canadian novelist realizes that as a child she developed an alternate personality to repress the fact that she had a sexual relationship with her father. Sylvia Fraser has written ''a case history that doubles as literature,'' Jill Johnston said here last year.

LEAD: One would have to search hard to find a playwright more obsessed with machismo, heroism and psychic emasculation than Mark Medoff. In his first successful play, ''When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder?'' a gun-toting drifter terrorizes the occupants of a roadside diner into confronting ''the truth'' about themselves.

LEAD: When James Pitney took title to his brother Jonathan's farm in 1771, the property was one of the most extensive in northern New Jersey. It had been assembled by Pitneys since the first of them, also named James, settled in the area earlier in the century. There was little more around then than gently rolling hills, woodlands and meadows, criss-crossed here and there by streams and by narrow, winding paths.

LEAD: A table last week showing the volume of weekly bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange included two errors. The numbers shown for 1988 and 1989 should be reversed. In addition, the year-to-date figure in terms of par value for 1988 was listed incorrectly. It is $2,905,375,000.
LEAD: There is a place, just 20 miles from Manhattan, where white sails stretch against a blue sky, boat motors purr through the bay and masts bob at their docks as the sun goes down.

LEAD: It would be foolish and wasteful to spend $4.4 billion on the Superconducting Supercollider when newer and superior technology -plasma particle accelerators, as reported in the March issue of Scientific American - is being proposed. The whole question of the S.S.C. deserves another look. We should pursue the development of a machine that could prove to be much cheaper and produce more power (faster particles).

LEAD: The Bush Administration's conditions for holding American-Soviet talks on short-range nuclear missiles would delay the negotiated reductions of those weapons for a substantial period of years, according to Western officials.

LEAD: As a lay person, I read with fascination James Trefil's lucid discussion of the proposed Superconducting Supercollider and the scientific discoveries it may yield (''Beyond the Quark,'' April 30). As a cynic, I am moved to wonder what military applications could motivate Congress to spend $4.4 billion on the project.

LEAD: BEGINNING Friday, with the start of the Memorial Day weekend and the traditional opening of the summer season, marine patrol officers will be on the lookout for drunken, speeding and reckless boaters.

LEAD: IN A MOVIE CAREER SPANNING MORE THAN 30 years and films from A (for ''Alfie'') to Z (for ''Zulu''), the 56-year-old Michael Caine has played everything from foppish Victorian officers to cold-war spies and contemporary con men. But there is one role he has never played: chef. That he reserves for his private life.
LEAD: Most players, no matter how practical, flexible or free from dogma, like to see their strategies stand up for a while - if not forever. But these days that seems quite impossible.

LEAD: THE BICENTENNIAL CELEBRATION of the French Revolution probably does call for some flamboyance. Alors, among the acts that will parade the length of the Champs-Elysees on the night of July 14 is the marching band of Florida A.& M. University doing the Michael Jackson ''moonwalk''; and two Russian ice skaters, one dressed up as a bear, the other as a ballerina, performing on a mobile rink.

LEAD: Hundreds of supporters of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos marched to the presidential palace today to demand that the ousted strongman, who is critically ill in a Hawaiian hospital, be allowed to return to the Philippines.

LEAD: I attended the game marked by the booing of Mark Jackson. I booed, too. However, my displeasure was directed toward Coach Rick Pitino. He was substituting Jackson for a ''hot'' Rod Strickland. I was booing Pitino's removal of Strickland from the game, not Jackson's entry into the game or his performance.

LEAD: Amid angry protests from a crowded courtroom, three Spanish judges dismissed murder charges today against distributors of an adulterated cooking oil that was found to have caused almost 700 deaths since a mass poisoning disaster occurred here in 1981.

LEAD: In ''The Sickening Cost of Getting Sick'' (Opinion page, April 30), Richard Elsberry expresses dismay that patients like himself ''smart enough to have health insurance or money in the bank'' are forced to support medical care for the ''poor and indigent.'' Until the state finds a ''kinder and gentler way'' (do I read lips in assuming this does not mean raising taxes?), he proposes an interim solution: the less smart should ''seek more affordable care out of state.

LEAD: I believe that Maggie Scarf's concluding suggestion in ''What, Me Angry?'' (Hers column: April 23), that she deal with her anger by taking a Valium, was meant in jest; however, I feel the joke may be lost on many. As a society, we tend to accept the idea of medicating our feelings - if not with Valium, then with alcohol.

LEAD: Westchester recycling programs won't get very far until the county's system of paying for garbage disposal is overhauled. The problem is that, under the present set-up, the major costs of recycling are paid by local government but the savings go to the county government.

Meese 3d, he summoned the agency's employees to hear what he expected of them. The language was blunt: ''no surprises,'' no ''counterproductive confusion,'' no ''giving aid and comfort to our adversaries and ill-wishers.

LEAD: A new chapter seemed to open in the history of China's Army yesterday as students and others faced military units on Beijing's streets trying to persuade them not to interfere with the huge protests going on in the center of the capital.

Alberto Mancini of Argentina, seeded 11th, beat unseeded Jordi Arrese of Spain, 6-2, 6-4, in the other semifinal on the slow red clay of the Foro Italico.
LEAD: It's not just specialty shops that are changing as bicycle retailing gets more competitive. Sporting goods discount stores and mail-order outlets are transforming their trade, as well.

LEAD: Ralph A. Corbin Jr., a New Jersey banker for the last quarter-century, died of kidney failure at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J., yesterday. He was 54 years old and lived in West Caldwell.

LEAD: UP IN FRIULI, THE ITALIAN RE-gion wedged into the northeastern corner of the country between the Alps and the Adriatic, people take great pride in what they like to call their native reserve. Walter Filiputti, the winemaker at the Abbazia di Rosazzo, a winery on the grounds of an 11th-century abbey that is an hour's drive north of Venice, is a typical Friulano.

LEAD: Swarming over trucks at the Mexican border, drilling tiny holes in the ribs of cargo containers at ports and airports, members of the National Guard have begun carrying out a $300 million program that expands the role of the military in anti-drug efforts.

LEAD: For This Week: Set out annual flowers, container-grown perennials and shrubs; be sure to work the planting holes well and incorporate organic material to aid the soil's water retention and improve its tilth. Finish pruning forsythia, kerria and other spring-flowering shrubs by cutting out one third of the older canes to ground level.

LEAD: Two Soviet state prosecutors, in a defiant test of the new policy of openness, are causing an uproar with charges that the Kremlin is quashing their inquiry into state corruption that they say might reach all the way to the Politburo.

LEAD: Soviet television viewers tonight received their most accurate account so far of the political turmoil in the streets of Beijing, including a brief glimpse of troops using force against the demonstrators.

LEAD: After Greco has applied makeup to a woman's face, he sometimes has to resist the impulse to sign his name - in eyebrow pencil - on the chin, perhaps, or beside a dimple. The 35-year-old makeup expert once studied art and now considers the face his canvas. He refuses to work in artificial light, and has been known to wander from room to room in clients' homes in search of sun.

LEAD: IT IS NO SECRET THAT THE NATO Alliance, which celebrates its 40th birthday next week, is going through a midlife crisis. For more than a month now, Americans and Germans have been locked in a loud cross-Atlantic argument over the alliance's short-range nuclear missiles in Europe, one that is likely to continue at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's coming meeting in Brussels.
LEAD: WITH Memorial Day weekend coming up, thoughts turn to summer entertaining. Buffet dishes that do not have to be served hot are among the best choices.

LEAD: A chart in some copies last Sunday about the New York City subways gave incorrect figures for ridership. The number of riders on an average weekday rose from 3.52 million in the first quarter of 1985 to 3.71 million in the same period this year.

LEAD: When one of China's student hunger strikers said last week that his demand was for ''a beautiful, perfect system,'' he was not merely being naive. He was reflecting in somewhat naive-sounding terms the yearning for restored national greatness that has led Chinese youth several times this century to take to the streets to demand change from what they saw as incompetent or dictatorial governments.

LEAD: LAST week a North Carolina gastroenterologist, speaking at a medical meeting in Washington, told of his small research project that has found that runners sometimes suffer from heartburn as they run. It was going to be an easy, uneventful day, the kind any middle-aged man would enjoy on his birthday.

In the video, Mr. O'Dwyer, who publishes a newsletter on the industry, quizzes the chief executives of the 10 largest agencies on current industry issues.

LEAD: President Bush's sister injured three police officers in a minor car accident Sunday on the way to hear her brother speak at Boston University's commencement. The officers had been directing Nancy Bush Ellis to a parking area when the car suddenly lurched backward and struck the officers, causing minor injuries, the police said.

LEAD: Responding to concerns over a new decree on the limits of dissent, the Soviet Government today issued a ''clarification'' stating that there would be no criminal proceedings merely for voicing criticism of the state.
LEAD: Brooklyn prosecutors reduced the most serious charge late last night against a teen-age mother who abandoned her 2-year-old daughter Friday in a women's restroom in Kings County Medical Center.

LEAD: Rabbi Zelo Schussheim, a professor of Talmud for more than 40 years, died of a heart attack Sunday at Booth Memorial Medical Center in Flushing, Queens. He was 62 years old and lived in Kew Gardens.
LEAD: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to the 30th annual conference of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee:

LEAD: Q. Why are there two high tides and two low tides each day? A. LEAD: A top Chinese official met today with Vice President Dan Quayle and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and said there would be no bloodshed in Beijing if the demonstrators continued to exercise restraint, an Administration official said.

LEAD: With the rest of the British political spectrum undergoing the most significant shift in years, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her resistance to European political and economic union have suddenly become the most heated issue in the campaign for elections for the European Parliament next month.

LEAD: An article in Business Day last Tuesday about legislation to help the savings and loan industry referred incorrectly to the liability of certain investors in a savings institution should that institution fail. Under a legislative amendment offered by Representative Peter Hoagland, Democrat of Nebraska, investors in a limited partnership that purchases an ailing savings institution would not be protected against losses should the institution fail.

LEAD: In other years boxing was a business of noble cruelty. ''But it's not boxing anymore,'' the old trainer Ray Arcel was saying recently. ''It's exploitation.'' And day by day, it's almost wrestling.

LEAD: Federal regulators announced new regulations today requiring savings institutions to meet more stringent standards in documenting their securities activities, the latest in a series of steps to tighten supervision of the troubled industry.

LEAD: An article by The Associated Press on Wednesday about the dismissal of Col. Jack Walsh as superintendent of the Ohio Highway Patrol misstated the cost of a free trip he took to South Africa as a guest of the City Council of Johannesburg. It cost about $4,000, not $18,000.

LEAD: House Speaker Jim Wright is hardly the only member of Congress with an ethics problem. Newly filed financial reports show that most representatives and senators continue to supplement their $89,500 annual salary by pocketing generous honorariums from Government favor-seekers.

LEAD: The Congressional Black Caucus was invited to the White House today for the first time in eight years, and though the 20 Democrats were grateful to President Bush for bringing them back to the table, they did not mince words.
LEAD: Three men were arrested yesterday and charged with pelting a police officer with rocks they were throwing at motorists on the Harlem River Drive, the police said.

LEAD: Representative Claude Pepper, Democrat of Florida, remained in ''serious but stable'' condition at Walter Reed Army Hospital today, his press secretary said. LEAD: Calgary is one victory away from doing what no Canadiens' opponent has done: hoisting the Stanley Cup in triumph on the Montreal Forum ice.

LEAD: The State Department urged yesterday that American citizens defer travel to China for at least 72 hours as a result of the student demonstrations. It also said the United States Embassy had advised travelers in Beijing not to leave their immediate residental area or hotel.

LEAD: In his 159th official time at bat this season, Don Mattingly finally hit his first home run after three earlier singles last night, but the Yankees lost to the California Angels, 11-4, in Jim Abbott's debut at Yankee Stadium.
LEAD: Vice President Dan Quayle told 1,011 soaked but enthusiastic graduating cadets at the United States Military Academy today to be prepared to lead a ''revolution in military affairs.''

LEAD: The Rev. Paul H. Beattie, a Unitarian clergyman who was a leader in the humanist movement, died Monday of complications following heart surgery at Presbyterian University Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 52 years old and lived in Pittsburgh.

LEAD: International telephone rates to 27 countries will drop by as much as 9 percent on June 1, ITT Communications Services Inc. said. The reductions will apply to the first minute of calls during the standard daytime period, which covers the hours of business for the country being called. Calls from the continental United States will fall 9 percent for the first minute to some nations, while those to other countries will drop 8 percent, 7 percent or 6 percent.

LEAD: First Nationwide Bank priced a $100 million offering of three-year notes. The notes, which will mature June 1, 1992, carry a 9 1/2 percent coupon and were priced at $100, or 70 basis points over the prevailing yield on three-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing. Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the underwriting.

LEAD: WE are sitting around a dinner table, six reasonably intelligent, reasonably well-educated people. We have opinions on everything short of economics and fusion, and we can defend most of them with some skill. So far tonight we have discussed the affairs of the day, a Broadway musical and whether New York City has a future.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a brief article in Sports Pages on Tuesday about the postponement of the Dodge Charity Classic golf tournament at the Rockaway River Country Club in Denville, N.J., gave the rescheduling date incorrectly. The tournament will be held in late September.
LEAD: Americans ought not to remain silent as India continues a harmful and indefensible blockade of Nepal.

LEAD: The National Transportation Safety Board, in a report documenting serious lapses in the air traffic control system in Southern California, has criticized the Federal Aviation Administration for ''inadequate, ineffective and unresponsive'' management.

LEAD: Roger S. Penske has three cars competing in the Indianapolis 500 race on Sunday, a contest he has dominated with four victories in the last five years. Winning again would be sweet for a man who first achieved renown as a champion driver during the 1960's.

LEAD: Richard E. Bader, whose experience in government and the arts ranged from expediting construction of police headquarters in New York City to co-ownership of a theater, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: An article in Business Day on April 22 about a patent dispute between the Hughes Aircraft Company and the Federal Government misidentified the law firm where Tom Arnold, a patent attorney, is a partner. Mr. Arnold works for the Houston firm of Arnold, White & Durkee.

LEAD: A seventh grader was charged with assault yesterday after a classmate was stabbed in the back with a steak knife at their junior high school, the police said.

LEAD: Even though Congress feels burdened by the Federal deficit, it has been unwilling to cede the power of the purse to the President. Thus, Congress has been wary of giving the President the power of the line-item veto. But there is a better way to cut spending.

LEAD: To the Editor:

When it's time to look back on the strange sweep of Clint Eastwood's career, from his ambitious direction of ''Bird'' to his coarse, classic Dirty Harry character, ''Pink Cadillac'' will probably settle comfortably near the bottom of the list. It is the laziest sort of action comedy, with lumbering chase scenes, a dull-witted script and the charmless pairing of Mr. Eastwood and Bernadette Peters. Ms. Peters plays Lou Ann, the innocent wife of an ex-convict who belongs to a well-armed white supremacist group called the Birthright. When the group's cache of counterfeit money is found in her trailer, Lou Ann is arrested. Leaving her baby daughter with her sister, she gets in her husband's old pink Cadillac - which happens to be so full of hidden money that bills eventually fly out onto the highway - and jumps bail.

LEAD: Three weeks after protesting students chained shut its only building, the Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York celebrated its 25th commencement yesterday at Town Hall in midtown Manhattan.

LEAD: In Paul Giovanni's production for the Acting Company, ''Love's Labor's Lost,'' that most literate of Shakespearean comedies, has been turned into a tedious exercise in artifice. The documentary may be unintelligible to anyone who has not seen ''The Sacrifice'' and unilluminating to anyone who has, but it provides a wonderful excuse to see Tarkovsky's eloquent, lyrical, magnificent final film once more.
