LEAD: A fourth man was arrested in connection with an armored car robbery of $4.4 million in Clifton last year, and a father and son have admitted their guilt in the incident, authorities said yesterday.

LEAD: Japanese officials today accused the United States of a ''lack of fairness'' and said America was undermining international accords by threatening unilateral action against its trading partners.

LEAD: Neil Rolnick, a composer, and Gamelan Son of Lion, a contemporary music ensemble and composers' collective that performs on its own Western variety of gamelan instruments (bamboo xylophones and gongs), will perform new music by Mr. Rolnick tonight at 8 o'clock at Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

LEAD: Samuel R. Pierce, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in Ronald Reagan's Administration, acknowledged today that he shared the blame for lax supervision of a Federal housing program. But he suggested that former aides were responsible for political abuses uncovered in a recent audit.
LEAD: Tommy John's 700th career start had ended much as had his 699th and several before: earlier than he would have liked and less elegantly than perhaps the Yankees can continue to afford.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: D. Wayne Lukas thought Open Mind was not quite good enough to win the Kentucky Derby earlier this month, so he ran her instead in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies the day before, and she won.
LEAD: Navy officials are investigating two cracks in the outer steel hull of a nuclear submarine under construction at the Electric Boat shipyard in Groton, Conn., officials said today.

LEAD: For 50 hours this month and last, the 15 citizens drafting a new government for New York City worked in public sessions as fumbling and querulous, open and unpredictable as democracy itself. In front of hundreds of people, they fought over questions from representative government to revenue estimates.

LEAD: In the halcyon days of rail travel, when a train whistle signaled escape and adventure in a grand style, a fitting place to begin a journey was the Oyster Bar and Restaurant in majestic Grand Central Terminal. Rail travel has lost much of its romance over the years; so, too, has this once-classy landmark restaurant.
LEAD: The actor Martin Sheen, honorary mayor of this beach-front community of celebrities and surfers, declared Malibu a ''free-speech zone'' last week, but the place was already in an uproar.
LEAD: The Reader's Digest Association Inc., since 1922 one of the most private publishing companies in America, has decided to give the public a very modest stake in the form of a stock offering.
LEAD: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas investor and corporate raider, said today that the board of the Koito Manufacturing Company of Japan had denied his request for representation on its board.

LEAD: James Arthur Campbell, an educator, chemist and former dean of faculty at Harvey Mudd College in Claremont, Calif., died of Lou Gehrig's disease Monday at his home in Claremont, Calif. He was 72 years old.

LEAD: Alexander Calder was in many ways an ideal mix of homo faber and homo ludens. As homo faber - builder, engineer, master of stress and strain - he carried on as if he could have built the Brooklyn Bridge single-handed, had he been around at the time. As homo ludens - humorist, prankster and inventor of strange creatures - he was in a class of his own.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company has suspended production at its Edison, N.J., assembly plant for two weeks, the first time in six years the company has laid off workers at a United States plant to trim inventory.

LEAD: Leslie C. Overlock, an early marketing administrator in the photocopier business, died Monday at his home in Sun City, Ariz., where he had moved in 1985 from Greenwich, Conn. He was 69 years old.

LEAD: News coverage of an assault on a woman 16 years ago by a man who later became House Speaker Jim Wright's principal aide has prompted an ethical and journalistic debate over publishing such an article. At issue is the propriety of delving into the criminal past of a person after his apparent rehabilitation and doing so at a time when the disclosure would be particularly damaging to Mr.

LEAD: Gary Susnjara resigned yesterday as president and chief operating officer of Saatchi & Saatchi DFS to pursue a career as an independent consultant.
LEAD: Zigmas Vaisvila was working in a physics institute in the Lithuanian capital last year when the Soviet Communist Party approved a new electoral system.
LEAD: With Democrats now considering it certain that House Speaker Jim Wright will resign from Congress, attention turned today to when he will leave and who will succeed him.

LEAD: Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet,'' set to Prokofiev's ballet score, was always a crowd pleaser when the Royal Ballet brought it from Britain, beginning in 1965. And a shrewdly programmed crowd pleaser it has remained since American Ballet Theater staged it in 1985.

LEAD: The Association of National Advertisers announced a slate of promotions yesterday, naming Daniel L. Jaffe executive vice president; Peter F. Eder and E. Clark Holt senior vice presidents, and Frank J. Mortensen and Renee E. Paley vice presidents. In his new job, Mr. Jaffe will head the A.N.A.'s Washington office.
LEAD: Armenak (Albert) Mardirossian, a real-estate developer and philanthropist, died of a stroke Monday at Passaic (N.J.) General Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Clifton, N.J.

LEAD: Taking strong action on an issue that has divided his Cabinet and threatens new trade friction, President Bush today named Japan, India and Brazil as unfair traders, subjecting them to special negotiations and possible sanctions if their import barriers are not lowered. The decision incensed the foreign governments.
LEAD: Alamo Rent A Car Inc., the nation's fifth-largest car-rental company, has named Charles D. Platt president and chief operating officer.

LEAD: Doug Drabek pitched six solid innings to snap his losing streak at five games, and the Pittsburgh Pirates extended their longest winning streak of the season to four games tonight with a 7-3 victory over the slumping Atlanta Braves.

LEAD: Bankruptcy court hearings on a proposal to allow Hasbro Inc. to buy most of ailing Coleco Industries for more than $85 million have been adjourned until next Wednesday. A Coleco lawyer, Daniel Golden, said all pending matters will be taken up then in United States Bankruptcy Court in New York.

LEAD: Considerable good or great evil can come out of the speech on the Middle East delivered by Secretary of State James A. Baker this week. To a large extent the choice will rest with him and the President he serves.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation formally settled a trademark infringement lawsuit filed against it last summer by Fabbrica d'Armi Pietro Beretta S.p.A., the Italian gun maker. In a ceremony held in Italy and attended by each company's chairman, G.M. contributed $500,000 to a Beretta cancer foundation and exchanged a Chevrolet Beretta GTU coupe for a

LEAD: The Southmark Corporation completed the sale of the Parker & Parsley Petroleum Company, an oil and gas syndication concern, for about $49.6 million in cash to Parker & Parsley Development Partners L.P. The acquiring partnership includes Parker & Parsley's management and the JM Petroleum Corporation, a Dallas-based affiliate of the Wesray Capital

LEAD: A surgeon saved a gunshot victim's life Thursday by plugging the bullet holes in his heart with her fingers and massaging the heart to keep it beating in a 14-minute helicopter ride to a trauma center.

LEAD: Carl Lewis, a six-time Olympic gold medal winner, and a group of other American Olympic medalists in track and field say they plan to boycott the national outdoor championships next month at the University of Houston to express their unhappiness with The Athletics Congress, the governing body of track and field in this country.

LEAD: West German politicians said today that the governing coalition was torn by a bitter struggle over its stand on short-range nuclear weapons. Chancellor Helmut Kohl emerged so politically isolated, they said, that a compromise with Washington at the NATO summit meeting was no longer considered feasible.
LEAD: Like a good five-cent cigar, a good million-dollar teacher is very hard to get these days.
LEAD: A front-page headline in some editions yesterday about charges of sexual assault against a group of high school football players in Glen Ridge, N.J., misstated the nature of the case.
LEAD: In 1925, Fabiana Ghigliani's grandfather left Italy for Argentina, a land of hope in the New World.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A Montana fishing guide and his client got a bill this week from the United States Forest Service, along with a pre-addressed envelope. The service wanted reimbursement for the cost of fighting a fire last fall in southern Montana.
LEAD: A court today upheld the Government's ban on the broadcasting of interviews with members of militant groups in Northern Ireland.
LEAD: The Sungene Technologies Corporation of San Jose, Calif., won patent approval for a recipe of nutrients to help breed higher-yielding corn.
LEAD: There was a time when gasoline buyers needed only to tell the attendant to ''fill 'er up,'' regular or high-test, and then pay the amount shown on the pump.

LEAD: As the Philippines awaits the death of Ferdinand E. Marcos, the nation is consumed with what some are calling ''necropolitics,'' a morbid mixture of squabbling and expiation so intricate that it needs a psychoanalyst or a priest to unravel.

LEAD: Sunday Silence, who will try to become the first Triple Crown winner in 11 years when he runs in the Belmont Stakes on June 10, worked three furlongs in 37 2/5 seconds at Belmont Park this morning. It was the colt's first workout since winning the Preakness Stakes last Saturday. Sunday Silence is expected to face between 5 and 10 opponents in the Belmont, led by Easy Goer, the Derby and Preakness runner-up.
LEAD: A temporary bridge across the swollen Great Miami River collapsed today and as many as four cars fell into the flood waters. The occupants of the cars were feared dead.

LEAD: For much of six years, James Reginald Jarvis lived in a cave in Inwood Hill Park at the northern edge of Manhattan with his prized possessions: a sleeping bag, a collection of rocks and fossils and sheet music of sonatas by Bach and Beethoven.

LEAD: Clearing the way for work to begin on the Government's huge new telephone system, the Federal Communications Commission yesterday rejected charges by the MCI Communications Corporation that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had set prices below cost to win a multibillion contract to build the network.
LEAD: Poison ivy is reaching its full leaf stage now. When all the leaves are open, kill it but don't touch it.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Arab League ended a four-day summit meeting today without persuading Syria to withdraw its 40,000 soldiers from Lebanon.

LEAD: The Majority Leader of the State Senate will inform Gov. Mario M. Cuomo next week that Israel Ruiz Jr., a Bronx Democrat, convicted in February on a Federal felony count, is no longer a member of the Senate, an aide said yesterday.

LEAD: The Harris Corporation exercised its option to buy the 50 percent interest held by the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company in a joint venture, Harris/3M Document Products Inc. Harris said it had paid about $190 milllion.

LEAD: ''I love elections,'' a former Irish Prime Minister, Garret FitzGerald, confessed this morning as he hurried into the Georgian parliament building, where he is a member of the opposition. ''It's the dull parts in between I can't stand.''

LEAD: The reason that newspapers will always print animal stories is because they distract from all the news about nasty things men and women do to each other day in and day out. Accordingly, today's column rambles from cemeteries to saloons, ferreting out the mysteries of dwarf rabbits, loving cats, tropical birds and the odd tarantula.

LEAD: A literature professor accused of making sexual advances to a male graduate student will take early retirement because of a growing controversy over Princeton University's handling of the matter, his lawyer said today.

LEAD: A farm tractor pulling a wagon loaded with wedding guests fell into a canal today, killing 13 people, a news report said. About 30 people were riding on the tractor or in the wagon near West Godavari, about 825 miles southeast of New Delhi, the United News of India said. Among the dead were three children.

LEAD: The National Steel Company, the nation's sixth-largest steel producer, said yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement with the United Steelworkers of America on a 50-month contract that would raise wages and benefits by about 12 percent over the period.

LEAD: Peter S. Kalikow, owner and publisher of The New York Post, dismissed his top editor, Jane Amsterdam, in a meeting late Thursday afternoon, persons close to each of them, who asked not to be identified, said yesterday.

LEAD: ''The Last Fair on Earth: The New York World's Fair, 1939/40'' will open on Thursday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. The exhibition, running through Nov. 11, features 100 photographs and letters, posters, drawings, blueprints and memorabilia from the fair. Admission is free.
LEAD: A grand jury in Rockford, Ill., has refused to indict a woman accused of causing the death of her newborn baby by using cocaine before she gave birth.

LEAD: Czechoslovakia expelled three British diplomats and a businessman today in what the Foreign Office called an unjustified retaliation for the recent expulsion of four Czechoslovaks from Britain.

LEAD: With Prime Minister Li Peng apparently winning China's power struggle, documents criticizing his rival, Zhao Ziyang, have been circulated among senior officials, evidently in preparation for a formal decision to dismiss Mr. Zhao as Communist Party leader.

LEAD: Less than two weeks after relinquishing its independence to the WPP Group, the Ogilvy Group lost another battle yesterday when Kraft General Foods dropped Ogilvy & Mather as its advertising agency for Maxwell House coffee and gave the account to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/ New York.
LEAD: The Bank of New York is transferring its mutual-fund shareholder accounting services to American Transtech, a unit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ''Relax!'' Andy Kahnle yelled at a thrashing striped bass as he plucked it from a huge net in the Hudson River, 97 miles above New York Harbor.

LEAD: The New York Philharmonic's final subscription program of the year offered Zubin Mehta in music of the kind for which his affinities have generally been considered strongest: orchestral excerpts from Wagner and a big Strauss tone poem.

LEAD: The Cincinnati Reds manager, Pete Rose, is facing allegations that he was involved in gambling on the very sport he played and coached for so many years. It is even alleged that he bet on his own team.

LEAD: Tom Benson, the owner of the New Orleans Saints, said yesterday that he had reluctantly given permission for the National Football League search committee to talk to Jim Finks, the general manager of the Saints. The action confirms that Finks is on the final list of candidates to replace Pete Rozelle as league commissioner.
LEAD: Two Japanese companies are beginning an English-language service that reports and analyzes all new patent applications in Japan.
LEAD: A few hours before President Bush arrived tonight for a two-day visit, Italian leaders took tentative steps to put their crumbled Government back together again.
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would idle its Wayne, Mich., assembly plant for one week to trim the number of unsold Ford Escort subcompact cars.
LEAD: The Soviet Union today struggled to give birth to a new kind of government in a process that laid bare bitter divisions of class, geography, nationality and outlook.

LEAD: When Jose Carreras, the Spanish tenor, walked onto the Carnegie Hall stage Thursday night, he received a standing ovation, complete with a ''Jose Carreras Society of America'' banner, before he had uttered a note.
LEAD: Government troops and leftist guerrillas clashed early today in some of the heaviest fighting in the capital in several years.

LEAD: Some 1,000 celebrators will gather at the Worthington Hotel tonight for a gala dinner opening the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition. But it's a good bet that most of the 38 contestants will make their way home to bed early. That's because the serious competing in the important quadrennial event is to begin at 9:30 A.M.

LEAD: The 27th annual U.J.A.-Federation Charity tournament played Thursday night at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, had one important difference from previous years. As usual, the efforts of Tubby Stayman and her committee raised more than $50,000 for Jewish charities. And as usual, there were some 50 experts taking part, many of them owning national and international titles, each playing in an impromptu partnership.
LEAD: Researchers at the Stanford University Medical Center in Palo Alto, Calif., have patented a new method of preventing jaundice in newborn babies.

LEAD: In a testament to China's economic liberalization, the streets of this city are clogged with merchants of all sorts - young men displaying gold necklaces or earrings, elderly women selling five-flavored tea-soaked eggs.

LEAD: After months of vigorous and competing marketing efforts, the nation's two largest commodity exchanges have decided to try to cooperate in their development of after-hours electronic trading systems, the exchanges announced yesterday.

LEAD: ''Ushers Onstage,'' a free show featuring performers who also work as ushers at Lincoln Center, is to take place on June 8 at Alice Tully Hall, 66th Street and Broadway, at 7:30 P.M. The performers - singers, pianists, dancers and a guitarist - were selected at a juried audition. Tickets are available at Alice Tully Hall box office.
LEAD: Representative Donald E. Lukens, Republican of Ohio, was convicted today in a case in which prosecutors said he had sex with a 16-year-old girl.
LEAD: The United States trade deficit improved sharply in the first three months of the year, narrowing to $27.6 billion, the smallest quarterly imbalance in four years.
LEAD: If Rick Pitino decides to remain as the Knicks' coach, all he has to do is say so.

LEAD: It was 2 A.M. in the nearly empty bar of the Majestic Hotel, many hours after the close of the 42d Cannes International Film Festival on Tuesday night, though the night hadn't ended. The center of attention at a corner table was Steven Soderbergh, the 26-year-old American who had just become the youngest director ever to win the festival's top award, the Palme d

LEAD: It's time for picnics again, and if you are preparing the fixings from scratch it pays to know how much chicken for chicken salad you can expect to strip from the carcass of a typical broiler or fryer and how many sandwiches a can of tuna will make. Salads can be stretched by adding diced vegetables, cucumbers, celery, peppers and tomatoes.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a pipeline explosion in San Bernardino, Calif., carried inconsistent references in some editions to the parent company of the Calnev Pipeline Company. It is the GATX Corporation, not the Union Pacific Corporation.

LEAD: Researchers at the University of Houston said yesterday that they had developed a superconducting equivalent of an electronic transistor, a crucial step toward building superconducting computers and other electronic equipment.

LEAD: Ben Johnson's personal physician today named eight substances that athletes are using routinely to hide the presence of anabolic steroids in their systems. A leading American expert in sports medicine said that current technology may not be sophisticated enough for laboratories to detect two of them.

LEAD: After singing for more than 50 years, Anita O'Day has arrived at a peak in her career as she approaches her 70th birthday. At Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, where she will be singing through June 17, she is drawing on her repertory and experience, including her scintillating years with Gene Krupa's orchestra..
LEAD: Dr. Morris Neiman, an educator and author, died from complications of cancer surgery Thursday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived in Rego Park, Queens.

LEAD: Patricia Anne Engel, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander R. Engel of Greenwood Lake, N.Y., and Paul Joseph McGoldrick, a son of Mrs. Charles G. Tierney of Pelham, N.Y., and the late Warren P. McGoldrick, were married yesterday at the Davenport Shore Club in New Rochelle, N.Y., by Mayor Joseph E.

LEAD: Andris Liepa and Leslie Browne looked splendidly and desperately in love in American Ballet Theater's ''Romeo and Juliet'' Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Would that this kind of emotional rapport existed in every performance of Sir Kenneth MacMillan's three-act version of Shakespeare's tragedy.
LEAD: Three Canadian inventors have developed a $50 device to help scuba divers accurately monitor their rate of ascent to the surface.

LEAD: There is a new joke around here that Jiang Qing, the widow of Mao Zedong, has asked to be released from the prison where she is serving a life sentence for crimes during the Cultural Revolution.

LEAD: A high school senior told a school official about the sexual assault of a 17-year-old mildly retarded girl here within two days of its occurrence on March 1, a lawyer for the student said today.

LEAD: President Mengistu Haile Mariam has named new armed forces commanders to replace those killed last week in an abortive coup, the Government radio announced. Diplomats say nearly the entire military high command was killed in the three-day revolt and the subsequent purge here.
LEAD: A South African judge today sentenced 14 blacks to hang for the murder of a black policeman in the rural town of Upington three and a half years ago.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: State police officers cracking down on speeders over the holiday weekend are confronting the force of public habit: most motorists across the New York metropolitan region appear to be ignoring the 55-mile-an-hour speed limit.
LEAD: The United States' decision to name Japan as an unfair trading partner does some immediate damage but could bring long-term benefits to the overall relationship between Tokyo and Washington.

LEAD: Rules governing the use of New York City parks that were found to be ''mean spirited'' and ''misguided'' last month by advocates for the homeless have been rewritten by the Parks and Recreation Department.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Chuck Finley, whose best game in 43 previous major-league starts was a five-hitter, held Boston hitless until Jody Reed's looping single with two out in the eighth inning tonight as he pitched the California Angels to a one-hit, 5-0 victory over Roger Clemens and the Red Sox.
LEAD: * Andrews Group Inc. said it had received commitments from Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. to provde financing to buy New World Entertainment Ltd., for $8.95 a share.
LEAD: A Manhattan jury yesterday convicted an East Harlem minister of rape and other sexual attacks on three church members.
LEAD: ''I want to give my party a chance to move on.'' - Representative Tony Coelho. [ 1:6. ]

LEAD: The Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers and the League of Resident Theaters have broken off talks on a contract, and the society announced that beginning today it would withhold its members' services from plays at league theaters across the country that have not begun rehearsals.
LEAD: An obituary on Wednesday about William J. Hampton, an aide to the late Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., misidentified a surviving daughter. She is Gail McKeller.
LEAD: The death of a Queens man in police custody, which sparked two days of angry protests, was caused by ''acute cocaine intoxication,'' the Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

LEAD: For a woman who the night before had been likened unflatteringly to Napoleon's Empress Josephine on nationwide television, Raisa Maksimovna Gorbachev was showing no signs of post-glasnost depression this morning.
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

LEAD: Eight years ago, after a court found that downstate real property taxes were being improperly calculated, Albany imposed temporary fixes in order to avoid painful choices. Now it is about to approve yet another temporary fix, but has an opportunity to do so in a more constructive way.
LEAD: The New York Philharmonic's 25th season of free parks concerts in New York City and Suffolk, Nassau and Westchester Counties will begin on July 24 on Central Park's Great Lawn at 8 P.M.

LEAD: Following a script as stylized and deliberate as Noh drama, the Administration has accused Japan of unfairly restricting imports of three major American products - and cited Brazil and India for three other offenses. The decision was an awkward straddle to placate Congressional protectionists without overly offending the Japanese in particular.
LEAD: Marion Pierce Mack, vice chairwoman of the Westchester County Republican Committee for 33 years, died yesterday at a nursing home in Rockport, Mass. She was 94 years old and lived in Rockport.

LEAD: When they rolled out the red carpet Thursday night and carried the Stanley Cup across it to center ice, it was the ingenue Calgary Flames rather than the venerable Montreal Canadiens who were left alone on the Forum ice to claim it.

LEAD: The Thermo Electron Corporation said it had acquired a 5.9 percent stake in the Milton Roy Company and was interested in acquiring the St. Petersburg, Fla., concern. Milton Roy's stock jumped $1.125 today, to $17.625 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. With 5.6 million shares outstanding, Milton
LEAD: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has begun to reassign the extra border patrol agents who were sent to Brownsville, Tex., in February to stem a surge of illegal aliens.
LEAD: Representative Tony Coelho's decision to leave Congress rather than face a siege of questioning over his finances dramatizes the extraordinary climate in Washington on the issue of ethics.
LEAD: We went to a commencement.

LEAD: A graduate student has filed suit in Federal District Court against the new anti-discrimination policy of the University of Michigan, which the student contends violates his First Amendment right to discuss his research ideas in class.

LEAD: A 57-year-old police inspector was promoted to deputy chief yesterday, making him the highest-ranking Hispanic officer in the New York City Police Department and the first person of Puerto Rican descent ever named a chief.
LEAD: June Watkins, a former actress who was active in civic and political affairs, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Providence, R.I. She was 73 years old.
LEAD: The International Monetary Fund approved $4.08 billion in loans to Mexico late today, officials of the fund said. Most of the money was tentatively approved last month.

LEAD: Safety specialists generally agree that safety information given on airplanes is boring, that most people do not pay attention and that even if they did they still might not know what to do in an emergency.
LEAD: A section of gasoline pipeline that ruptured in a fatal explosion Thursday was not checked for damage after a runaway train plowed across it two weeks earlier, the line's owner said today.

LEAD: In the largest purchase ever of a credit card business, the Chase Manhattan Corporation is buying about 1.2 million Visa and Mastercard accounts with more than $1.1 billion of outstanding debts from the Michigan National Corporation.

LEAD: The students in Beijing appear to have lost to the aging Deng Xiaoping and his colorless, hard-line protege, Prime Minister Li Peng. But it's far from certain that the defeat is permanent; whether the students have truly won or lost will only be determined when Mr. Deng departs and a new leadership emerges.
LEAD: The people at Farberware Inc. have taken a hard look at the cup of coffee, and say they have discovered a better way to brew it.

LEAD: The Bronx woman who was charged with throwing her 2-year-old daughter to her death Wednesday night and her husband, who was charged with abusing the child and her two siblings, were depicted by city caseworkers three months ago as a ''strong and motivated'' couple.
LEAD: India today assailed Washington's decision to place the country on a list of unfair traders.

LEAD: Broadway between 72d and 79th Streets will be closed from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. today for the Spring Festival. Second Avenue between 42d and 53d Streets will be closed from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. tomorrow for the Turtle Bay Fair.
LEAD: An article on May 11 about the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition misstated the location of Youri Egorov's 1978 debut concert in New York. It was Alice Tully Hall, not Carnegie Hall.
LEAD: A mother who abandoned her newborn daughter in a jetliner's restroom before a cross-country flight has pleaded no contest to charges of child endangerment.
LEAD: The Toronto Blue Jays will offer Lou Piniella their managing job, if they receive permission from George Steinbrenner to do so.
LEAD: At the gasoline pump this summer, the oil companies will have the upper hand. But experts say smart shoppers can limit the damage to their wallets.
LEAD: SCS Communications, a company owned by Stephen C. Swid, has acquired a controlling interest in SPIN magazine with an investment of $4 million in the four-year-old publication.
LEAD: The majority of Americans would like to retire early, but few have done the serious retirement planning that would enable them to do so comfortably, a survey by Merrill Lynch & Company shows.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: American writers will read from their own works on three evenings in June at the Poetry Center of the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, to benefit the American Foundation for AIDS Research.

LEAD: Japan said today that it would refuse to negotiate trade issues with the United States while American officials ''brandished the threat of unilateral sanctions'' against trading partners who did not accede to their demands.
LEAD: The Salonika Bay Murder Cold War Politics and the Polk Affair By Edmund Keeley Illustrated. 395 pages. Princeton University Press. $24.95.

LEAD: Responding to American accusations of unfair trade practices, Brazilian officials said today that import barriers allowed the nation to build up a surplus that in turn helped it to make payments on its large foreign debt.

LEAD: Stena Holding A.B., a Swedish ferry operator, and Tiphook P.L.C., a British container-rental company, offered yesterday to pay $50 a share, or $815 million, for Sea Containers Ltd., a Bermuda company with interests in containers and British ferries.

LEAD: Therese Marie Barr, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Stevans Barr of Farmington, Conn., and Robert Adam Schrecengost, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Eugene Schrecengost of North Huntington, Pa., were married last evening at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Farmington. The Rev. Thomas M. Ginty officiated.

LEAD: Frederick G. Fisher, a Boston lawyer who in 1954 became a target of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy at a dramatic turning point in hearings involving the Senator and the Army, died of a heart attack Thursday in Tel Aviv, Israel. Mr. Fisher, 68 years old, was at a lecture sponsored by the Israeli bar.
LEAD: The United States Mint has inadvertently struck a new collector's item: an unknown number of 1989 quarters with no mint mark.
LEAD: On the next-to-last day of the Giants' minicamp, Coach Bill Parcells came up with a mini-report card.

LEAD: The ''At the Bar'' column on the Law page yesterday discussed lawyers' use of advertising, legalized 10 years ago. Describing the use of newspaper ads by some kinds of law firms, it said: ''One will never see Sullivan & Cromwell alongside the bartending schools or high school equivalency courses. Most are personal-injury firms, whose names, like Longi & Loscalzo or Gersowitz & Libo, seem lifted from the log at Ellis Island rather than the pages of Martindale-Hubbell.
LEAD: A jury's libel award of $960,000 against Private Eye, the satirical British magazine, this week has prompted the Government to undertake a review of defamation law.

LEAD: Joe Clark, the principal known for his tough disciplinary measures, has been hospitalized and is scheduled to undergo open-heart surgery, officials said today. Mr. Clark, the principal of Paterson's Eastside High School, was admitted Wednesday to Beth Israel Hospital in Newark, said Vincent Fusco, his personal manager.

LEAD: Representative Tony Coelho of California, the No. 3 Democrat in the House and the leading contender to become majority leader, said today that he was resigning from Congress rather than put his party and his colleagues through a protracted investigation of his personal finances.

LEAD: Ralph Winsor, chairman of Curtice-Burns Inc., a food processing company based in Rochester, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Thursday at his dairy farm in Harpursville, N.Y. He was 53 years old.

LEAD: In a gesture both to American allies and to Moscow, President Bush is expected to act next week to remove the remaining economic sanctions imposed on the Soviet Union after its military intervention in Afghanistan 10 years ago, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: Interest rates continued to slide yesterday as prices of short- and long-term Treasury securities rose in an abbreviated pre-holiday weekend session.
LEAD: A man convicted of killing a widow and stealing her Christmas presents was executed in Alabama's electric chair early today after the United States Supreme Court denied his appeal.

LEAD: A sailor under investigation in the explosion aboard the battleship Iowa said today, in his first public appearance since being linked to the blast, that he had nothing to do with it and that he was the victim of a Navy ''looking for a possible scapegoat.''
LEAD: Mark Langston said yesterday that the Seattle Mariners tried to sign him to a new contract minutes before trading him to the Montreal Expos on Thursday night.

LEAD: YACHTING Trimaran Staggers to Mark: The crippled trimaran Great American sailed through the Golden Gate Bridge yesterday, breaking a three-month-old New York-to-San Francisco sailing record by three days after an exhausting 77-day, 14,500-mile voyage. The Great American crossed the finish an hour short of 77 days after departing New York for the arduous journey round Cape Horn.

LEAD: Ever since an eclectic religious colony settled on the edge of Yellowstone Park in 1981 and began developing a scenic valley into a thriving community, its members have found themselves at odds with neighboring park officials, environmentalists and townspeople.

LEAD: Eugene J. Keogh, who as a Congressman from Brooklyn was the principal sponsor of the pension-plan legislation that bears his name, died of pneumonia yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Stockholders and directors of United Artists Communications Inc. and the United Cable Television Corporation approved the merger of the two companies to form the United Artists Entertainment Company. The merger makes United Artists Entertainment the nation's third-largest operator of cable television systems and the largest motion-picture theater operator.
LEAD: The joke about the driver who made a dozen pit stops at the Indianapolis 500 to ask for directions is not as absurd as it sounds, once you talk to Scott Pruett.

LEAD: Jon Peters, who set the national high school record of 51 consecutive victories last month, lost his first game as a scholastic pitcher Thursday night when West Orange-Stark of Texas beat Brenham, 3-0, on a no-hitter.
LEAD: Since the National Basketball Association playoffs began, the Los Angeles Lakers have never been better.
LEAD: The Honda Motor Company will replace its top executive in North America at the end of June.

LEAD: John L. Jeffers Jr., a senior partner in the law firm of Baker & Botts in Houston who was a leading lawyer in the Pennzoil Company's successful court battle against Texaco Inc., died of complications arising from a brain tumor at Methodist Hospital in Houston Thursday. He was 46 years old.

LEAD: If adversity builds characater, the Mets built a pile of it today.

LEAD: Kazuko Takatsukasa, the elder sister of Emperor Akihito, died of heart failure at a Tokyo hospital early today, Imperial Palace officials said. She was 59 years old. Mrs. Takatsukasa was the third daughter of the late Emperor Hirohito, Japan's longest-reigning monarch, who died on Jan. 7.
LEAD: His career with the Oakland Athletics has been short, his roles varied. Todd Burns has pitched long relief, middle relief, as a spot starter and as an occasional closer.

LEAD: President Bush arrived here tonight for the start of a weeklong European trip, emphasizing that ''new challenges and unparalleled opportunities'' face the Western alliance in view of Soviet initiatives.

LEAD: There are those who still associate Milwaukee with that script writer's concoction - the beer, brats and bowling mecca of the ''Laverne and Shirley'' television show. But people familiar with the real Milwaukee know it as a city in transition, from a quiet, conservative factory town to a lively, diverse, cosmopolitan city.

LEAD: Some have said that high definition television is simply a problem for the computer industry to solve by sending digital information over a fiber optics highway. This could not be farther from the truth. No one industry, technology, or company can meet the challenge of HDTV - not even the computer industry.

LEAD: GEORGE BERNARD SHAW wrote much that was dramatic, but not everything he wrote was theatrical. A case in point is ''In the Beginning,'' the current production at Long Island Stage in Rockville Centre.

LEAD: Your article on John Silber is aptly titled, but what is he crusading for? Excellence, he says, and he frankly embraces elitism. But people who are truly wise (Einstein, Dostoyevsky, Rembrandt, for example) are compassionate. As the Greeks understood, there is no wisdom (sophia) without compassion (aidos).

LEAD: SOME DEMOCRATIC members of the Senate Judiciary Committee suspected that the Bush Justice Department was applying an ''ideological litmus test'' to its judicial nominations, and demanded that several nominees 'fess up to the kind of questioning they had undergone before being offered the jobs.

LEAD: Chamber Sound, an ensemble of young freelance instrumentalists who have been working together in various combinations for eight years, played an interesting program of comparatively light rarities and meatier standard repertory works Tuesday evening at Weill Recital Hall. One could not have asked for livelier or more expertly turned performances.

LEAD: The graphic violence in the comics discussed by Joe Queenan is of less importance than the violence that exists in comics of even the most mundane, newspaper variety. If a door-to-door salesman is obnoxious, Dagwood kicks him away, and the police are never involved. Dagwood's boss pummels him, although in real life the boss would then be on the wrong end of a lawsuit.

LEAD: IN February 1986 the State Department of Transportation began what was supposed to be 14 months of repair to a bridge on Route 12 at the southern edge of Jewett City. But the job went on for almost 40 months, and businesses watched as not only traffic from nearby Interstate 395 dwindled, but also their profits.

This is the fastest field ever assembled. Only a few years ago, a qualifying speed of 212 m.p.h. won the pole; now such a speed will not make the field.

LEAD: The little pellets first appeared on the West Coast in the early 1980's, the product of brilliant marketing. Someone figured out how to boil down powdered cocaine into crystals that could be smoked rather than snorted. Inhaling this ''crack'' gives a brief, intense high - followed by a crash that leaves the user desperate for more.

LEAD: Amnesia has reached a new high. When George Bush was Republican Party chairman during the Watergate days, he could not recall any Nixon wrongdoing. Now he cannot remember having been ''in the loop'' of the Iran-contra affair. The current G.O.P. national chairman, Lee Atwater, can't recall any of his past racist or anti-Semitic smears.

LEAD: In May 1969, a couple of months before man's first lunar landing, Mario Andretti drove into Victory Lane at the Indianapolis 500 for the first time. For 20 years, the Moon has been the easier return trip.
LEAD: Rick Sutcliffe was paying as much attention to the Bulls as he was to the Reds.

LEAD: SPORTING the sort of smiles not often seen on a Monday morning, people with various shapes and personalities descend upon the Cross County Square Mall here. They are not here to eat, although they might sneak in some coffee, and they are not here to browse, although they cannot avoid window shopping.

LEAD: IT MAY NOT YET BE AS POPULAR as, say, arena football, but according to Sorin Balaianu, you can bank on it: foot tennis is coming to your neighborhood. Balaianu, once a Rumanian national wrestling champion, is now the executive director of the International Foot Tennis Federation, a governing body based in Phoenix whose stated purpose is to organize and sanction ''recreational and professional tournaments throughout the world.

LEAD: A June wedding is planned by Peg Tyre and Peter Blauner, the parents of the bride-to-be, Thomas E. Tyre of Mohegan Lake, N.Y., and Frances Tyre of Ossining, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Blauner is a son of Sheila Druckman of New York and Greenwich, Conn.

LEAD: IN frequent-flier programs, 1988 was the year of triple mileage, when many participants were spending weekends bouncing around on short trips to ''earn'' two first-class tickets to Europe or Asia. This year will probably be the year the airlines experienced a hangover and began to cut back on frequent travel programs.

LEAD: FIFTEEN years ago, a Democratic Congress forced a Republican President from power, striking a blow against what had come to be called ''the Imperial Presidency.'' Ever since, Republicans have bemoaned the rise of what they called ''the Imperial Congress.''
LEAD: The chief of the Connecticut State Lottery was dismissed Friday after he refused to recommend a change in the state's Lotto game that will reduce a bettor's chances of winning.

LEAD: Teachers are notorious for inflating grades (''Schools Say Inflated Grades Cut Grants,'' May 7). Nowadays, in most schools the ''good'' students are almost always given A's, the ''mediocre'' students B's and the ''poor'' students almost never less than C's, despite their dubious achievements.

Mrs. Eckerson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Holz of Camden, is a graduate of Connecticut College. She is a production associate in Boston for Bulfinch Press/Little, Brown & Company.

LEAD: Someone once asked Harry Waugh, the grand old man of the English wine trade, how long it had been since he'd mistaken a Bordeaux wine for a Burgundy. ''How long is it since lunch?'' he replied. No single part of wine lore is more beset by myth and misinformation than the vague area of wine tasting.
LEAD: I NEVER thought I'd get married, but a few years ago I met the type of man no one believes still exists. And so, at 40, I'm taking the plunge.
LEAD: Stephen Sell, executive director of the Philadelphia Orchestra since 1982, died of lung cancer Friday at Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 47 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

LEAD: REPORTS IN RECENT MONTHS about the high rate of ''false negatives'' for Pap smears were frightening to women. A false negative, in medical lingo, is a screening test that says ''no cancer'' when all the while a cancer is, in fact, growing undetected. Pap smears, which can detect cancer of the cervix, are now said to have a false negative rate of 20 to 40 percent.

LEAD: Role models are useful up to a point. It's good to be able to note that Eddie Murphy, Bill Cosby, Oprah Winfrey and Michael Jackson are among the biggest personalities in American show business today. However, what effect have these individual success stories had on the lives of the members of America's black underclass?

LEAD: A wave of nationalism in Sind, Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's home province, is putting new pressure on her Government and giving her political opponents opportunities in a region where they have never been strong.
LEAD: WHEN Le Coq Hardi, the stylish French restaurant near Town Hall in Ridgefield, metamorphosed into La Cave in mid-February, it did more than just change its name. It changed its entire persona.

LEAD: Ever since he was a boy growing up in Amarillo, Tex., Dennis Hedlund has had a passion for the classics, relying on television programs like those showing Leonard Bernstein's concerts for his early cultural enrichment.

LEAD: Contrary to the expectations of Carl Lewis, the Olympic gold medalists Louise Ritter, Roger Kingdom and Evelyn Ashford, along with the middle-distance runner Steve Scott, plan to compete in the Mobil championships in Houston.

LEAD: It would appear that we now have a brand-new, shiny, politico-cultural Hula Hoop with which to do our academic-artistic gyrations: anti-Eurocentrism.

Robert Campbell has a mouthful to say about a chump like that, and in JUICE (Poseidon, $18.95) he says it with grand panache, in the colorful patois of Hollywood ''gamooshes'' and ''juicemen.

LEAD: Thousands of homes were without power in Putnam and Dutchess counties after lightning struck a power station in Fishkill during a rainstorm. More than 22,000 homes lost their electricity Friday at about 9:15 P.M.

LEAD: SEVILLE is not just a great city of the past. It is the vibrant modern center of western Andalusia, as the traffic and the crowds make plain. Situated in one of the most fertile provinces of Spain, the Guadalquivir River that flows through it was navigable until the last century. The university thrives, as it has done for centuries, and during the school year students throng the city center and fill the bars with noise as the young have done since the days when Muslims ruled, when the students, merchants and tourists of those days first crowded the avenues.

LEAD: NOT very long ago early June was intermission time in Westchester: the spring season was over, and summer events had not yet started. Only sporadic musicales broke the performing silence. No longer. Next weekend will bring two festival openings; chamber, choral and orchestral concerts; jazz and even flamenco.

LEAD: The impending shake-up of the Democratic leadership in the House has set off intense jockeying for the top three positions, coveted posts that are critical to the fortunes of the party, its agenda and the careers of the members.
LEAD: Are horse races getting too fast? Are basketball players jumping too high? Are baseball players hitting the ball too far?

LEAD: In 1987 and again last year, Suffolk County residents agreed to a quarter-cent increase in their sales tax so that the county could buy thousands of acres of Long Island's most ecologically sensitive land, the Pine Barrens.
LEAD: The 6 percent turnout for the recent school board elections in New York City was far below the participation in school elections in many other cities, officials elsewhere say.

LEAD: Like furry animals emerging from a long hibernation, adults and children alike are rediscovering the process of moving their limbs.

LEAD: IN warm weather, thousands of homeless people move from winter shelters to a more pleasant refuge in the city parks. In March the city proposed new park rules that, at the least, implied they were not welcome.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Herrick of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Jo Herrick, to Jeffrey Stuart Mahan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Mahan of Baltimore. An August wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: APRIL 17, 1989: Sporadic shelling this morning. I drive home from my office at midday with a 25-liter canister of gasoline for my electric generator. Just moments after I pass the state-run Lebanese University, a mortar shell strikes the campus. The blast causes my car to wobble, but I make it home to my apartment building on the rue Bachir al-Kassar, in West Beirut.
LEAD: NEW YORK CITY'S plan for mandatory recycling of some garbage is causing widespread grumbling among landlords and managers of commercial property.

LEAD: The conflict between Israelis and Palestinians is stoked by fear: mutual fear. We at a distance know that as a generality, as we know it of Northern Ireland or any inter-communal conflict. But we cannot really know the blinding personal intensity of the emotion.
LEAD: Some rustic gift baskets brimming with fruits, flowers and confections must be hand-delivered; they're too delicate, their maker believes, to encase in shrink-wrap and ship cross-country.
LEAD: FOR at least one Rutgers senior, the road to graduation may have been unorthodox, but it represented a victory that was almost unthinkable a few years ago.

LEAD: It has been 150 years since photography, that most literal of image-making media, appeared on the scene. To say that it has changed the way we view the world and ourselves is perhaps an understatement; photography has transformed our essential understanding of reality and, in the process, transformed itself.

LEAD: LIGHT, by Michael I. Sobel. (University of Chicago, $14.95.) A physicist shows that understanding light can lead to an appreciation of every level of the universe, from atoms to animals to stars. The author ''is a popularizer in the best sense, the expert witness clearly and concisely explaining complex concepts,'' James Cornell said here in 1987.

LEAD: In my doctoral dissertation, on baseball batting slumps, I am studying the precise details of optimal performance states - ''the zone'' (''Finding 'The Zone,' '' by Lawrence Shainberg, April 9). We know that athletes are able to reach the zone with simple stimulus-response patterns, such as the snapping of one's fingers.

As a result, it was impossible to see much of ''Bennington in New York,'' the program presented Monday night at the Twining Gallery by three alumni of the dance department of Bennington College in Vermont.

It took several days to clear the virus from the computers, but it has taken longer to take care of the rest of the matter.

LEAD: Batman's 50th anniversary will be celebrated at a convention in the Days Inn Hotel, 440 West 57th Street, from 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. today. Toys, comic books and collectibles will be displayed. Admission is $5. Information: (718) 266-1853.

LEAD: FROM the southern coastal plain to the rocky fastnesses of the Northeast, the old gravestones dot New Jersey's African-American cemeteries. They have a characteristic silhouette, and when you get used to it you can readily pick them out. Occasionally you'll see a Grand Army of the Republic stanchion stuck in the ground alongside, and there are always the flowers on Memorial Day.

LEAD: A class-action suit has charged seven New York City supermarket chains with widespread violations of state law by limiting the numbers of bottles and cans that homeless people can redeem for their deposits.
LEAD: Driven by the explosive growth of state-sponsored lotteries, gambling is becoming a national pastime.

LEAD: MANY of us recognize that Connecticut is a culturally vibrant state. That is one reason this is a great place to live. Now economists have uncovered the outline of an industry underlying that vitality. It is a growth industry, but one vulnerable to the special sources of its capital.

LEAD: Seeking to defuse Japan's long-running leadership crisis, top leaders of the governing Liberal Democratic Party have settled on the choice of Foreign Minister Sosuke Uno to serve as the country's next Prime Minister, news organizations reported this morning.

LEAD: LAST year, when a heat wave combined with fouled beaches, the resourceful found a way to the water. If they couldn't be in it, they could be on it, and boat tour operators suddenly found themselves rich in passengers. They are bracing for another banner season this year.

LEAD: I would like to add to your report on human rights in China that, no matter how badly intellectuals and activists are treated, it cannot compare with Chinese brutality in Tibet. LEAD: President Bush told Italian leaders that Soviet proposals to reduce conventional arms could lead to reductions in U.S. forces in Europe. His spokesman said the issue would be discussed at the NATO summit talks on Monday and Tuesday. Article, page 18.

LEAD: When the Minneapolis-based Dayton Hudson Corporation acquired Mervyn's, the California apparel chain, a decade ago, it got a powerhouse - an innovative and much emulated retailer that could contribute mightily to the parent corporation's earnings. But, as Dayton Hudson learned after Mervyn's drifted into serious problems, benign neglect is no substitute for hands-on management.

LEAD: Everything seems royal about the diamond-encrusted ''Pine Cone'' Easter egg that the Russian jeweler Peter Carl Faberge made in 1900. Everything, that is, except its pedigree. This exquisite bauble is royal blue, an enameled triumph. When it was auctioned on May 10 by Christie's in Geneva, it fetched the princely sum of $3 million.

LEAD: Pizza Hut wants to find neighborhoods with just the right balance of different types of people, as well as enough traffic to make a new store's success likely. The World Bank wants to see how cattle might be displaced by a pipeline in Tanzania. Politicians want to redraw political boundaries. The fire department wants to know, when a 911 emergency call comes in, where the nearest hydrant is.

LEAD: Ireland's first entry in the Whitbread round-the-world race, a massive white and green maxi-yacht, was being wheeled out of a repair shed in Portsmouth, R.I., last week. The yacht's crewmen had a race to think about, but it wasn't around the world. It was to be across the Atlantic Ocean, a mere sprint by Whitbread standards.

LEAD: With the encyclopedia of the near future, looking up Africa would be the next best thing to being there. You'd walk through the jungle, hear the lions roar and see tribal rituals - all on your television screen. Pressing a button on the controller could bring you face to face with a Zulu warrior.

LEAD: NOW that it's spring in England, the windows of H. F. Richards poultry, game and pork shop in the Oxford Covered Market have lost their winter plumage. Since the feathered game season ends in February, overhead racks of wild mallard, teal, wood pigeon, grouse, widgeon, partridge and scores of pheasant from nearby Blenheim Park are empty.

LEAD: A home gardener is in charge and can choose a way to get rid of pests that is least harmful to the environment. Too often when chemical weapons are used for complete eradication, the good is destroyed with the bad.

LEAD: An Arab who tried to infiltrate Israel from Jordan opened fire and slightly wounded two Israeli soldiers this morning before he was shot and killed, the Israeli Army said. An army spokeswoman said that around 6:30 A.M., an army patrol was fired on from near the border fence opposite Kibbutz Hamadya, 12 miles south of the Sea of Galilee.

LEAD: WE wait for summer, and then our thoughts call up the rewards of reading in pleasant, relaxed surroundings. LEAD: Last summer, just after the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan bought the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, it said it would invest $1.5 billion in its new American property, raising spending for everything from research to plant modernization. To executives in Firestone's Chicago headquarters, who had watched the company steadily decline and shrink in the past decade, the purchase signaled a much-needed renaissance.

LEAD: THE ICE AT THE BOTTOM OF THE WORLD. By Mark Richard. (Knopf, $16.95.) Abandoned children, bereaved lovers, victims of flood and other devastations - these are the characters who inhabit Mark Richard's first collection of short stories. Set somewhere in the South in bleak landscapes that mirror the futile existence of those who live there, the stories depict a world wracked by emotional, economic or natural disaster.

LEAD: Tennis West Germany Tops U.S.: West Germany defeated the United States, 2-1, yesterday at the World Team Cup tournament in Dusseldorf, West Germany, advancing to a showdown today against Argentina in the final. LEAD: Gene Gotti, the 42-year-old brother of John Gotti, was convicted of running a multimillion-dollar heroin ring, but it wasn't easy. The case began in 1983, resulted in two mistrials and became one of the oldest unresolved matters on the Federal docket. A third mistrial was narrowly averted in Brooklyn when one of the 12 jurors whose identities were supposedly secret said that two men had threatened him in his driveway.

My heart jumped; when I had met him before he had mentioned that he might be interested in doing some theater, and I happened to have a play in my desk drawer.

Others have unusual silhouettes.

LEAD: Anyone new to the experience of owning a lawn, as I am, soon figures out that there is more at stake here than a patch of grass. A lawn immediately establishes a certain relationship with one's neighbors and, by extension, the larger American landscape. Mowing the lawn, I realized the first time I gazed into my neighbor's yard and imagined him gazing back into mine, is a civic responsibility.
LEAD: Advocates of more radical change in the Soviet Union suffered a bitter defeat today when many of the most outspoken political insurgents were denied seats in the country's new legislature.

The ''frivolous society'' of turn-of-the-century New York, Edith Wharton claimed in her 1905 novel ''The House of Mirth,'' ''can acquire dramatic significance only through what its frivolity destroys.'' In this volume, Louis Auchincloss - like Wharton, a novelist of manners and a scion of the patricians he chronicles - calls this the society of ''The Vanderbilt Era.

LEAD: Egypt is facing an impending financial squeeze over the repayment of debts related to United States military aid that has prompted a review of military spending, Egyptian and Western officials said here.

LEAD: An extensive survey of air traffic controllers by the General Accounting Office paints a picture of low morale, heavy workloads and a lack of experience and training. In contrast, it shows a corps of managers who believe things are not so bad.

LEAD: Wende Ellen Sawyer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Sawyer of San Mateo, Calif., was married yesterday in Stanford, Calif., to George Thompson Hutton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Hutton of Greenwich, Conn., and Seattle. The ceremony, at the Stanford Memorial Church, was performed by the Rev.

LEAD: I eagerly read Linda Wells's article ''Spa Life'' (May 7), hoping to find some spas in the United States like the ones I enjoyed so much during the three years I lived in Hungary. I was disappointed to see that the spas you mention are more like modern resorts, with fitness facilities. These resorts may be pleasant places to spend some time; however, they are not built around mineral springs, as are European spas.
LEAD: EACH year, three million people make fourteen million visits to Central Park. On a beautiful summer day, there might be 250,000 people in its 843 acres.

LEAD: The son of Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher has acknowledged that the Department of Housing and Urban Development quickly approved financing for a low-income housing project in Texas after he sought assistance from the chief aide to the former Secretary of the department, Samuel R. Pierce.
LEAD: Phineas Newborn Jr., a leading jazz pianist, died at his home in Memphis, Tenn., Friday. He was 57 years old.

LEAD: A few days ago, I attended a new piece of musical theater by Paul Dresher and Rinde Eckert called ''Power Failure.'' The production was part of the American Music Theater Festival season in Philadelphia, and the first night of its two-week run was therefore the world premiere.
LEAD: President Bush said Thursday that he would nominate Edward J. Perkins, a career diplomat and most recently the Ambassador to South Africa, as director general of the Foreign Service.

LEAD: IT is tempting to drive through Garden City, Utah, too quickly, pausing only at the stop sign where Route 89 skitters up to Bear Lake and then curves sharply to avoid it. To tourists in the West, after all, towns are just interruptions along the great, shimmering highway that stretches toward the horizon.

LEAD: To the Editor: Some tourists really might not care that their tour payments go to Tourist Burma, which provides the junta with the foreign exchange to purchase the ammunition vital to maintaining its privileged position astride a degraded country.

LEAD: HE was standing in the courtyard of the Great Mosque of Cordoba in southern Spain when I saw him, gargling water from the ritual fountain there. Three times he took a mouthful and spat it out; three times he sniffed water up his nostrils and snorted; three times he washed his face and ears and then his hands and forearms as far as the elbow, to purify all five senses.

LEAD: After watching the pro basketball playoffs for the past few weeks, I realize why I did not become a great player like Michael Jordan: I was taught the wrong game.
LEAD: No one was surprised when student radicals declared the other day that they would devote the next two weeks to anti-American themes. ''We're used to it,'' an American diplomat said.
LEAD: The Rockefeller Foundation has elected five new trustees, including Alan Alda, the actor and director, and Henry G. Cisneros, the retiring Mayor of San Antonio.

LEAD: House 1. Emergency Spending Bil: Vote on passage of a $3.7 billion emergency spending bill that includes $822 million in new anti-drug spending and $1.2 billion for the Veterans Affairs Department. Approved 227 to 197, May 24. 2. Anti-Drug Abuse: Vote on a proposal to shift $862 million from the Strategic Defense Initiative to drug control programs.

LEAD: ON a cold winter morning in the early 1870's - the chronicles are not exact - two long-haired, bearded brothers drew their revolvers and stopped the stagecoach on the edge of what is now Eureka Springs, Ark., and politely requested the passengers to dismount. Among the five men on board was one wearing a clerical collar.

LEAD: ''It's a breath mint,'' says Robin Williams, spurred by it's-impossible-to-say-exactly-what. ''No, it's a paper,'' he continues, and now it's getting clearer. The rhythms of the contrast come from an old TV commercial for Certs. But where is he going?

LEAD: Launched in May of last year at the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford, England, a traveling exhibition called ''Lucian Freud: Works on Paper'' can be seen through June 24 at the Brooke Alexander Gallery, 59 Wooster Street.

LEAD: Representative Richard A. Gephardt all but officially entered the race for House majority leader today and became the instant front-runner as his colleagues prepared for a sweeping leadership change, Democrats on Capitol Hill said.

LEAD: The engagement of Quina Fonseca to Jonathan Jova Marvel has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Elizabeth K. Fonseca of New York, East Hampton, L.I., and Venice, and Gonzalo Fonseca of New York and Seravezza, Italy. Mr. Marvel is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Marvel of San Juan, P.R., and Bear Island, Me.

LEAD: To the Editor: I would like to note an inaccuracy in ''What's Doing in Louisville'' (Travel, April 9). The J. B. Speed Art Museum, while enjoying a close relationship with the University of Louisville, is not ''the University of Louisville's . . . Museum,'' but a private institution, Kentucky's oldest and largest art museum, which has served this area of the county independently as an art museum for more than 60 years.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An escaped mental patient who said he had a bomb ordered the pilot of a Miami-bound jetliner to fly to Cuba today, Federal officials said. But the plane put down here instead, and the man was arrested after two hours of negotiations, during which 150 passengers sat by helplessly on board the jet.

LEAD: The deft touch for raising political contributions that helped propel Tony Coelho into the Democratic leadership in the House never extended to his personal finances, leaving the California Congressmen financially insecure for much of his political career.

LEAD: If New York jazz has a local habitation and a name, it is the Village Vanguard. The 54-year-old, 123-person-capacity club is a basement in Greenwich Village, a rounded-off triangle (like a pie slice) where Seventh Avenue South meets Waverly Place.

LEAD: Three nations were accused of unfair trading by President Bush. The action means that Japan, India and Brazil are subject to special negotiations with the United States and could face trade sanctions if they do not lower barriers to American imports within 18 months. Japan was cited for trading practices involving satellites, supercomputers and forest products; Brazil for general import licensing requirements and India for restrictions on foreign investments and on foreign insurance companies.

LEAD: WESTCHESTER is on the verge of a ''true recycling adventure,'' County Executive Andrew P.O'Rourke said Monday as he announced plans for a sophisticated plant to separate and process recyled goods into marketable materials.
LEAD: THROUGH the coincidence of transferring from one school to another, changing majors and adding courses, our three children will graduate from college this spring.
LEAD: The marriage of Evelyn Susanna Bolten to James Laurence Connaughton took place yesterday at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington. The Rev. James Conn performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Julie Ann Schwartz and Alan Madison plan a July wedding, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Irvin Schwartz of New York and Southampton, L.I., have announced. Mr. Madison is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Madison of Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

LEAD: Jane E. Dinsmore and Mark S. O'Keeffe were married yesterday in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Sheffield performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church-on-the-Green. Mrs. O'Keeffe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald E. Dinsmore of Convent Station, N.J., graduated from the University of New Hampshire.

LEAD: Composers, or their publicists, are always talking about breakthroughs. No sooner is a new work introduced than it is touted as an unprecedented advance, a break with the past. Perhaps this obsession with forging ahead is a legacy of modernism that lingers in our post-modern era.
LEAD: It's midnight in the world of medical research. Do you know where your mice are?

LEAD: Harness racing, a sport that achieved its highest levels of popularity and financial success in the 1970's, has for more than a decade been experiencing steadily declining attendance and smaller betting handles. Standardbred racing is now trying to recapture the lost interest of the betting public with modifications that promise a better deal, more winners and higher payoffs.

LEAD: Having completed final examinations and papers, the answers for Mount Holyoke College mwomen seeking to let off a little steam has been the Lunar Howling Club. The club, which at last count had a mailing list of 101, meets to howl at the full moon and whimper at the new moon. ''We howl to let off stress and to have a good time,'' said one member, Staci Dumoski, a sophomore and American studies major from Placentia,

LEAD: To the Editor: The box accompanying Steven Erlanger's article on Burma (Travel, April 2) may confuse readers planning to travel to that endlessly fascinating country. You report that the State Department has warned Americans not to fly on Burma Airways because of the airline's appalling record of fatal crashes in the past two years.

LEAD: LAST night in my garden, something like a memorial mound sprang up. Under the earth are hidden lost hopes, among them the remains of a calf bought cheap from a farmer. Why cheap? Because the farmer was upset by the price of the dollar, the only real currency in the country, constantly jumping up, and the stories of so-called economic reforms that would only make his life worse.

LEAD: Any musical that depends as much upon evoking a high-style period ambiance as Lerner and Loewe's ''Gigi'' is bound to be compromised by a production that fails to offer at least a modicum of opulence. In the Equity Library Theater's cheery but threadbare revival, the few props chosen to suggest turn-of-the-century Parisian grandeur look like moth-eaten relics from a second-hand shop.

LEAD: In a highly secret arrangement, the United States has long provided substantial covert assistance to the French nuclear weapons program, apparently in violation of American law, an authority on international relations says.
LEAD: Twenty-five years ago, Paulo Freire's world as a radical educator crashed around him.

LEAD: Open Mind beat ten 3-year-old fillies so impressively in the $186,600 Acorn Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park that her handlers are now thinking about running her against colts in the Belmont Stakes June 10.

LEAD: The Alabama Supreme Court has let stand a lower court decision that prosecutors ''utterly and completely failed'' to prove that Jim Abernethy, a former sports agent in Atlanta, violated criminal law when he paid an Auburn University football player. LEAD: The lawyers for Pete Rose will question Ronald Peters, one of Rose's accusers, before Rose's hearing June 26 with Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti. The hearing was originally scheduled for May 25, but Rose's lawyers were granted a delay to cross-examine accusers of their client and prepare a defense.

Kaneb of Weston, Mass., to George deLancey Soule, the son of Richard H. Soule of Canterbury, N.H., and Emily M. Soule of Darien, Conn.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: A VISITOR on a tour of the state's theaters in late September could have been fooled. There were ''The Glass Menagerie,'' ''La Cage aux Folles,'' ''Born Yesterday'' and ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' all set to start the season in four major theaters, all bespeaking theatrical balm in New Jersey.

LEAD: ON a recent Saturday morning at 4:30, Robert and Evelyn Irons left their home in Juliustown and drove three hours to William Paterson College in Wayne to be first in line for Ken Gordon's sold-out show.

LEAD: RICHARD ROY waved his hands a few times and appeared to make a short rope long and then short again. A few minutes later, he asked a visitor to pick a card from a freshly shuffled deck and, without looking, was able to tell what was picked. ''Magic,'' Mr. Roy says, ''is something that happens that's not supposed to happen.

LEAD: An hour's drive from the heart of New York City can take sailing enthusiasts to a world of their own. Here on Senasqua Bay, where the Hudson River is at its widest, you can learn to sail, brush up on boating skills or charter a boat for a day cruise.
LEAD: Nancy Reagan has withdrawn her support for plans for a drug treatment center, and the organization undertaking the disputed project said the center would not be opened.

LEAD: ''Atwater and his fraternity brothers,'' we are told, ''used to rent black-and-white pornographic movies and charge 50 cents to see them. '' 'You can bet nobody asked for their damn money back on those flicks,' he volunteers, sitting with his wife and parents [ emphasis mine ] in the family living room.
LEAD: Marcy Ann Corbett and Ellis Joseph Verdi were married last evening at the Hotel Pierre in New York by Rabbi David Weiss.
LEAD: Second Avenue between 42d and 53d Streets will be closed from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. today for the Turtle Bay Fair.

LEAD: At All Saints' Episcopal Church in Chevy Chase, Md., March Victoria Moore, a daughter of Guy Will Moore of Arlington, Va., and the late Hazel Cartwright Moore, was married yesterday to Christopher Lockwood Dodge. The Rev. Dr. H. Stuart Irvin officiated.

LEAD: UNABLE to reach his coat because the hangers in the closet of his Wall Township home were too high, 7-year-old Nicholas Giammanco - 40 inches tall - used to leave it crumpled on the closet floor. Eventually his parents hung it up, and to get it down again, he tugged at the sleeves, knocking down other coats, too.

LEAD: The pianist Alexis Golovin has had a curious career odyssey, one result of which was that his New York debut Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y, with an audience full of piano fanciers, presented a fully formed musical personality.
LEAD: An article last week on the bicycle business incorrectly identified the first American winner of the Tour de France. He is Greg LeMond, who won the race in 1986.
LEAD: THE EVENING WOLVES By Joan Chase. 295 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

LEAD: There is no greater opportunity for the aspiring young grandmaster than to be taken on as second to a principal of world championship caliber, but there is also the hazard of becoming awestruck.

LEAD: The Maglev thing seems to be out of place on Long Island. No doubt someone could build one, but what need would it serve? Manhattan to Riverhead? How many people make the trip between those two points? Many to the North Fork or to the Hamptons, but just to Riverhead? When you get off the Maglev there, how do you get to Aquebogue or Mattituck or Shelter Island or Montauk?

LEAD: The Museum of the City of New York, at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, is exhibiting ''Family Treasures: Toys and Their Tales'' through April 1990. Reflecting the social history of New York, the toys include expensive European imports, modest domestic inventions of the 19th and early 20th centuries, and dolls commemorating such events of local importance as the Seventh Regiment Armory Fair of 1879.

LEAD: It is the same sport but a different game, with the rules, the duties and even the environment influencing the way a basketball coach approaches his job at the college or the professional level. There is, however, at least one similarity. As Rick Pitino has discovered, a coach with a high-profile job at any level is subject to intense public scrutiny.

LEAD: On the cover of her new album, ''Absolute Torch and Twang'' (Sire/Warner Bros. 25877; all three formats) K. D. Lang is pictured standing in a golden field under a deep blue prairie sky. Clad in denims, her hair short and spiky, the Canadian country singer casts a flinty gaze over the landscape toward the horizon.

LEAD: There is perhaps someone somewhere who has never wished to get even about something. In fact, a surprising number of people claim to be that someone, but they know in their hearts it isn't true.

LEAD: A plan that would leave the impending Time-Warner combination with control of cable television in 60 percent of New York City's households has encountered a rough reception at the Board of Estimate.
LEAD: A 34-year-old teacher at Amityville High School accused of selling five ounces of cocaine to undercover agents was held on $800,000 bail today.
LEAD: THE LONG ROAD TO FREEDOM Russia and Glasnost. By Walter Laqueur. 325 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $21.95.

LEAD: The engagement of Faith Tara Schwartzman to Dr. Jeffrey Craig Wint has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Schwartzman of Princeton, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Dr. Wint is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Wint of Manhasset Hills, L.I. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: People love pretty much the same things best. A writer looking for subjects inquires not after what he loves best, but after what he alone loves at all. Strange seizures beset us. Frank Conroy loves his yo-yo tricks, Emily Dickinson her slant of light; Richard Selzer loves the glistening peritoneum, Faulkner the muddy bottom of a little girl's drawers visible when she's up a pear tree.

LEAD: Enthusiasts of the perky cabaret revues once so prevalent in New York who - in an access of ungrammatical nostalgia - like to say ''They just don't make 'em like they used to,'' should take note: a visit to ''Showing Off'' shows that they do.

LEAD: THERE is more to a successful retirement than careful financial planning, according to Susan Fitzgerald, an adult development specialist and director of the Fairfield Adult Career Educational Services at Fairfield University. Planning for the psychological and emotional hurdles of retirement is equally as important.

LEAD: EVEN before the Bush Administration declared Japan an unfair trading partner last week, it was hard to miss the cracks spreading across the thin shell of smiles and bland assurances of ''close cooperation'' that masks the tensions in the United States-Japan alliance.

LEAD: The world is on the verge of a technological transformation that will make current televison as obsolete as the hot-air dirigible. This new technology will also radically enhance the competitiveness of American technology and the richness and variety of video programming. This new development is not high definition television, which offers only a fourfold increase in picture quality over existing television.
LEAD: Public schools must provide education for all handicapped children, no matter how severe the disability or how little they might benefit, a Federal appeals court panel has ruled.
LEAD: MY beautiful antique clock hung mute on the wall. It slowly worked down, gradually losing time until its handsome brass and ebony pendulum stopped swinging altogether.

LEAD: Spain will compete in the 1992 America's Cup with a Spanish-designed vessel, the president of a group in charge of organizing the country's effort said today.
LEAD: About 200,000 young people attended a daylong open-air pop concert in Hong Kong today to raise money for the pro-democratic demonstrations in China.

LEAD: To the Editor: We at Classic Rail Cars also provide premium rail transportation. Generally, costs start at about $3,000 a day, including food and beverage service, transportation and a staff of four. We also offer the availability of multiple-car operations for parties or weddings and even private trains.
