LEAD: The tract of forest and meadow in central New Jersey near Princeton first attracted the attention of eagle-eyed London speculators, John Lord Berkeley and Sir George Carteret, in the 1650's; they acquired it from the Crown. Later, it was owned by William Penn, the Quaker leader, and, at the time of the Revolutionary War, it was the property of Richard Stockton, one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence.

LEAD: IN ACCORDANCE WITH AN OLD TRADITION, THE GRAND shrine at Ise, in central Japan, is pulled down every twenty years and built up again in exactly the same form, that of an ancient wooden hut for storing rice. There, sometime in the seventh century, a princess of the imperial court decided the sun goddess Amaterasu was to be worshipped.

LEAD: The National Ballet of Canada has recently presented ''Tagore,'' a premiere by Glen Tetley, and staged here, for the second year, its International Competition for the Erik Bruhn Prize. The competition - limited to four companies with which Bruhn was associated - may continue, albeit in modified form.

LEAD: An Argentine Navy supply ship that ran aground and capsized in Antarctica four months ago continues to leak oil, and approaching winter weather has virtually ended efforts to limit the damage, United States authorities and environmentalists say.

LEAD: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Dolores Janes-Garcia, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Janes of Kew Gardens, Queens, was married yesterday to Wesley D. Wheeler by the Rev. Dr. R. Maurice Boyd.

LEAD: ON a recent tour of Westminster Abbey my wife and I found a dank, chilly enclosure in the cloisters crowded with tourists of many lands leaning over benches and industriously rubbing wax of various colors onto black paper laid over engraved brass plaques.

LEAD: I was delighted to read about William B. Styple's book about Gen. Philip Kearny (''About Books,'' April 23). It brought back memories of my early youth in my birthplace, Kearny, in the early 1920's.

LEAD: Orville Schell's trenchant article ''Human Rights in China: An Act of Defiance'' (April 16), about the surrealistic odyssey of Fang Lizhi in Beijing is important. Mr. Schell paints a chilling picture of human rights in China. The persecutions continue, with the acquiesence of the United States.

LEAD: Politicians and chief executives, best sellers and cover stories by major publications lament the sale of corporate America to foreign buyers. LEAD: THE sign at Freeport's Victoria De Las Tunas reads Spanish Restaurant, but diners expecting standard Spanish fare will be disappointed.

LEAD: Getting away from it all was taken to new heights, or depths, by Stefania Follini, who last week completed 130 days without human contact in a sealed cave in Carlsbad, N.M. It was an experiment to help researchers learn how people could be affected by long periods of isolation during interplanetary travel.
LEAD: Jerry Colangelo, president and chief executive officer of the Phoenix Suns, has been selected the National Basketball Association's executive of the year by The Sporting News.

LEAD: At the Rancho Seco Nuclear Generating Plant here, where cows graze in the shadow of the twin cooling towers, contingency plans are being made to turn off the plant, move the fuel into storage, lay off hundreds of workers and buy power from alternative sources.

LEAD: EMILY L. By Marguerite Duras. Translated by Barbara Bray. (Pantheon, $15.95.) Marguerite Duras, the Goncourt Prize-winning author of many novels, including ''The Lover,'' again combines her gifts for the literary and visual arts in this arresting novella. In a French quayside cafe in late summer, the French narrator, accompanied by the man with whom she's been having an affair that is ''taking forever to die,'' grows absorbed by a British couple sitting nearby.
LEAD: Andrea Susan Booth and Dr. Steven Marc Wolf were married last evening in the Eastchester, N.Y., home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Wolf. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman officiated.

LEAD: A group of about 40 youths raced through Greenwich Village Friday night, snapping gold chains from the necks of strollers, harassing women and pushing and menacing anyone who came in their path, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: To the Editor: Steven Erlanger glossed over the truly splendid and unusual things to see in Burma. I found it totally refreshing to be one of only 50 to 75 tourists in the whole country. While Burma isn't geared for tourists yet, it was wonderful to visit the various sites and not be inundated with gawking tourists and hordes of tour buses.

LEAD: An article on May 14 about new uses for the antibiotic tetracycline misstated its effect on the tissue-destroying enzyme collagenase. Collagenase is believed to be a factor causing rheumatoid arthritis. Tetracycline reduces the enzyme's activity by 67 percent, not 6 to 7 percent.

LEAD: WITH the Broadway season's supply of new plays falling to near an all-time low, as reported by the League of American Theaters and Producers, the notion of a work being broken in for Broadway by a regional theater is more an illusion than a probability.

LEAD: A new book contends that American intelligence agencies bungled inquiries into the death or disappearance of three men entrusted with some of the nation's most closely held secrets.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Cheng Ching Wang of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Vera Wang, to Arthur Paul Becker, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold H. Becker of Avon, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Speeds at Indianapolis are not too fast. Today's racing machines are far safer than those driven just a few years ago. As design engineers build stronger and safer cars, I see no reason why speeds shouldn't continue to rise.
LEAD: Arrowhead coins of the ancient Scythians pose an interesting question: When does an object become a coin and cease to be an object of barter?
LEAD: Charles Parkhill Lykes, chairman of a cattle, citrus and meatpacking empire and patriarch of one of the state's most prominent families, died Thursday. He was 72 years old.

LEAD: NOT long ago, the details of running a nuclear reactor were guarded by the United States and the Soviet Union as secrets vital to national security. But last week it seemed that the superpowers were rushing to bare all.

LEAD: THE State of Connecticut is interesting for many reasons, one of which is its practice through the Department of Transportation to allocate contracts for the construction of sound and sight barriers along our main highways.

LEAD: EVERY year 2.5 million people visit the 70,000-acre Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area, a Federal preserve straddling the Delaware River in northwestern New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania. Despite all the visitors, the park has remained a quiet retreat, a peaceful valley of hiking trails and fishing brooks rich in natural beauty, wildlife and historic landmarks.

LEAD: I BRISTLE at the thought of being ''only'' a housewife. I do make apologies, all the time now, it seems. And despite the fact that my children have grown into fine human beings, I definitely do have regrets.

LEAD: Sara Stern, a flutist born and based in Washington and a performer of more than usual accomplishment, appeared Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall. LEAD: Rabbit ears may look good to (and on) a rabbit. But they lack charm as indoor antennas.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Alter of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Midge Alter to Mark A. Caparosa, a son of Dr. Ralph J. Caparosa of Lebanon, Pa., and Patricia E. Caparosa of Forest Hills, Pa. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: ''It is very difficult to continue our sit-in. As leaders, we have responsibility for students' health, and the difficulties are obvious. Hygiene is extremely bad and the food is insufficient.'' - Wuer Kaixi, a student leader in Beijing. [ 1:3. ]
LEAD: Dexter Manley, the All-Pro defensive end for the Washington Redskins, recently came out with an embarrassing confession. He almost made it to the age of 30 without being able to read.
LEAD: Two floors below the polished Senate chamber, in a plain basement office dubbed ''the Pit,'' University of Texas students dash to the rescue in response to a stream of phone calls from above.

LEAD: WHEN interest rates are low, as they were until recently, the allure of state-chartered mortgage programs providing inexpensive loans to first-time buyers tends to fade.

LEAD: IN the cycles of Middle East diplomacy, last week's speech by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was a turning point. LEAD: When the composer Gil Evans died last year, he left a jumble of reputations, some stronger than others. In the 1950's, as a collaborator - his best-known musical personality - he created luminous arrangements on albums such as ''Miles Ahead'' and ''Porgy and Bess'' for his friend Miles Davis's chillingly passionate trumpet.

LEAD: Tamara LaForge Jaycox and Lewis Maier Kessler, 1987 graduates of the Harvard Law School, were married yesterday at the Samuel Powel House, a historic site in Philadelphia, by Judge James T. Giles of the Federal District Court for Eastern Pennsylvania.

LEAD: To the Editor: I disagree with the advice given by Steven Erlanger. He writes, ''The children behave as if they haven't seen candy since martial law, so bring or buy lots of it. Kids of a more discerning age will prefer pens.'' This advice, if followed, will certainly promote the image of the ''ugly American'' abroad.
LEAD: In its 129th commencement yesterday, Bard College graduated 143 undergraduate and 8 graduate students.

LEAD: HAPPY HOLIDAY For those who like to celebrate Memorial Day with more than a backyard barbecue or a look at the holiday parades that have survived Long Island's suburbanization, there's plenty to do this weekend.

LEAD: Alison Creighton Schmults and Cameron Horatio Burns were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Terence L. Elsberry. Kelly Dixon Cooper was the matron of honor. Seth Shepherd Burns was best man for his brother.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: AS an infant in a highchair, I was encouraged to stamp on pieces of boiled potato with my fist (the result is known as ''smashed'' potato), to squeeze bananas through my fingers, and later to eat spaghetti by sucking it up strand by strand. My grandmother called it ''experimenting with textures.''
LEAD: When Brian Donahue graduated from St. Michael's College in 1988, he planned to become a salesman. ''My career goal was to make some money and then go into politics,'' Mr. Donahue said.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Roy Earl Demmon of Washington and Atherton, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Bailey Demmon to George Allen Fowlkes Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fowlkes of New York and Nantucket, Mass. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: MAPPING THE MORAL DOMAIN A Contribution of Women's Thinking to Psychological Theory and Education. Edited by Carol Gilligan, Janie Victoria Ward and Jill McLean Taylor, with Betty Bardige. 324 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $30.

LEAD: A wild notion that Louisville lay in the sunny South inspired me to make Kentucky my home back in the 1970's. Geographically and climate-wise, I was off a bit, but I was right on the Mason-Dixon line when it came to the food.

LEAD: In an effort to provide more housing for the elderly in Harlem, the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development has teamed up with one of the city's largest black churches to build an apartment house at 2177 Frederick Douglass Boulevard at 118th Street. The building will be named Wyatt Tee Walker Senior Housing.

LEAD: For This Week: Plant: tomatoes, peppers, sweet corn, melons, cucumbers, begonias, geraniums, marigolds, petunias, sweet alyssum. Prune back any overgrown shrubs that bloomed earlier this season; be sure the cutting tools are sharp so the bark is not torn. Daylilies/Lilies

LEAD: IN TRANSIT Twenty Stories. By Mavis Gallant. 229 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

LEAD: THE Yonkers City Council, where a continuing dispute over a court-ordered housing-desegregation plan has dominated the agenda in recent years, may look a lot different after this November's elections. But the legislative results could remain the same. All six district seats are being contested, as is the mayoralty, the Council's seventh vote.
LEAD: CONFESSIONS OF A BAD GIRL By Bette Pesetsky. 211 pp. New York: Atheneum. $16.95.
LEAD: Because James Worthy is soft-spoken, his presence in the Los Angeles Lakers' locker room is unassuming. Because he plays for a star-laden team, his importance is sometimes unappreciated.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Lippmann of New York of the engagement of their daughter Pamela Linde Lippmann to Matthew Adam Roth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Roth of Peekskill, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: John Silber, like the philosopher Allen Bloom, feels strongly that the chief objective of a university should be dedication to the learning process. It is good to know that there are men in responsible positions like this crusading educator who are willing to make difficult and unpopular choices in support of the stern moral precepts laid down by the American pioneers.
LEAD: During the Presidential campaign and many times since we have heard President Bush say, ''Read my lips,'' and this we have been doing.

LEAD: The wedding of Prof. Linda Silberman and Dr. Victor Goldberg took place last evening at D'Agostino Hall at the New York University School of Law. Judge Phyllis Gangel-Jacob of Manhattan Civil Court officiated.
LEAD: AFTER more than two decades of trying to obliterate their house-trailer heritage, manufacturers of modular houses are finally persuading skeptics to buy housing off the assembly line.

LEAD: Capitol Hill braced today for more partisan bloodletting after the announcement by Representative Tony Coelho, the third-ranking Democrat in the House, that he would resign to spare his family and his Democratic colleagues the turmoil of a lengthy investigation of his finances.
LEAD: Mark Gubicza pitched a seven-hitter to win at home for the first time in five starts this year and Jim Eisenreich had a single and two doubles today as Kansas City beat the Detroit Tigers, 5-1.

LEAD: ''I Know My Name is Steven,'' which was broadcast by NBC on Monday and Tuesday nights, was the second-highest-rated mini-series of the season, according to the A. C. Nielsen Company. The four-hour program had an average rating of 24.5 and was seen by 39 percent of the viewing audience.

LEAD: Consider the land of the made-for-TV movie. You probably know it's there, but you haven't been paying that much attention to it. Made-for-TV movies don't hang around like ''theatrical'' movies. Even a really horrible theatrical movie will be advertised for a couple of weeks or so and is more noticeable than ''Everybody's Baby: The Rescue of Jessica McClure'' on ABC last Sunday or ''Out on the Edge'' (CBS, May 14).

But Martin Jaite of Argentina rallied and defeated Carl-Uwe Steeb, 6-4, 6-3, in the second singles match.

LEAD: Batters Up and Down Q. Thirty years ago last week, Harvey Haddix of the Pittsburgh Pirates pitched one of baseball's masterpieces, working 12 perfect innings, retiring 36 batters in a row, but, incredibly, losing the game in 13 innings to the Milwaukee Braves. LEAD: The pain poured over the Mets in waves today: Gary Carter underwent surgery on his right knee and will be gone nearly two months. Davey Johnson will try to avoid or delay surgery on the two ruptured disks in his back, but does not know if he can. The hitters have collectively been so weak that the brass will hold a series of summit meetings this week to try to head off a collapse.
LEAD: Steffi Graf, playing at the top of her game, and slumping Mats Wilander opened defense of their French Open titles by coasting to straight-set victories today.

LEAD: Never has Las Vegas, the glittery and gaudy capital of American gambling, faced more competition for the gambling dollar and yet never have its casinos been more popular - and profitable. Las Vegas has responded to the new realities of gaming by trying to transform itself from sin city into family entertainment zone, where wagering seems as routine as taking in a movie.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: With the game down to its last second, John Dressel of Johns Hopkins took a last shot at the Syracuse goal today in a final attempt to tie the score. But the goalie Matt Palum blocked it, and the Orangemen won their second consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association lacrosse championship.

LEAD: A cyclone that tore across Bangladesh and eastern India on Saturday killed at least 84 people and left more than half a million homeless, officials and news reports said today. Tens of thousands of mud and straw huts were blown away during the storm, which was accompanied by winds of up to 85 miles per hour, they said.
LEAD: The Nevada Assembly voted 31 to 9 today in favor of a bill to legalize surrogate motherhood agreements, a measure described by its advocates as the first of its sort in the nation.
LEAD: Private researchers contended today that the Navy covered up a nuclear accident on a submarine 16 years ago because the incident was not mentioned on the ship's logs.
LEAD: Rick Pitino, the Knicks' coach, has informally agreed to become the University of Kentucky's head basketball coach, according to reports.

LEAD: ARIF JAMAL, an agronomist and pesticide specialist, had traveled from Khartoum to tell the story haunting him since droves of animals were killed last August in the Dinder wildlife reserve in the Sudan.
LEAD: Japanese officials are hoping to use a gathering of the industrial world's economic and finance ministers here Wednesday to rally European countries against United States trade policies.
LEAD: Massachusetts faces a public health crisis that threatens dramatic service cuts if the state fails to meet its financial obligations, a broad range of health-care providers have warned.
LEAD: If you're the champion, the world hangs with bated breath on your every sneeze. That was evident from what happened in the Fourth World Cup Tournament, which ended April 20 in Barcelona, Spain.
LEAD: The Government reported a new guerrilla offensive around Jalalabad today, but said its soldiers had repulsed the insurgents with artillery fire.

LEAD: Jockeying for the second- and third-ranking House leadership posts intensified today as a new contender emerged for Democratic whip and a candidate for majority leader vowed to stay in the race despite earlier doubts that he could win.

LEAD: After more than a decade of winning praise both in New York and across the country for innovative cost-cutting policies and improvements in patient care, Dr. David Axelrod, the state's Health Commissioner, is under growing attack as New York's hospitals sink deeper into crisis.

LEAD: Westchester County has decided to build a $10 million plant in Yonkers to recycle newspapers, glass, cans, aluminum and plastics, reducing the pressure on a garbage-to-energy incinerator in Peekskill and providing savings for the county's cities and towns. The plant is scheduled to begin operations next summer.

LEAD: In the advanced state of self-absorption in which modern life exists, it is sometimes hard to determine with any degree of accuracy whether the emotion one feels toward another person is love or hate. It is even difficult to remember whether one is alive or dead.
LEAD: Zhang Quan slipped out of work several times earlier this month to join pro-democracy rallies, and he donated $27, two-thirds of his monthly salary, to the student demonstrators.

LEAD: Many business leaders, worried that in the long run they may be hit with the cost of health care for millions of uninsured people, are beginning to advocate a greater role for the Federal Government in extending coverage to all Americans.

LEAD: It is time now to talk about men and women whose dreams and sufferings are shaping great events but whose names and very lives are hardly ever mentioned.

LEAD: The dollar is soaring in value. Just this month it has risen about 6 percent against the Japanese yen and West German mark. Ordinarily, that would be reason for American consumers to cheer: they are collectively richer.
LEAD: Go easy on the oat bran or it may go hard on you, doctors advise.

LEAD: Dance Theater Workshop, established in 1965, began as a showcase for a group of modern-dance choreographers and their friends. But even those who have seen the organization grow from its modest beginnings in a narrow Chelsea loft with protruding ceiling pipes into a leading theater for new dance might be surprised at the programs it will present tomorrow and Thursday.

LEAD: After further examination of Willie Wilson's right shoulder yesterday, doctors said the Kansas City Royals center fielder would probably go on the disabled list for a couple of weeks. The 11-year veteran was diagnosed as having tendinitis of the right rotator cuff.
LEAD: Lieut. Eddie Cash parked his face just an inch from the nose of 18-year-old Heath Partlow.

LEAD: COMPAQ rolled out three new computers last week, all of them 33-megahertz versions of the Deskpro 386 personal computer. The Deskpro 386/33 Models 84, 320 and 650 set new standards for power and performance in desktop systems.

LEAD: If anyone thought it was easy to forge a common stance on a very complex issue among 16 very different countries, the full scope of the challenge became apparent only after a glance at the parties involved.

LEAD: LAST year, when Backer Spielvogel Bates's top executives gathered for their first worldwide management conference ever, their talk was of creativity, and the reaction among agency observers was incredulity.
LEAD: This week's new Treasury issues include tomorrow's auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills and Thursday's auction of a new one-year bill.

LEAD: Sammy Davis Jr. is sitting in the Presidential Suite of a midtown hotel, 85 blocks south and 63 years west of his childhood Harlem home.

LEAD: Eberhard von Kuenheim, the chairman of Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G., exudes confidence as he contemplates the automobile business from his office atop the company's distinctive high-rise headquarters here.

LEAD: OFFICIALS and legislatures in dozens of states have been reaching for ways to ease the problems of patients, doctors and insurers who battle in court in multimillion-dollar medical malpractice lawsuits. But a case in Minnesota illustrates how complicated and controversial the issues of malpractice insurance can be.

LEAD: DIGGING into valleys detected by space shuttle radar under the Sahara's sands has shown that during three separate periods up to 212,000 years ago they were vegetated and densely inhabited by makers of stone axes.
LEAD: * American Electric Power Service Corp., Columbus, Ohio, named Armando A. Pena vice president of finance.
LEAD: A 42-year-old Swede with a history of criminal violence and drug abuse was charged today with murdering Prime Minister Olof Palme in 1986.
LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc. has signed up one of Japan's leading computer companies to support its microprocessor and software.

LEAD: Prosecutors in Japan's influence-peddling scandal said they had not found enough evidence to charge Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita or any other top political leader with committing criminal acts. The announcement ended the eight-month investigation that forced Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita to resign.

LEAD: Four neo-Nazi ''skinheads'' attacked a Jewish couple, their infant, and a black man who tried to help them Sunday, the police said.
LEAD: THE combination of depression and asthma is potentially lethal in children, a new study suggests.

LEAD: The sign on the outskirts of town reads, ''Welcome to Rigby - Birthplace of TV,'' although considering how much television has changed the rest of the world, it doesn't seem to have done a great deal to for Rigby.

LEAD: WAITING for Carl C. Icahn, the corporate raider, to do something about his investment in the USX Corporation is a bit like waiting for Godot, but speculation of action is again on the rise, fueled by two coincidental events happening in early June.

LEAD: COLLEGE BASEBALL Arkansas Edges Le Moyne: Troy Eklund hit a grand slam home run in the seventh inning yesterday as Arkansas came from behind to edge Le Moyne of Syracuse, 6-5, in the championship game of the N.C.A.A. Division I Northeast Region tournament at Waterbury, Conn. The victory, the 700th in the career of the Arkansas coach, Norm DeBriyn, gave the Razorbacks (50-14) a berth in the College World Series, which starts Friday in Omaha.
LEAD: * Seagram Beverage Co. retained Chiat/Day, New York, for Soho Natural Sodas, after a review. A budget has not been set.

LEAD: After a Catholic group dropped its opposition, lawmakers appear close to an agreement on legislation that would allow patients in New York State to authorize other people to make life-and-death decisions about their medical treatment.

LEAD: Thousands of workers nationwide went on strike for higher pay today, defying an appeal by President Corazon C. Aquino, who said labor unrest would discourage needed foreign investment. The Government said the general strike affected 169 companies employing more than 137,000 workers. Unions said half a million workers on central Luzon island alone stayed home.

LEAD: At the start of this decade, when scientists were enthusiastic about building computers that would think like humans, the Pentagon embarked on a huge program to harness the technology for military use. Among the most publicized goals was a truck that could plot its own course and steer by itself.

LEAD: THERE are many men and women, otherwise capable and canny, who quail at the thought of writing a business letter. Perhaps they are less than confident of their command of grammar, syntax or spelling, or maybe they think a business letter requires the formal, stuffy style of the era of the steel nib and inkwell.

LEAD: About 50 members of a Roman Catholic parish held a Mass outside their shuttered church Sunday, but an archdiocese spokesman said the service was just a stunt. The church, Mother of Our Saviour, which had 57 member families, was one of 30 Detroit parishes with dwindling congregations that were ordered closed by Edmund Cardinal Szoka to save money.
LEAD: Cultural politics being as hot as any other kind here, rumors are flying about who will be named to head the National Endowment for the Arts, and when.

LEAD: The Chicago Bulls needed more 11th hour heroics from Michael Jordan today, but they didn't receive any. Instead, the Detroit Pistons outmuscled the Bulls, 86-80, to tie the four-of-seven game Eastern Conference championship series at two games apiece.
LEAD: Japan is expected to raise its discount rate on Tuesday for the first time in nine years, ending an era of loose money policy here that fueled Japan's economic boom through this decade.

LEAD: The Memorial Day speech by the Mayor of Glen Ridge was not a tribute to war heroes this year. Rather, Mayor Edward M. Callahan took the occasion today to reject the idea of collective guilt over charges that five members of the high school football team had sexually assaulted a 17-year-old mentally retarded girl.

LEAD: ABC's ''Thirtysomething,'' which has just finished its second season, could very well be the prototypical television series for the 1990's. The Reagan years gave us ''Dynasty,'' a fantasy of money, power and glamour. They also left us with profound questions about morals and ethics, questions being distilled in today's headlines concerning politicians and stockbrokers, not to mention obviously troubled teen-agers and growing contingents of the homeless.
LEAD: Under President Matina S. Horner, Radcliffe College attained for its women undergraduates what had long been the school's dream: all the rights and privileges of the men of Harvard College.
LEAD: Last summer, when the Bibby Venture was docked in the East River, the inmates dubbed it ''the Love Boat'' - an odd name for the country's first offshore floating jail.

LEAD: Anatoly I. Lukyanov was his nondescript, nearly bashful self today as he was summoned into the national limelight by sharp-tongued critics demanding he explain his career role as Mikhail S. Gorbachev's indispensable cipher.

LEAD: Every year, hundreds of analytic studies are churned out about the American social welfare system without measureable impact. The Library of Congress alone has catalogued 447 titles on public welfare since 1986.

LEAD: Mike Schmidt, one of the greatest home run hitters of all time, retired today in an emotional farewell to baseball. The 39-year-old Philadelphia Phillies third baseman made the announcement at Jack Murphy Stadium hours before his teammates played the Padres.

LEAD: AGREAT plume of molten rock, rising from deep in the earth, created the Indian Ocean by pushing India, Antarctica, Australia and Africa aside, according to a scenario devised by British and Canadian researchers.

LEAD: MANAGERS at companies that have been involved in a leveraged buyout face a degree of risk but also a challenge that can be valuable to their development, executives at management recruiting firms say.

LEAD: Ten days ago, a handful of the highest-ranking officials of the Bush Administration gathered in George Bush's Kennebunkport home on a rocky promontory overlooking the Maine coast. Mr. Bush told the group he wanted to take ''a bold step'' to deal with Mikhail S. Gorbachev's initiatives.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Ever since King Gustav V of Sweden told Jim Thorpe, ''You, sir, are the greatest athlete in the world'' in 1912, the Olympic decathlon champion has been accorded that unofficial title. Bob Mathias, Milt Campbell, Rafer Johnson, Bill Toomey, Bruce Jenner and Daley Thompson have basked in the golden glow of that description.

LEAD: On Memorial Day, 1988, Jim Macfarland started thinking it wasn't right that Navy Seaman Joseph Bowden's name was omitted from the Mountain Lakes World War I boulder. After all, the 14 local men killed in World War II were listed on the World War II boulder. ''This guy was robbed,'' Mr. Macfarland said.

LEAD: After an attempted hijacking of an American Airlines jet, the authorities are asking how a Cuban exile wearing green military fatigues and a bomber-style jacket and carrying a starter's pistol and two knives was able to elude X-ray devices and other security measures at Los Angeles International Airport
LEAD: All stock, bond and commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Memorial Day.

LEAD: The new proposals for cutting conventional forces made by President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev have brought Western and Soviet bloc nations well down the road toward an agreement that could transform the military equation in Europe.

LEAD: Ally & Gargano lost its president on Friday when Bill Bishop resigned to become chairman of CHC Advertising, a small health care advertising agency based in Woodbridge, N.J. William Luceno, chairman of the New York agency, said Mr. Bishop's departure was unexpected, but added, ''Bill has always wanted to run his own agency.

LEAD: Proper Reality slipped inside the dueling stablemates Seeking the Gold and Dancing Spree in the final furlong and bobbed his nose down at the wire first to win the $589,000 Metropolitan Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

LEAD: President Bush won tentative approval from the European allies early today for proposals that he said could lead to ''a revolutionary conventional arms control agreement'' with the Soviet Union. And he seemed to have made major headway toward mending a split on arms policy within the North Atlantic Treaty

LEAD: Dance Theater Workshop presented two modern-dance choreographers with strong voices but quite different views of life in its ''Split Stream'' program on Sunday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

LEAD: The crimes appear both aberrant and sporadic: High school football captains accused of the degrading sexual assault on a mildly retarded girl in a New Jersey suburb; high school hockey players in a Minneapolis suburb accused of the hotel room rape of a 13-year-old fan; a 15-year-old inner city youth saying he raped a 12-year-old neighbor because ''she really wanted it.
LEAD: A New York City police officer was shot and critically wounded during an exchange of gunfire last night in Brooklyn that ended with the arrest of two gunmen, the police said.

LEAD: The lines of the 25th District of the New York City Council form a rectangle in the heart of Brooklyn, encompassing most of the Flatbush and East Flatbush areas. Seventy percent of the district's population is black or Hispanic; the Councilwoman is Susan D. Alter, who is white.
LEAD: A SIMPLE blood test commonly used to measure kidney function is a highly accurate predictor of heart attack and stroke in patients with high blood pressure, a new study indicates.

LEAD: Quinine in Tonic Q. Is there enough quinine in quinine water to have a medicinal effect? A. It would not be much help against its original target, the fever of malaria, though it might be of some slight help against leg cramps.

LEAD: About 300 Jewish women stood silently today near the gate of the Auschwitz death camp in southern Poland to protest the presence of a convent of Roman Catholic nuns at the site where millions of Jews were killed by the Nazis.
LEAD: In the face of mounting public indignation, the four-day-old Soviet congress reversed itself today and voted to give Boris N. Yeltsin, the maverick Communist, a seat in a new legislature.
LEAD: * Jack Bruemmer has joined DMB&B/Chicago as executive vice president and director of client service.

LEAD: The major role that drug or alcohol abuse plays in causing homelessness has emerged in recent comments by advocates for the homeless, who estimate that addicts constitute a higher proportion of the homeless than do the mentally ill or other identifiable subgroups.

LEAD: An official in the Department of the Interior has cleared the beleaguered president of Haskell Indian Junior College of charges of nepotism and conflict of interest, and has temporarily reinstated him at the small campus in nearby Lawrence, Kan.
LEAD: Ogilvy & Mather's loss of the $50 million-plus Maxwell House coffee account on Friday was softened somewhat by the news that another longtime client has opted to stay put.
LEAD: The members of Congress are in a bind. The virtual decapitation of the Democratic leadership will heighten the pressure for ethics reform, while making it that much more painful to enact.

LEAD: An oil fire in an isolated industrial section of Jersey City burned out of control for nearly four hours yesterday afternoon, sending up clouds of dark smoke visible as far as Long Island and Westchester County. Fire and police officials said the blaze burned from about 3:20 P.M. to 7:10 P.M. on a site close to the Hackensack River where it flows into Newark Bay.

LEAD: Reversing their earlier position, thousands of university students resolved on Monday to maintain pressure on the Government by continuing their round-the-clock occupation of Tiananmen Square for at least three more weeks.

LEAD: Bob Waters, who had continued as head football coach at Western Carolina University for five seasons while suffering from the degenerative nerve-cell disease amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, died this morning at his home. He was 50 years old.

LEAD: COMPUTER experts are exploring a variety of cures for the nation's epidemic of computer viruses, but they see no sure way to stop outbreaks that threaten all but the most isolated and elaborately protected systems.

LEAD: Although the economy appears to be Poland's most pressing problem, it is not an issue in the nation's freest election campaign since the Communists took power after World War II.
LEAD: By her own admission, Marlene Krauss has a lot of energy. She is a surgeon and ophthalmologist, and she has just been named a managing director of corporate finance at D. H. Blair & Company.

LEAD: Two years ago, in a poll of 50,000 employees, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company found that its work force was interested in more than salaries. LEAD: Petr Klima of the Detroit Red Wings was arrested last night by Bloomfield Township police, according to reports by the Detroit television stations WJBK and WXYZ.

LEAD: The year was 1975, and George Balanchine was in Chicago looking for promising young student dancers to fill children's roles in the New York City Ballet's season there. Girls and boys danced by their teacher, Maria Tallchief, a former City Ballet star. Suddenly Balanchine pointed into the crowd. ''That Hawaiian girl,'' he said.
LEAD: Some of the 270 residents who were forced to flee after a gasoline pipeline explosion killed two people last week began returning to their homes today.
LEAD: THE great hope known as low-temperature nuclear fusion suffered its worst setback yet last week at the first Federal conference to assess the phenomenon.

LEAD: When Emerson Fittipaldi retired from Formula One racing, he could not imagine coming back to drive at Indianapolis. Now, Fittipaldi, the winner of this year's Indianapolis 500, says he rarely thinks about retiring.

LEAD: Kinder-Care Inc., the nation's largest child-care service company, yesterday announced a restructuring in which its child-care operations would be separated from its financial-services and retail businesses.
LEAD: If you are a stickler for the calendar, your year is quartered by solstices and equinoxes. If you are a horseplayer in New York, there are four very different seasons.

LEAD: Alan E. Boles, a vice president of the General Reinsurance Corporation in Manhattan from 1937 until he retired in 1969, died Wednesday in Wesley Long Hospital in Greensboro, N.C., where he lived. He was 82 years old.

LEAD: Charles Gibson, the co-host of the ABC news program ''Good Morning America,'' addressed Vassar College's 125th commencement Sunday, telling the 584 undergraduates receiving degrees that college should have provided them with four years of contemplation ''from which you would hopefully emerge with a critical, analytical mind.

LEAD: Investment bankers are being sharply criticized in the Delaware courts, the nation's most important forum for takeover battles, for playing favorites when they oversee auctions of companies and for giving arbitrary investment opinions about the value of bids.

LEAD: Lorraine McCusker did not dare brave the waves. There she was on Jones Beach in her two-piece brown-and-black bathing suit. And there were the breakers, crashing less than a hundred yards away. But - wouldn't you know? - the water was an almost arctic 52 degrees.

LEAD: Hope Dana Mehlman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myron A. Mehlman of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday at the Jewish Center to Eli Hurowitz, the son of Dr. Shula Prigason of Plainsboro, N.J., and Dr. Bertram D. Hurowitz of Hamilton Square, N.J. Rabbi Melvin Glazer performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average has recovered three-quarters of the ground it lost in the 1987 decline, and foreigners have shifted into the United States stock market in large numbers. But many domestic investors are still unwilling to embrace this rally.

LEAD: Civilians firing a submachine gun shot and killed a teen-age Palestinian girl in the occupied West Bank today, despite new official warnings to Israelis to avoid taking the law into their own hands.

LEAD: A Navy Tomahawk cruise missile launched this morning from the Gulf of Mexico successfully completed a 450-mile test flight over Florida and Alabama, a Department of Defense spokesman said. The land-attack missile was launched about 9:15 A.M. from a submarine and was recovered after making a parachute landing in Eglin's test range, said Bob Holsapple of the Cruise Missile Project.

LEAD: Congratulations to you, Henry Stern, New York City's Parks and Recreation Commissioner, for strengthening security in Central Park before the gang attack on a female jogger, and for properly and promptly adding more police muscle after the attack. But now, in defiance of common sense, you are beefing up patrols to enforce absurd new restrictions on everyday park users.
LEAD: An aerial protest by graduate business school students briefly darkened Yale University's 288th commencement in New Haven yesterday.

LEAD: One of the trickiest problems facing New York City's Charter Revision Commission is to save the five borough presidents from political extinction. To that end, the commission would give them discretionary authority over part of the city budget. It's a generous idea but it can only complicate budgeting.

LEAD: In a long and often contentious day of testimony, the doctor who managed Ben Johnson's drug program for five years continued today to deny any complicity in Johnson's positive drug test at the Seoul Olympics last fall.

LEAD: The Spoleto Festival U.S.A. offers its performances in several theaters, auditoriums and churches around Charleston, some of which are striking for historical or architectural reasons. But the best place in town to hear music is the Dock Street Theater, a 463-seat hall built in 1736 and reconstructed in the 1930's.

LEAD: They are calling it the fling. It goes by other names as well, including stole, shawl, poncho, ruana, rebozo or just plain scarf. But fling is what it does, whether it is a long rectangle, perfect square or a series of undulating curves that arch around the neck and dip in front and back. It wraps cozily around the body, offering warmth, color and a graceful look to day and evening clothes.
LEAD: Ben Oglivie, a former Milwaukee Brewers outfielder, has signed a contract with the team's Class AA Texas League affiliate at El Paso.
LEAD: Despite some signs of softness, the economy is still growing and the chances of a serious slowdown or recession are remote, a number of analysts contend.

LEAD: Because the Democrats have been in command in the House of Representatives for more than 30 years, even during the Administrations of five Republican Presidents, does that mean power has corrupted the Democratic majority? LEAD: The winners of the prestigious Goldman Pairs, concluded Sunday night at the Penta Hotel, were Michael Radin of Manhattan and Carol Simon of Summit, N.J. They came out of the pack in the last session with a score of almost 70 percent, overtaking Win Allegaert and Allen Kahn of Manhattan, who placed second.

LEAD: Derek Lilliquist, a rookie, allowed one run and seven hits in seven innings today as the Atlanta Braves beat the Chicago Cubs, 2-1.

LEAD: It has become part of the conventional wisdom that black, Hispanic and Asian New Yorkers now account for more than half of the city's population. Elected officials frequently make the claim, as do newspapers, political candidates and members of civic groups.

LEAD: With a flourish of oratory, the two tenant representatives on New York City's Rent Guidelines Board quit last week after it tentatively approved 6 and 9 percent increases. They complained they had received too little information with which to appraise landlords' costs. Nothing on the record suggests that they cared to know anything about tenants' ability to pay.

LEAD: Mozart's ''Marriage of Figaro'' will open the sixth season of the June Opera Festival of New Jersey at 8 P.M. June 16 at the Allan P. Kirby Arts Center of the Lawrenceville School, at Route 206 and Route 546 in Lawrenceville. There will be evening performances as well on June 23 and July 1, and matinees at 3 P.M.

LEAD: Dr. Barry D. Gingell, who helped AIDS patients seeking speedier testing of experimental drugs and broader access to them, died of AIDS at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday. He was 34 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Many doctors say they would withhold information or mislead a patient's family to protect the patient, a new survey shows. But some doctors indicated that they would also practice such deception to protect themselves in extreme circumstances.

LEAD: IT came 15 or so years too late, but it was gratifying recently to read the British writer Jancis Robinson's description of Muscadet as ''the blind taster's bete noire.'' It was just about that long ago when a prominent Muscadet producer, Louis Metaireau, invited me to Nantes, the unofficial capital of Muscadet country, to taste his wines.

LEAD: As investigators looked for a motive, a young man charged with stabbing his mother, his brother and two other people to death in a suburban Springfield neighborhood appeared today before a Criminal Court judge, who set bail at $4 million and remanded him to the County Jail.
LEAD: The huge algae masses that muddied waters and devastated the rich marine ecosystem of eastern Long Island have subsided as mysteriously as they first appeared four years ago.

The sweetened offer gave Gateway holders a choice between 210 pence, or $3.30, a share in cash or 195 pence, or $3.06, in cash and at least 15 pence, about 24 cents, worth of Isosceles stock.

LEAD: AFTER a steady diet of exotic fruits and winter-stored apples, few things gladden the heart more than the sudden appearance of fresh, field-grown rhubarb. From mid-May through early July, this seasonal delight is available nationwide from Washington State and Michigan and from farmers in the Northeast who may grow as little as one acre.

LEAD: Sales of new homes were up a strong 10.9 percent in April, the Government said today, but housing economists said the industry would remain sluggish at least into summer because of high interest rates.

LEAD: Tom Webster, a former coach of the Rangers, reportedly has been hired as coach of the Los Angeles Kings.

LEAD: Broadway set a box-office record in the 1988-89 season, but attendance and the number of new productions declined, according to figures released yesterday by the League of American Theaters and Producers. There were more new plays than in the previous year, but there were decidedly fewer new musicals.

LEAD: Avon Products Inc. yesterday rebuffed an executive at Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc. who expressed interest last week in acquiring the direct-selling cosmetics company.

LEAD: Poland has accused Western governments, and specifically the United States, of interfering in the campaign for national elections this Sunday. The American Embassy immediately denied the charge.

LEAD: Talks between Libya's National Oil Corporation and five American oil companies on resuming operations in the North African country are deadlocked, the Middle East Economic Survey reported on Monday. The newsletter said the negotiations, which began in Vienna last month, were continuing, with both sides aiming for an agreement by June 30, the deadline set by the Libyans.

LEAD: Dr. Ernst A. H. Friedheim, a pathologist, microbiologist and chemist who developed drugs that saved the lives of three million victims of sleeping sickness and other tropical parasitic diseases, died of kidney cancer Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89 years old.

The oldest member of Congress, he was 88 years old and lived in Miami.

LEAD: Saying he hoped to help persuade Congress to impose tough new capital standards on savings and loan institutions, Warren Buffett, the Omaha investor, denounced the savings and loan industry's principal trade group yesterday and said the savings institution he controlled was withdrawing from the organization.

Gray 3d, the fourth-ranking Democrat in the House and a candidate for majority whip, said tonight that two F.B.I. agents visited him on Memorial Day to ask about allegations of wrongdoing by an employee. LEAD: Foreign investors spent $65 billion to acquire or establish United States businesses last year, up sharply from the $40.3 billion spent in 1987, the Government reported today.

LEAD: For many of New York's tournament players, Memorial Day was a beginning, or an end, or both. It was the start of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championships, with 12 teams surviving last night from an original entry of 40. Play will end Saturday.

LEAD: Chiat/Day, New York won a $10 million account yesterday from Bissell Inc., a home appliance manufacturer. LEAD: Newmark & Lewis Inc., the 47-store appliance and electronics chain based in Hicksville, L.I., announced a new pricing policy in which its products would be cut in price by 5 percent to 20 percent. The prices will take effect on June 1 in all stores in New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts.

LEAD: Like highway engineers adding extra lanes to freeways to eliminate traffic jams, computer designers are searching for new strategies to permit computers to execute several instructions simultaneously and thereby dramatically increase their speed.

LEAD: At first glance everything seemed right with the farmers' world around Floresville. The big combines were rolling across the fields, gathering in the golden grain at the start of another wheat harvest.

LEAD: Dr. Helen L. Robinson, a former research scientist at Dartmouth College working in the field of thyroid hormonal activity, died of multiple sclerosis Monday at a nursing home in New Haven. She was 44 years old and lived in New Haven.

LEAD: It was the heaviest rainstorm that had ever been recorded in western Pennsylvania. When the dam broke, 15 miles above Johnstown, it loosed a torrent that swept away 2,209 lives. The Johnstown flood, 100 years ago today, remains the worst such disaster in U.S. history.
LEAD: Alfred L. Teti, the chief operating officer of the Centrust Savings Bank in Miami, is moving to another Miami financial institution, the Amerifirst Bank, on a turnaround mission.

LEAD: The Gold Star Company will produce videotapes at its electronics plant in Huntsville, Ala., beginning in September. Officials said production facilities capable of turning out a million tapes a year are being installed at the plant, which has been operating since 1982.

LEAD: A series of campus protests this spring against Pentagon-financed research at the University of Massachusetts' Amherst campus have brought the arrests of dozens of people. Just one is a professor.

LEAD: Tired of working as janitors and cab drivers and automobile mechanics, 400 immigrants who were doctors in Nicaragua are pressing the state of Florida to change its licensing rules so they can practice medicine in this country.
LEAD: The city's Board of Supervisors today passed an ordinance giving legal recognition to the ''domestic partnership'' of homosexuals and unmarried heterosexual couples.

May 18, 1988: Common Cause, the public affairs lobby, calls for a House ethics inquiry into two matters. One is the financial arrangements surrounding the royalties that Speaker Jim Wright received from the publication of his book, ''Reflections of a Public Man.'' The other is allegations that the Speaker intervened with senior Federal bank regulators on behalf of troubled savings and loan associations.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company raised cash rebates on several cars and trucks and extended the other discounts that it had introduced in late March. Rebates on the Ford Tempo and the Bronco II increased $250, to $750, and those on the Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar rose $150, to $750. But the alternative of low-rate car loans, starting at annual interest rates of 2.9 percent for two-year contracts, will be available on fewer vehicles and a few truck models carry lower rebates.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 467 money market mutual funds increased by $599.30 million, to $312.68 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 141 institutional funds increased by $17.60 million, to $79.43 billion. The assets of the 231 general-purpose funds rose $414.20 million, to $101.66 billion.

LEAD: Andrew Homzy, a jazz historian from Canada, was cataloguing the late Charles Mingus's scores - piles of music paper stored in bags and boxes around the Manhattan apartment of his widow, Sue Mingus - when he started to find what seemed to be parts of larger pieces for jazz orchestra. One started with measure 417, another with 2,106; eventually, he realized that the stacks of frayed, yellowing, oversized manscript paper all fit together.

LEAD: A museum can be all things to all people. It can show great works of art, one by one, in isolation. LEAD: When his first recording of Bach's ''Goldberg Variations'' was released in 1956, the 23-year-old Glenn Gould became an immediate international star. In taking what had been regarded as a cerebral set of academic exercises and revealing the passion and beauty lurking beneath its glittering surface, he had also revealed himself as one of the world's most gifted and distinctive pianists - a pianist blessed with precision and intelligence, breathtaking speed and a rare ability to isolate contrapuntal lines and weave them back together again in a glorious pattern of sound.

LEAD: To see the most ambitious shows in New York City at this moment requires straying from the museums and wandering into SoHo where, as it happens, two important traveling exhibitions have stopped on Wooster Street.

LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company said today that it intends to offer $1.1 billion of debentures and use the proceeds to reimburse its treasury for construction expenses, to redeem outstanding bonds and to provide working capital.

LEAD: Back in that innocent time when drugs were ''reefers'' rather than a national tragedy, Tom Lehrer wrote a hilarious ballad singing the praises of that pillar of American folklore, ''The Old Dope Peddler.'' Mr. Lehrer's song was a put-on, of course, but William S. Leavengood, who expresses much the same sentiments in a new play titled ''Florida Crackers,'' doesn't appear to be joking.

LEAD: New York City schools can guard against corruption scandals by conducting background checks on certain employees and requiring them to give detailed financial statements, a state appeals court ruled today.

LEAD: Paul A. Bilzerian, under cross-examination after a request for a mistrial was denied, testified at his securities fraud trial yesterday that he had exchanged numerous fraudulent invoices with Jefferies & Company, the West Coast brokerage.

LEAD: The president of Queens College, Shirley Strum Kenny, told graduates at the college's 65th commencement yesterday, ''It will be your burden to continue the tradition of our commitment to civil liberties, the determination to right wrongs, to insure equality of opportunity for all Americans.''

LEAD: The Henley Group Inc. said it would recapitalize a subsidiary, the PA Holdings Corporation, shifting about $400 million from short-term to long-term debt. Henley, which has headquarters in La Jolla, Calif., and Hampton, N.H., said it would invest $100 million in cash and $75 million in notes in PA
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A Company Briefs listing in some editions of Business Day on May 17 gave an incorrect location for Charan Industries, which said it intended to sell a sporting goods subsidiary, Cooper Canada. Charan, a Canadian company, is based in Montreal and is not affiliated with Charan Industries of Garden City, L.I.

LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a long-awaited genetically engineered drug to treat anemia in kidney patients, and experts said it may also help some people with AIDS and cancer.

LEAD: The nation's large retailers reported yesterday that sales last month were better than in May 1988, but sales at several of the biggest chains barely kept up with inflation and in some cases rose less than the prices of their goods.

LEAD: Trio Con Brio Ray Brown Trio, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). One cannot identify Ray Brown simply as ''a bassist.'' He is one of the most celebrated bassists in jazz, having been the anchor of the original Dizzy Gillespie big band in the 1940's; an original member of the Modern Jazz Quartet, when it consisted of four members of the Gillespie band, and a longtime member of the Oscar Peterson Trio.

LEAD: As hundreds of protesters shouted ''Dump Koch,'' Mayor Edward I. Koch proclaimed the month of June as Lesbian and Gay Pride and History Month at a ceremony last night in Sheridan Square in Greenwich Village.

LEAD: President Bush reassured Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today that the close ties between the United States and Britain would continue despite Mr. Bush's view that West Germany is now the key to the future of the East-West relationship in Europe.

LEAD: The commander of the 30th Precinct, Capt. Richard Martin, strolled Edgecombe Avenue on the Upper West Side of Manhattan yesterday, patting children on the head and waving to elderly neighbors fanning themselves on the stoops. He wore a white shirt and a tight smile.
LEAD: High interest rates continued to hamper private construction in April, although total construction spending rose a weak one-tenth of 1 percent because of an upturn in work on public projects.
LEAD: Edsel Ford 2d, great-grandson of the Ford Motor Company's founder, was named executive director today of the auto maker's marketing staff, effective next month.
LEAD: Because of the Plantathon, a plant and crafts sale, the northbound lanes of Broadway between 72d and 79th Streets will be closed tomorrow from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M.

LEAD: A Brooklyn woman was released from jail yesterday after her husband returned to New York City with their 4-year-old son, whom he had taken from the hospital where he was to be treated for leukemia.

LEAD: Roy Lichtenstein's brightly painted bronze sculptures may not represent the artist at his best but they could hardly look snappier than they do lined up in the airy, ample space that is 65 Thompson Street, a new gallery under the joint direction of Leo Castelli and Larry Gagosian.

LEAD: House Speaker Jim Wright's intention to resign his Congressional seat prompted widespread sorrow and some anger among many of his fellow Texans today as they pondered the loss of a powerful favorite son.

LEAD: Accompanied by his wife, Joanne, and modest applause, he walked into a conference room brimming with 15 television camera crews, a sportscaster powdering his nose with makeup, a number of newspaper reporters and the 22 members of the University of Kentucky Athletics Association Board of Directors, as well as other university dignitaries.

LEAD: Antony Tudor, one of the 20th century's greatest choreographers, was especially attuned to the cruelties and inequities of life. Such concerns were once deemed outside ballet's province, but it was Tudor's achievement to treat them with expressive power and through an entirely innovative use of the classical dance idiom.

LEAD: The Lark String Quartet will perform Libby Larson's ''Alauda,'' Peter Schickele's String Quartet No. 2 and Jon Deak's ''Fundevogel'' as part of the Queens Symphony Orchestra's ''From the Left Bank'' series on Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock at P.S. 1, 46-01 21st Street, Long Island City, Queens. Tickets are $7.

LEAD: The Manhattan String Quartet will play all 15 of Shostakovich's string quartets in chronological order in four concerts this weekend at the Paramount Center for the Arts, 1008 Brown Street, in Peekskill, N.Y. The series begins tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock. The other performances are tomorrow evening at 7:30, and Sunday at 3 and 7:30 P.M.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A carefully scripted little ceremony at the Supreme Court this week lasted barely a minute. But for that moment, it opened a window on the select, tightly knit world of lawyers whose professional lives revolve around the nation's highest court.

LEAD: THOUGH President Bush put Japan, Brazil and India on the ''hit list'' of countries charged with unfair trade practices, and named a score of other countries to the ''watch list,'' everyone knows, including the Japanese, that it is overwhelmingly the American grievance against Japan that lies at the root of his decision to start using the so-called Super 301 section of the 1988 United

LEAD: For those who have already seen or cannot get tickets to ''The Heidi Chronicles'' and ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway,'' the presumed victors in Broadway's Tony Awards ceremony on Sunday night, there is still plenty of lively, not to mention enjoyable, theater to be found in New York this weekend.
LEAD: Jane Evans, who held several top retailing jobs before moving to investment banking, has returned to the business as head of a company with specialty stores throughout the Pacific region.

LEAD: A remarkably simple way of transplanting genes by using sperm as the vehicle has been discovered by Italian scientists in a research development that other specialists have described as surprising, even astounding.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the New Jersey Weekly section of The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. The Brass Rail Very Good (March 12, 1989), 135 Washington Street, Hoboken (201-659-7074) - The restaurant, behind etched-glass doors that mute the sounds of the pub downstairs, has the luxurious style of a French dining salon.
LEAD: De l'Alsace a Brandywine

LEAD: Ruth S. Tefferteller, a social worker and former associate director of the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side, died of cancer on May 15 at her home in Marblehead, Mass. She was 71 years old.
LEAD: On this summer's hottest days, the Dominic Bratta family here plans to go without air-conditioning for 40 minutes every hour.

LEAD: Shows, Nature, Museums Schedule ''UGLY AND THE BEAST: OR BEAUTY IS AS BEAUTY DOES,'' a play with original music, presented by the Appleseed Players, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Home for Contemporary Theater and Art, 44 Walker Street. Admission: children, $5; adults, $8. Reservations: 431-7434.

LEAD: Sousuke Uno accepted his appointment as president of the governing Liberal Democratic Party today. As he prepared to become Japan's 18th postwar Prime Minister he warned that the country ''has to save the bright and growing side of Japan from being overshadowed by the darkness'' of political corruption.
LEAD: Who is the most conservative Democratic candidate for mayor?

LEAD: Now that President Bush has become an instant hero among American foreign policy strategists, Heaven protect us, he may be able to devote more of his mind and time to a rather larger group of constituents.
LEAD: * Precision Tune Inc., to J. Walter Thompson, Detroit, with a budget of $5 million.
LEAD: As the farm crisis of the 1980's deepened, Dixon Terry rallied farmers who were beaten and weary, calling on them to turn their plowshares into political swords.
LEAD: Citibank is selling $845 million of credit card participation certificates through National Credit Card Trust, with the First Boston Corporation as lead underwriter for the financing.

LEAD: With the primary just a few days off, the Republican candidates for governor have turned their attention away from noble visions of the future to answer questions on how much the future is going to cost.
LEAD: Companies

LEAD: A chart on Monday listing winners of the New York City school board elections omitted a name for District 29 in Queens and included an erroneous name. The winner was Denise Richardson; Denis H. Stuart did not win.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Chinese Government has agreed to pay $25 million to stage a boxing match between the heavyweight champion, Mike Tyson, and the former champion George Foreman, Tyson's manager and the fight's promoter said yesterday.
LEAD: * Lou Centlivre announced his retirement as executive vice president of Foote, Cone & Belding, Chicago.

LEAD: In ''Vampire's Kiss,'' Nicolas Cage plays a literary agent named Peter Loew, a young man who keeps a photo of Kafka behind his desk and seems to suffer from garden-variety fear of commitment. When he finds the woman of his dreams, she turns out to be a creature who bites his neck passionately with her long fangs at night, and is sure to be out of his hair by dawn.
LEAD: Treasury bond prices were essentially unchanged yesterday as traders and investors marked time awaiting this morning's scheduled release of the employment data for May.

LEAD: An international panel has backed a contention by Australia that the United States violated trading rules by limiting its sugar imports, the Office of the United States Trade Representative said today.

LEAD: The chief of the K.G.B. said today that the newly elected Soviet legislature should have full authority over the state security agency, including power to approve the appointment of the K.G.B. chairman.

LEAD: ''A Paintings Retrospective'' is the title of Helen Frankenthaler's exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. Like the show itself, it is well chosen. We are warned from the outset that the confrontation is to be on the high, clear, level ground on which Ms. Frankenthaler has always excelled.

LEAD: In the first transfer of power from one elected civilian to another in El Salvador's history, a political neophyte was sworn in today as President amid rising concern that right-wing extremists have played a dominant role in shaping his administration.
LEAD: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn has indicted five men on charges of conspiring to export highly sophisticated underwater mapping and surveillance equipment to the Soviet Union.
LEAD: Stuart E. Jacobson, a writer of books on gift-giving, died Saturday at his home in Dallas. He was 34 years old.

LEAD: The Quaker State Corporation has completed its acquisition of McQuik's Oilube Inc. The acquisition was made Wednesday through an exchange of less than 3 percent of Quaker State's outstanding shares for all shares of McQuik's. McQuik's operates 71 fast car lubrication facilities in Indiana, Ohio, Florida, Kentucky, Maine, Michigan, South Carolina and Tennessee.

LEAD: Fifty-one new waterfront units at Four Beaches, one of the more dramatic condominium projects to be constructed along the Connecticut shoreline in the last few years, will be auctioned off at the Marriott Hotel in Trumbull, Conn., on June 25.

LEAD: The United States Tennis Association said yesterday that it had reached a five-year agreement with Tennis magazine, a publication of The New York Times Company, to produce the organization's membership magazine, Tennis USTA, beginning with the February issue. Tennis will distribute its own magazine along with the association's publication to the 350,000 members of the association.

LEAD: Charles E. McDonnell Jr., a stockbroker and president of McDonnell & Company (Bermuda Ltd.), died of cancer yesterday at his home in Paget, Bermuda. He was 41 years old and had lived in Bermuda since 1972.

LEAD: President Bush's arms control initiatives at the NATO summit meeting appear to have deflated much of the criticism that his Administration was not being responsive enough to the ''new thinking'' of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

LEAD: The chairman of a healthy California savings and loan association calls his industry's lobbying to weaken the S & L bailout bill ''disgraceful'' - as bad as if Exxon, after the Valdez oil spill, had called for the ''liberal use of whisky by tanker captains.'' Charles Munger of Pasadena's Mutual Savings and Loan Association vented his thoughts in an angry letter canceling Mutual's membership in the U.S.

LEAD: GOLF Weibring Ties Kemper Record: D. A. Weibring tied a course record with a seven-under-par 64 yesterday for a one-shot lead over Fred Funk after the first round of the Kemper Open in Potomac, Md. Weibring nearly missed the tournament with an infected toe. He withdrew after nine holes of the Pro-Am on Wednesday, but received treatment.

LEAD: President Bush has scored an unmistakable triumph in Europe, calming potential crisis within NATO and dramatizing his leadership with a strong proposal for conventional arms reductions. Good for him and good for us, but . . .

LEAD: * Black & Decker Corp., Towson, Md., said it plans to sell Dynapert, a maker of automatic assembly machinery for the electronics industry, and its Mallory and Arcotronics capacitors businesses. The units were all acquired in its purchase of Emhart Corp.

LEAD: Tucked away in the small gallery near the top of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum are 19 collages and assemblages by Hannelore Baron. They are a useful foil to the main show - the retrospective of Arnulf Rainer, the contemporary Austrian artist whose effusive performances on paper and canvas struggle with confinement and oblivion in a furious, almost exhibitionistic way.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II arrived here today on the first visit by a Pope to Scandinavia, bringing a message of ecumenism to a Protestant stronghold where Roman Catholicism has long struggled to survive.

LEAD: A 500-pound slab of concrete fell from beneath the northbound lanes of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive near 21st Street last night, crashed through a car windshield and fatally injured the driver, the police said.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: If cabaret is an endangered species of entertainment, there are still new clubs popping up around Manhattan. When Rainbow and Stars opened in January on the 65th floor of the RCA Building, it became the crown jewel of the city's intimate cabarets. The luxuriously appointed room has perfect acoustics and offers a spectacular view north over Central Park.

LEAD: A summary of a sealed deposition created a sensation today in a trial in Federal District Court to decide the ownership of four sixth-century mosaics from a church in Cyprus. The summary, read aloud by a lawyer for the Government and Church of Cyprus, who say the mosaics were stolen and are seeking their return, revealed previously unknown details of the financial arrangements in their purchase.

LEAD: The Gibraltar Financial Corporation, parent company of Gibraltar Savings and Loan of Beverly Hills, Calif., said it would not make a $1.02 million interest payment due today to bondholders. If the payment, due to holders of $22 million worth of 9 1/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2008, is not made by

LEAD: The power of the Speaker's gavel began to pass today from Jim Wright of Texas to Thomas S. Foley of Washington, who quickly sent a message of calm and reassurance to his battered House colleagues on both sides of the aisle and appealed for their support.

LEAD: CAN a company really guarantee the value of its own securities? The Western Union Corporation is finding that it is hard to live up to such a promise. At best, the cost will be severe dilution for the company's shareholders. At worst, the company could run out of cash.

LEAD: The productivity of American workers slipped in the first quarter, while unit labor costs rose 6.6 percent on an annual basis, the Labor Department said today. Analysts cited the report as proof both of a slowing economy and stubborn inflation.

LEAD: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto arrives on Tuesday for a five-day visit at a critical time in U.S.-Pakistani relations. Her efforts to reassert democratic civilian control over political and foreign policy questions, including the war in Afghanistan, deserve the strongest U.S. support. Yet foreign aid programs are jeopardized by

LEAD: ''I have never been driven by a desire to become Speaker. I'm not a fatalist. But I am one who thinks circumstance, happenstance, accident has a lot to do with what happens in a political career.'' - Representative Thomas S. Foley. [ A1:5. ]

LEAD: Scoring 100 points in the Eastern Conference final is proving to be difficult for the Chicago Bulls and the Detroit Pistons.

LEAD: Contributions of broadcast time and print space for public service advertising increased a record 22 percent in 1988, the Advertising Council reported yesterday. The council and the Media-Advertising Partnership for a Drug-Free America, two affiliated organizations that say they account for roughly one-third of all public service advertising in the United

LEAD: Last month, Cathy L. Petryshyn, marketing director at Benesch, Friedlander, Coplan & Aronoff, held a seminar for the Cleveland firm's 165 lawyers on how to sell their legal services. But aware that lawyers cringe at the thought of giving their clients a sales pitch, she took care to avoid using the word ''sell.

LEAD: A birthday party for Martha Washington will be held 2:30 to 4 P.M. Sunday at Washington's headquarters in Newburgh, N.Y., in Orange County, on the banks of the Hudson River.

LEAD: As part of its celebration of the bicentennial of the French Revolution, the French Institute/Alliance Francaise is presenting Concert Royal and the New York Baroque Dance Company in performances of ''Le Devin du Village,'' a one-act opera by Jean Jacques Rousseau. The production opened on Tuesday evening at Florence Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street, and will be repeated there next Wednesday through Saturday.
LEAD: The three primary unions of Eastern Airlines yesterday won an additional day to put together a viable offer to buy the airline, but their chances of meeting the deadline appeared doubtful.

LEAD: Although the search for a new schools chancellor for New York City has yet to begin in earnest, more than a dozen people fit the preliminary qualifications sought by the Board of Education, say educators, board officials, union leaders and others.
LEAD: Two leading international conservation groups called today for an immediate worldwide ban on imports of ivory to prevent a threatened catastrophe for African elephants.

LEAD: After seven and a half years of record growth, Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that earnings for the fourth quarter, ending June 30, will be significantly below the results for the period a year ago. Depending on revenues, Sun said, it could even report a slight loss.

LEAD: In a tremulous falsetto, with phrases that ripple and float, Aaron Neville sings of perfect romance and intricate pain. He's a member of the Neville Brothers band, for whom he delivers change-of-pace ballads and fills out harmonies, but on Tuesday night at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights, accompanied by Asa
LEAD: Audrey Mars, a civic leader and longtime volunteer in cancer organizations, died yesterday from complications of cancer at her home in Washington. She was 79 years old.
LEAD: Lawrence Keville Larson, a retired lumber company official, died May 25 at his home in Chapman, Ala. He was 90 years old and had been ill for several months.

LEAD: Two pay-cable presentations are among the more prominent offerings this weekend. One, a movie called ''Looking for Miracles,'' is on the Disney Channel at 7 o'clock tomorrow evening. That's a problem for many New Yorkers because Manhattan Cable TV does not carry the Disney Channel, the winner in a Consumer Reports poll asking which cable service generates the most subscriber satisfaction.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The missing voice at this year's Van Cliburn International Piano Competition made itself heard for the first time in the early hours of this morning from the stage of the Landreth Auditorium at Texas Christian University here. Speaking at 12:45 A.M., John Giordano announced the first decisions of the 14-member jury of which he is chairman - the 12 competitors who will go on to the semifinal round of the quadrennial event.
LEAD: Chris Rea

LEAD: C. L. R. James, the Trinidadian-born historian, literary critic and philosopher who was a leader of the pan-African movement, died suddenly of a chest infection Wednesday at his home in London. He was 88 years old.
LEAD: The varsity eights from Cornell, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin won their heats this morning to qualify for Saturday's championship race at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's annual regatta.

LEAD: In Washington nothing quite tops a fight over a monument that is to take note of a war. The squabble over the design of the Vietnam Memorial comes first to mind. Despite the fact that the black stone slash in the Mall is just about the most popular visitor's site in town, it still draws periodic outbursts that it is too pacifically abstract or not heroic enough.
LEAD: Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos today established tough penalties against colleges and trade schools with large proportions of former students who default on federally backed loans.

LEAD: Scott Bryant, a versatile junior player for the University of Texas, was selected as the college player of the year by the American Baseball Coaches Association yesterday as the Longhorns prepared for the College World Series, which begins today in Omaha. Bryant, who hit 18 home runs and led the nation with 108 runs batted in and 31 doubles, was an outfielder, a designated hitter, a first baseman and pitcher for Texas.

LEAD: A tour of Hudson River houses will take place tomorrow from 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. in Coxsackie and Athens in Greene County, along Route 385, which runs parallel to the river. Picnic lunches will be offered for sale along the route. Admission: $7.50. Information: (518) 731-6822. To get to the starting point: take the Gov.

LEAD: School authorities refused tonight to say when they first learned of allegations that a mentally impaired girl had been sexually assaulted March 1 by five members of the high school football team.

LEAD: An 18-year search for one of the nation's most wanted fugitives - a New Jersey man who vanished when his mother, wife and three children were found shot to death in 1971 - ended in Virginia yesterday after his case was featured on a national television program.

LEAD: On paper it seemed like a perfect match. White & Case gave Rudolph W. Giuliani an establishment image, a generous income and a long leash for his extracurricular political activities. And whether he became mayor or not, Mr. Giuliani would be a classic ''rainmaker'' for staid old White & Case, bringing it new clients, new visibility and new panache.
LEAD: Fans of folk music in the broadest senses, stylistically and geographically, can hear a world of local styles this weekend in Manhattan.

LEAD: Jack H. Docktor, a Miami investor, has acquired a 5.2 percent stake in National Lampoon Inc., the New York-based publisher of the monthly humor magazine. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Docktor said he had acquired the National Lampoon shares for investment purposes. He said he had bought 81,500 shares in the open market for an average price of $3.72.
LEAD: * HBM/Creamer Direct, the direct marketing subsidiary of Della Femina McNamee WCRS, has changed its name to DFM Direct.

LEAD: The House Republican leader, Robert H. Michel, today called for an end to disclosures of criminal investigations against House members and urged Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to consider the appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate the disclosures.

LEAD: Donald K. Ballman, retired senior vice president of the Dow Chemical Company, Midland, Mich., died in his sleep Wednesday at his daughter's home in Hinsdale, Ill. He was 79 years old and lived in La Jolla, Calif.

LEAD: SOMEDAY it may be said that advertising's battle for Europe was won on the playing fields of New Haven. It was there, in 1956, that Joseph E. DeDeo, a Princeton sophomore, met Alexander Kroll, a sophomore at Yale, in a contest for the Ivy League football championship.
